LESSON II Work and Business (Second Week in October)
TEACHERS' TOPIC FOR OCTOBER—THE HOME
The Home as a Social Center
"I do not believe that this nation has ever produced in its history a finer type of youth than the present generation, but I am convinced that society, the home, and the school are not measuring up to the responsibilities which rightfully belong to them."—Judge Fred R. Morgan of the Juvenile Court, Salt Lake City.
I. Among the family group. A. Agreeable conversation. B. Music. C. Games. D. Well planned social periods. E. Proper use of meal times as social periods. F. Special programs.
II. For association with friends. A. The home a place for friendships and mutual visits. B. Encourage children to entertain friends at home. C. Group parties. Facilities for entertaining. Interest in the group. Hospitality. Suggestive programs for entertaining groups of different ages, delightful and in keeping with L. D. S. Ideals.
"Make the home the most dignified, attractive, and charming place to be found. The place to rush to, rather than to rush from—a place of arrival rather than a place of departure. A place fulfilling every noble desire."—Elder Stephen L. Richards.
Robert Colley Angell, in the March number of the Forum, just off the press, in an article entitled, "Roots of College Evils," has this to say on this subject:
"Nowadays, the parents, distracted by other duties and absorbed in their own pleasures, turn the larger share of the task of education over to the schools; while the children do not find the learning process adventurous enough to compete with the more colorful pursuits at hand. * * * A quiet evening in the family circle, talking, reading, or playing games, is a rare exception in modern American life. Parents as well as children find their amusement elsewhere after the evening meal."
GUIDE LESSONS FOR OCTOBER 445
LESSON III Literature (Third Week in October)
BERTHA A. KLEINMAN
Bertha A. Kleinman was born in a part of Salt Lake City familiar to many of our readers. It was in the region of the 18th ward, taking in the hills that in her childhood were carpeted with wild flowers and that followed the trail of City Creek to the old mill—a place regarded with awe and delight by the children who listened to the whirr of the big wheel and saw the crystal waters of City Creek splash over it. The details of this sketch have been furnished by Mrs. Kleinman's mother. We follow these details rather closely; but before making use of the biographical material, we wish to pay tribute to Mrs. Kleinman for the recognition she has received in various magazines of the country. She is certainly one of the best known poets of this intermountain region, one of whom we are sure the State of Arizona is justly proud, for her poems have been published in Harper's Bazar, The Ladies' Home Journal, Little Folks, Out West, Pacific Coast Musician, Our Dumb Animals, The Classmate, The Quarterly Review, Child's Garden, The Boy's Comrade, The Young American, The National Conservation Bulletin; recently eight were accepted for the new Latter-day Saints' Hymnology. Her mother writes: "She was born October 1, 1877, on the brow of the hill overlooking City Creek Canyon. Her favorite haunts were the canyon and hills about. Her father, James Anderson, was of Danish descent, one of Utah's pioneers, who emigrated to Utah as a young man, walking the entire distance across the plains. Her mother, Eliza Clissold Anderson, emigrated with her parents from Birmingham, England, as a little girl of twelve." In the name of our poet, Bertha Eliza, we recognize her mother's name; yet that same mother assures us that the thought in naming her was not only that she should retain her mother's name, but that she should be called after Eliza Roxey Snow, the distinguished writer of Latter-day Saint hymns. Whether there is anything in a name or not is perhaps a matter of conjecture; however that may be, it would seem that the spirit of Eliza R. Snow has been with Mrs. Kleinman; for, like her famed predecessor, she has written many songs and is now the author of a group of Latter-day Saint hymns. She tells us that Apostle Orson F. Whitney, himself a poet and her bishop when she lived in Salt Lake, has been a great inspiration to her and that John Nicholsen, a neighbor, who discovered her
446 RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE
talent for verse writing at a very early age, did much to encourage her. Her first poem was published in one of the earliest numbers of the Young Woman's Journal when Susa Young Gates was its editor. Bertha was then only twelve years of age. Mrs. Gates wrote her a letter, explaining somewhat the technique of metrical composition. "After thirty-five years," says Mrs. Kleinman's mother, "I find it still preserved in her scrapbook. She says it has been of more value to her than all the treatises on Rhetoric, or the lexicons of synonyms and rhymes that are the guides of students today." "She first went to school in the old adobe school house just within the Eagle Gate—the school house erected by President Young for his own children. Here she wrote her first poem upon her slate; this was a eulogy of her fellow students, and it received favorable comment from her teachers, Dr. Ada B. Faust and Gideon M. Mumford, who did much to encourage her childish efforts." To follow her mother's narrative: "At the age of thirteen she graduated from the 18th ward L. D. S. Seminary and was chosen class poet and Valedictorian. At the age of eighteen she graduated from the L. D. S. College, having received her Certificate in Kindergarten training from the Brigham Young University of Provo. For two years she taught under the Utah Kindergarten Association, then again entered the L. D. S. College for a course in Business Training, taking a position in the Presiding Bishop's Office at the end of a few months. She was the first girl to enter the employ of the Presiding Bishopric and retained her position for seven years, at which time she married." The union was with Orson C. Kleinman, a member of a well known Arizona family and an employee of the Utah Idaho Sugar Company. Elder Kleinman had but recently returned from a mission to Germany. His main business interests as a cattle man, were in Arizona; so they sold their home in Salt Lake and moved to Mesa, where they have since resided. Undoubtedly Mrs. Kleinman has been a very real asset to the community in which she has lived these many years. She is now the mother of four stalwart sons and two lovely daughters, who have been the chief source of her inspiration through the busy years of home-building and community service. Her tribute to them she has often expressed in the words, "I have everything to do to live up to my children." "Always an ardent worker in the auxiliary organizations, Mrs. Kleinman has taught in every department of the Sunday School, being an officer of both ward and Stake before her marriage, in the 18th, 10th and 33rd wards. For three years she was Kindergarten Supervisor of the Sunday Schools of
GUIDE LESSONS FOR OCTOBER 447
Liberty Stake, was also first counselor in the Y. L. M. I. A. to President Lotta Paul Baxter, for whom she formed a lifelong friendship. In the Emerson ward she was a Primary executive for two years. During her residence in Mesa, she has taught in the Relief Society and Primary, and for two years has been an executive in the Stake Primary. She has served seven years on the Y. L. M. I. A. Stake Board, and is now first counselor to President Lisana Brimhall in its Presidency. "In a civic way, she has always been active, being Publicity chairman of the Musician's Club for three years, and chairman of the Legislative and Applied Education Departments of the Woman's Club of Mesa for the past three years. During that time she has also been Secretary of the Mesa Commercial Club, stenographer of the Mesa Rotary Club, and Librarian of the Mesa City Library—positions which she recently resigned when appointed as Assistant Recorder of the Arizona Temple. Her work has been addressed to all walks of life. She is never too hurried to pen her contribution—her toast, her measure of consolation—and no one, from the tiniest child or the humblest supplicant, has ever been refused her tribute. In sorrow, in illness and distress, as likewise in joy and congratulation, her word of cheer has found its way into the homes of hundreds. She has a touching fondness for the aged, and some of her best work has been written in eulogy and admiration for them. Her files contain letters of appreciation from senators, legislators, governors of states, ministers, from Mrs. Warren G. Harding, Mrs. Calvin Coolidge, Carrie Jacobs Bond, and numerous editors and commentators." Any knowledge of Bertha A. Kleinman's poems will reveal the fact that she is a versatile writer. Two of her poems that we print here were undoubtedly inspired by her own children. A poem that she calls one of her favorites is entitled "The Kingdom" and is a tribute to her own boys and girls. Another, entitled "Your Boy," was very likely written to her own husband, but is applicable, of course, to all fathers. We shall here include "The Kingdom" and follow with "Your Boy."
THE KINGDOM
If I would fathom the miracle Of God's magnanimity, I need but serve at the oracle Where my little child trusts in me;
If I would reason his Providence, With logic pro and con, I need but treasure the confidence, My children build upon.
448 RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE
If I would travel the Holy-land, I need not travel far, For the Kingdom borders near at hand, Where the feet of the children are;
If I would merge my trust supreme, In the might of His diagram, I need but soar on my children's dream, And be what they think I am.
Your Boy
There isn't a boy in the world—not one— But longs to be big like you, Who thrills at the sound when you call him "Son" And copies the things you do,
Whose shoulders, braced to the world's demand, Are squared and broad and strong; As yours are squared when you take his hand And lead that boy along.
There isn't a boy on the wide-flung map But longs for your manly pace, Who chafes at the years and the long-grown gap Till he stands with you face to face,
A kingly giant in miniature, Evolving might on might— A god to be, just as true and sure As you lead that boy aright!
Mrs. Kleinman has written many tributes to friends, a splendid example of this style of writing and one that will, we are sure, tend to give comfort to women in general, is a tribute to Ellen E. Tiffany, which follows:
A TRIBUTE TO OUR BELOVED SISTER, ELLEN E. TIFFANY
There's so much we loved about her—constancy and zeal throughout her, Oh, so much that made us glad to call her friend! Yet we knew it too about her that a day could dawn without her, And how little it would count to tell it then.
There were days when she was worried, when we passed by all too hurried, Knowing well the grind and stress of every day; Days when she was tired, tested, and her right to joy molested, Yet we passed in careless greeting on our way.
GUIDE LESSONS FOR OCTOBER 449
Well and fit—she never wavered to request or sue for favor, That perhaps would be so easy to bestow, When we knew no other neighbor has a conscience that was braver, Yet we chanced some other day to let her know.
In the needs of every hour, with her faith and love and power, She has carved her monumentals deeply, daily, on and on; We have learned to know her tether by her splendid, staunch endeavor, How slow we were to pass her praise along.
Oh, why is it hard to tell it, when we have such words to spell it— Things she richly earned and needed us to say? Why should scenes like this approach us, wring our heartstrings and reproach us, For the flow'rs we failed to strew along her way!
Lowly toil—she knew its meaning, days of hers were filled and teeming, Yet with smiles she met each handicap and care, Yes, she smiled when days were dreary—others gloomy—she was cheery, And we're going to miss her good smile everywhere.
In the days that dawn without her, you who loved and clung about her, May her sunshine linger ever at your side; And though God has seemed to smite you, He will heal and bless and guide you, In her footsteps where her star is sanctified!
Mrs. Kleinman appreciated Art. Her poem, "In Things of Art," will, we feel, substantiate this statement.
IN THINGS OF ART
I builded an epic, line on line, Of stately diction and chaste design, Each canto girt with metric song, But all in all my theme was wrong— My ode from art was fugitive— I left Love out and it will not live.
I fashioned a tale of lustrous deed, And sent it forth for the world to read, With gibe and satire unafraid, With quirp and quirk to lend it aid— I placed my treatise on revue, But Love—not there—my book died, too.
450 RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE
I thrilled a song on an ether length, And sent it forth in its pristine strength, Attuned to rote of staff and score, A brilliant cleft of sounds—no more— I left Love out and my song rebounds, An argosy of empty sounds.
And so I fail in things of art, Who spurn the dictum of the heart, My soul with Love must teem and burn, My soul for yours must writhe and yearn, For the force of maul and the fire of pen Is Love, much Love for my fellow men!
We are told that Mrs. Kleinman has always been deeply interested in civic life. In her poem, "The Beautiful City," she certainly expresses a wholesome attitude toward the community where she lives. In every city there are critics who would make one feel that everything is wrong in that particular city in which they live. Mrs. Kleinman's attitude is wholesome, fresh and full of faith.
THE BEAUTIFUL CITY
What matter the lure and the calling Of places I never shall see— Wherever the sunlight is falling The Beautiful City may be.
What matter the strands that are sainted, With laurel and temple and shrine, Wherever my vision is painted Is the Beautiful City of mine.
What matter the song and the story, What matter the star in the East, The rays on my home-land are glory, And make it the City of Peace.
What matter the shores that are holy While Truth is resplendent and free, My own—be it ever so lowly, Is THE BEAUTIFUL CITY TO ME.
She loves trees, and "My Trees" is an evidence of this fact.
MY TREES
Trees seem like people, fine and tall, And shedding down their good— I never think of trees at all Like common logs of wood;
GUIDE LESSONS FOR OCTOBER 451
For trees have limbs and climb and grow, And trees can PINE and gasp, And trees get scared when tempests blow And shake like QUAKING Asp.
Some trees are grand—like mighty Oaks And grown themselves for use, And some are POPULAR, same as folks, And some are trim and SPRUCE.
Trees seem like mothers when they hide The birds and nests so high, And tuck the soft leaves all outside And rock them when they cry.
Trees build my home so snug and fine, And furnish it complete— They keep me cool in summer time, In winter give me heat.
The lovely fruit, the maple sap, The nuts that fall for me— There's scarce a thing that's worth a rap That wasn't born a tree.
Lost in the woods, so damp and raw, And wandering in the storm, I'd hunt an ELDER like my pa And FIRS to keep me warm.
And so I never think at all That trees are logs of wood, But just like people fine and tall And shedding down their good.
In the sketch furnished by her mother, she tells us that she is very fond of aged people and has written many poems devoted to them. "The Faith of My Fathers" is a very good example of this interest.
THE FAITH OF MY FATHERS
I sit at the feet of the old, old folk, The bent and the halt and the grey, And I string the pearls from the good lips spoke, For a learned folk are they.
I fondle the hands of the old, old folk, And a courage new is born, For theirs is the strength of the tempered oak, In the fingers gnarled and worn.
452 RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE
I welcome the smile of the old, old folk, The wrinkled and comely cheer, And proud am I when I invoke The praise of an old compeer.
I look in the eyes of the old, old folk, In the windows dulled and dim, Where vision lightens with master-stroke The sight that is turned to Him.
I follow the wake of the old, old folk, And reap the goodly seed, Over fruited trail that their feet have broke, Where the steps of the fathers lead.
I stand for the faith of the old, old folk, The light of the world to be, I stand for the standards their lives invoke, For their faith is the faith for me!
There is a spirit of reverence and devotion to God in all that she writes. Her poem entitled "Joy" tends to impart joy and no one, we feel, can read it in the spirit in which it is written, without having his or her joy increased.
JOY
The reason for all that lives and dies, For all that moves and feels and breathes, The meaning of earth and of Paradise— Is Joy, the Joy that Truth bequeathes!
The depths, the heights of a soul subdued, The end, the all, the blessedness, The fullness of each Beatitude, Is lo! The promise of happiness.
The rite and rote of philosophy, The ultimo of text and song, Religion's troth to man must be A thing of joy or its theme is wrong.
An angel fell, nay, a God came down To turn the key of mortality, That faith should bide and joy encrown To the furthermost posterity.
And the stars that swung to their glad employ When the earth was new and life was youth, The "Stars of the Dawn" that sang for Joy, Are singing yet at the feet of Truth.
GUIDE LESSONS FOR OCTOBER 453
The themes which Mrs. Kleinman makes use of have their roots in the every-day lives of men, women and children, and for that very reason they will make a broad appeal. It is of the people with whom she mingles daily and the people who pass her door that she writes, and from this class she is bound to receive heartfelt thanks and blessings. There are few of our writers who have contributed so consistently and constantly to all of the Church publications for so many years as Bertha Anderson Kleinman. Her mother assures us that it is from the Church publications she has received her best encouragement and for them her best efforts are always reserved. "Her first book was copyrighted and published when she was twenty years of age and represented about one hundred of her maiden-day poems. She has on hand at the present time material for several books and contemplates their production in serial volumes under the titles of 'Friends Like You,' 'Babes Like You,' 'Mothers Like You,' 'Boys Like You,' 'Girls Like You.'" "Asked to name her own favorite poems, Bertha always remarks, 'If it fits the needs of someone, it is my favorite.'"
GRACE INGLES FROST
The sketch of Miss Grace Ingles Frost which we are presenting to our readers was written by her friend Maude Ellen Baggerley, also a poet whose own singing was hushed in death sometime ago. We feel sure that our readers will appreciate this sketch from one intimate with Miss Frost. Grace Ingles Frost, daughter of John Franklin and Elizabeth Grace Mackintosh Frost, was born in Salt Lake City, Utah, September 24, 1874. Owing to the fact that she very early gave evidence of being an extremely sensitive, nervous child, she was not permitted to enter school until her tenth year. Previous to that time, she received instruction at home; chiefly in the use of the needle. From her mother and grandmother, who were both skillful needle-women, she seems to have inherited an adaptability for such work. At all events, even in her extreme youth, she proved to be a very apt pupil. By her Scotch grandmother, she had been taught very rigidly by the time she reached her seventh year, that "anything worth doing, is worth doing well." A stitch that was not considered perfect, or very nearly so, was never allowed to remain in the child's work. While she sewed her fine seams, she was taught to repeat,
454 RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE
"Whatever you do, Do with your might, For things done by half, Are never done right."
The result of this early discipline is that Grace Ingles Frost has become an expert with the needle. Even her plain sewing is poetry. She has been awarded cash prizes and diplomas for every piece of work that she has exhibited in Salt Lake City and elsewhere. Ever generous with her gifts, she has taught many women to make exquisite laces and embroidery, besides those attending her regular classes; and she has tutored (gratis) numerous students who have been backward in English; thus enabling them to receive coveted degrees. Grace Ingles Frost's formal education was received in Salt Lake City, from Miss Lyde Wells (who conducted a private school); the Collegiate Institute, and our L. D. S. Institutions of learning. She has also taken special work in English at various times, in later years: and has become deeply versed in Theology, which amounts to almost a passion with her. After leaving school Miss Frost became interested in millinery work. For a number of years, she designed and made hats for persons of fastidious fancy in such matters of apparel. Later, she took a course in nursing, passed a perfect examination, and during the years she has practiced has done splendid work. Her grandmother's precepts are too deeply ingrained in her being to permit her to neglect even those things which might seem to another to be trifling details. She believes that seeming trifles are stepping-stones to perfection. In 1908, she was offered the position of Instructor of English Composition and Domestic Arts in a Church High School in Southern Utah. She was forced to refuse this offer, however, because of not being in robust health, and also because its acceptance would necessitate her resignation from other Church duties, in which she was deeply interested. Grace Ingles Frost has been associated with almost every phase of woman's work, in the Church. She became a teacher in Sunday School at an early age and served in that capacity for many years. She has served as instructor in Advanced Religion Class work, as chorister and instructor in the Primary Association, as president of the Y. L. M. I. A. in Waterloo Ward, Granite Stake, and as aide on the Granite Stake Board of the Y. L. M. I. A. In the latter position, she acted as instructor of Theology at the Stake House. Illness or weather or both combined never prevented her from being at her post, nor from being perfectly prepared.
GUIDE LESSONS FOR OCTOBER 455
Order and perfection, or at least something very nearly approaching the latter, characterize her work. She always gives her best and gives lavishly. At one time, Miss Frost possessed a beautiful singing voice. She was a member of the Salt Lake Tabernacle and ward choirs, and was also heard in concert work. A severe illness deprived her of the gift of song, but music still lives on in her soul, and she strives to express it, if only in words. Many years, that should have been the best in her life, have been spent as an invalid. Few people have endured the excruciating agony that has been her portion, and few people have won the steadfast friends, who have been ever ready to serve her in her terrible periods of illness. Being deeply religious, the storms of life have apparently never caused her to envy the more fortunate ones about her, however cruelly those storms may have bruised her. In 1910, Miss Frost received a letter from Richard Badger of the Gorham Press, Boston, Mass., stating that he had read a number of her poems in the Young Woman's Journal and that he would like to publish a volume of her verse. To this proposition, Miss Frost replied in the negative. She thanked Mr. Badger for his interest, but assured him that she was not then ready to have a book published. She felt that her work was not sufficiently important to warrant its publication in book form at that time. Miss Frost was quite young when she first began to write prose, but she never submitted any of her work for publication until she attained to her twenty-eighth year. It was due to the suggestion of her cousin, Mahonri Young, the now internationally known sculptor and painter, that she began to express herself in verse. One day, while Mr. Young was visiting at Miss Frost's home, a copy of an Oregon publication, to which she was contributing a series of articles on Utah's natural scenic beauty, was received by her. The paper contained a sketch from her pen entitled, "Brighton by Moonlight." After reading the description, Mr. Young asked Miss Frost why she had never written verse. He said, "Grace, almost everything that you write is poetical prose. All this lacks to make it poetry, is meter. Try verse writing next time." Several days later, four manuscripts were handed to me to read. The suggestion given by Miss Frost's cousin fanned into flame the embers of a desire that had been hers since childhood. She told me later how she prayed that she might be able to write verse and that her prayer had been answered. All she needed was the stimulus that she had received that day.
456 RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE
I persuaded Miss Frost to submit her verses for publication and all were accepted. Since that time, she has, now and then, written a prose article or a short story, but verse is her chosen medium for expression, and through that medium her best work has been done. In all, Grace Ingles Frost is the author of several hundred poems, numerous prose articles, and a number of short stories. Her work has been published chiefly in Utah, but also in Oregon and in Oklahoma. She has been urged, frequently, to send her verses to more distant fields. Her reply has been—"I prefer to be known by my own people and to give them my best work." It is often asserted that women who incline to literary work are not domesticated. This cannot be truthfully said of Miss Frost. She is an immaculate housekeeper and an excellent cook. Among other things, she has shown considerable ability as an amateur painter of exquisite water colors; and she has designed, printed and bound two books by hand. She possesses a wonderful color-sense, which is shown in many of her verses. Her great love for children has inspired much of her work. Her nature poems testify to her fondness for nature and all that is beautiful. Grace Ingles Frost's chief characteristics are loyalty, uncompromising, outspoken candor, (an excellent thing for making enemies); a Christ-like sympathy for the oppressed and weak of the earth, and an overwhelming desire to do with her might everything that her hands find to do. Many a young girl's feet would have strayed had Grace Ingles Frost not set them in the path of right, even though she has, at times, received cold scorn from some self-righteous Levite. Her motto has ever been, "Do right and fear no man." Miss Frost has been a contributor to practically all of the Church magazines, her very early poems appearing in the Young Woman's Journal and in the Juvenile Instructor. Readers of the Tribune and undoubtedly of the Deseret News have come in contact with her writings. She tells us that her ability to write verse has been the means of casting much sunshine 'over an otherwise sorrowful life.' One of these gladdening experiences happened during the present year. The Adams Ward Relief Society, Los Angeles Stake, has asked that a chair with a metal plate bearing Miss Frost's name be placed in its new auditorium. She writes "you may be sure that their appreciation (meaning her sisters who have shown her this honor) of my literary efforts has made me desire more earnestly to produce work which might merit such a kindly tribute GUIDE LESSONS FOR OCTOBER 457 The wonderful letters of appreciation received from this society have caused me to wonder how my verses could possibly inspire such words." During the past year Miss Frost has been invited to join the International League of Writers. She adds, "I did not accept the invitation because writing is my pleasure and not my profession." Miss Frost has a very deep-seated love for nature and writes some of her most beautiful lines when contemplating and reveling in the beauties of nature. As an example of this we include: APPLE BLOSSOMS Dainty, modestly blushing things, Fragile as the gossamer wings Of the small creatures clothed i in cloth of gold; That flit from flow'r to flow'r and dip Down to the heart of you to sip The nectar hidden there for ages old. Dainty, modestly blushing things, From out your midst the wild bird flings A flood of. Lilting notes upon the wind, To bind them in a sheaf of song That makes me glad the whole day long, Down 'neath the bowers of bloom you've intertwined. Dainty, modestly blushing things, The breeze with gentle mischief brings You pattering down, a fragrant shower, That lulls my senses, aye, and soothes My restive spirit 'til it woos Me into oneness with the Divine Power. Dainty, modestly blushing things, Within my soul a pean rings, For busy bees ahum and boughs abloom, And for the blithesome notes that float From the treasure of the feathered throat, Which leave in mind, for meagre thoughts, no room. A poem she calls "Living" begpeaks the same sincere love of nature. LIVING Hoary headed peaks ablaze with glory, And winter's keen caress upon each cheek; The rhythmic, crispy sound of crunching snowflakes That white and glistening lie beneath our feet, 458 RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE The pearly sails of graceful, speeding cloudships That hold a glad regatta in the sky, The green-black firs aglint with frosty fringes That gleam like diamond-drops and you and I Filled with a bouyant, new found joy of living, And after eventide, an azure night Bright with the starry lamps that shine in heaven, And the deep, white silence from a moonlit sky, Oh! This is living, living, living! And you, thank God, are. You and I am I. One of Grace Ingles Front's outstanding characteristics is her love of children. In her poem "Answered" she discovers much of the wonder and glory of God's handiwork in the face of a little child. ANSWERED I longed to penetrate the depths of space, To see beyond the blue of sapphire skies, To look upon the glory of God's face, To view and learn of mighty mysteries. Nor cup of disappointment did I quaff; One day my yearning arms held close a babe, And in its eyes, from its sweet, gurgling laugh, I saw and learned those things my soul had craved. Her love for children is again revealed in the poem, WHEN THE WIND SANG ITS BABE TO SLEEP (First published in "The Young Woman's Journal") The wind sang its babes to sleep last night, With a sweet, low croon, with a sweet, low croon, Rocking them high in a tree near by, Tucked into beds of apple bloom. The stars came blinking out from the blue, And the moon peeped from over the hill, And for each wee hand in its trundle bed, There was left on the window sill, A bundle held by a sheath of light, That the tiny moonbeams had spun From their own gleams into wondrous dreams, For a gift to each little one. While the moon sang its babes to sleep last night. With a sweet, low croon, with a sweet, low croon. Rocking them high in a tree near by, Tucked into beds of apple bloom. Can you see from the blue, starshine beckon to you, And moonbeams to guide your wee feet, From the playtime and noise of your romping and toys, To the quiet of Milky Way Street? Ah! Then harken, oh, hark 'tween the dusk and the dark, 'Till the lullaby song seals your eyes, And soon you will be far, far out on the sea That leads you where Dreamy Land lies. It is not an uncommon thing for poets to feel as Tennyson felt, that words "half reveal and half conceal the thoughts within." The poem "Unuttered Songs" are in line with this idea. UNUTTERED SONGS Those songs the vice cannot find notes to utter, Do they not fall back into heart of man, Like unshed tears that are too great to pass The conduit of the outward being through? Shall they not echo and reecho in the soul, Until this sphere of limitation's past? And then in music they have made their own, Break forth in a magnificent at last? Methinks the songs that yet remain unuttered, Awaiting for fortuity to voice, Are those to which but higher mind can hearken, So fraught are they with words and music choice. No one can read a sketch of Grace Ingles Frost's life and not be impressed by her versality. The art instinct is so much a part of her whole being that it has found expression in needlework, painting, music, and in poetry. She is indeed one of very exceptional gifts. All of her poems have in them a deeply religious strain. "My Mother's Ring," published in the May issue of the Magazine, carries with it a deep-seated faith in the immortality of the soul. We quote the last stanza: 460 RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE "Oh! Since she has awakened Within the Better Land, Can it be she has longed to feel This circlet on her hand? Or does she wear another, The counterpart of this, Yet of a rarer beauty, There is in her home of bliss? This much, I know+-my Mother's ring (Worn on my hand today). Seems to keep her near me, Though she has passed away; And well I know 'twill keep my feet From treading devious ways; For Mother's ring is shining With a gleam from her life's rays. Devoted to children.: GUIDE LESSONS FOR OCTOBER 461 LESSSON IV Social Service (Fourth Week in October) THE CHILD-STUDY COURSE How THE CHILD LEARNS TO Express HIMSELF IN LANGUAGE, Music, Etc. (Based on Chapter VII: The Child: His Nature and His Needs.) The reader will recall that in the six preceding lessons we have been considering the various phases of child nature and attempting to separate the "wheat from the chaff" in regard to child psychology. It will be recalled, specifically, that we discussed the more important inborn tendencies in childhood and their need for proper guidance by the parent. Then we consider the child's active nature and the need for wise direction of these energies rather than their suppression. Later we consider the child's moral and social development, noting the way in which the growing child learns to live successfully in a world of other persons. In the present chapter—the last in Part Il—we are to consider a somewhat different aspect of child nature. We are to think about the ways in which the normal child learns to express his ideas, his attitudes, and his emotions. Our expert this time is another national authority on the subject, Dr. E. A. Kirkpatrick, psychologist at the Massachusetts State Normal School, Fitchburg. A. The Laws of Learning in General. (Pages 132-139) Before taking up language and some of the other arts of expression, the author treats the reader to a rather lengthy discussion of the laws of learning in general (This section, pp. 132-139, by the way, can be omitted without much loss by those who do not care for such a bit of theoretical psychology. ) Memory, learning and motor skill, as the author points out by his numerous examples, are possible only because stimuli and responses, ideas and processes, become definitely connected. I. €., associated with one another in the brain. Habits, good or bad, helpful, harmless or harmful, are developed by the mere process of strengthening the associations (or bonds) between these elements; i. E., by repetition under favorable conditions. It would seem appropriate here to call attention to another law of learning too often neglected in this age of speed; viz., in all forms of motor skill, accuracy should be striven for before speed. Specifically, in-the child's learning to speak, to write, to cipher, to draw, to play the piano, etc., certain standards of 462 RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE accuracy should be insisted upon by the parents before speed is stressed. Such an emphasis by parents and teachers would do much to improve the low quality of handwriting, spelling, arithmetic, etc., common among American children. Questions 1, From your own experience, illustrate the laws of association referred to on page 132. 2. Why is it "very important that children should be given some means of seeing their own improvement in whatever they are learning?" How might a parent do this in the case of a child learning to speak, to play the piano, etc.? B. Learning Language. (Pages 140-148) Language behavior is extremely complicated. Learning a language constitutes the child's first great task. It challenges and measures not only his mental powers but the guidance skill of his parents and teachers. The most important phases of language behavior and the order in which they develop in the child-are: talking, reading, and writing. Because of the fact that speech disorders are so common (surveys show that 8 or 9 out of every 1,000 school children stutter, for example), it has been thought well to introduce a few pertinent quotations from two reliable authorities on the subject —Blanton and Blanton, Child Guidance (Century Co., 1927), pp. 105-110* "Speech disorders may be classified from the descriptive standpoint as follows: (1) delayed speech, (2) oral inactivities, (3) letter-sound substitution, and (4) stuttering, which includes stammering. "Delayed speech. The normal child begins to use voluntary speech constantly when he is about fifteen months old. If it is delayed a year beyond this time, he should be examined by a physician who is familiar with nervous diseases. The five common causes for delayed speech are: (a) lack of mental development, (b) lack of necessity for speech (e. G., where the child has too much 'done for him), (c) continued illness with extreme malnutrition during infancy, (d) unhealthy emotional attitudes and (e) deafness. "Oral Inactivities. Oral inactivities consist of a slurring or indistinctness of speech, which may be due to some organic disease of the speech organs, to some emotional conflict, or to some difficulty in the learning process. *For a more complete discussion of this subject see Blanton and Blanton, Speech Training for Children (Century Co.). GUIDE LESSONS FOR OCTOBER 463 "Letter-sound substitution and omission. This is usually called lalling or lisping, and is a substitution of one sound for another, such as th for s, w for r, tsh for tr, and ¢ for k. * * The majority (of such cases) are caused by emotional conflicts. Many of them are due to a retention of infantile phonetic habits, and many of them are due to a retention of infantile emotional habits. The treatment consists of two parts: (a) emotional re-education, and (b) phonetic re-education. Yr ae "Stuttering, which includes stammering. Stuttering, under which we include stammering, may be described as a break in the rhythm of speech due to a blocking or inhibiting of the muscle co-ordinations. It must not be thought of as a disease, but: as a symptom of any of a number of underlying conditions. "We do not find any explanation of the cause of stuttering through examination of the bodily organs. Of course, such conditions as malnutrition, diseased tonsils, carious teeth, and nasal obstructions, may cause an increase in the natural irritability of the nervous system, but these conditions are not the cause of stuttering. A "A search of the 'emotional life of stuttering children always reveals some of these defects: timidity, strong feelings of inferiority, an over-dependence on the parents, and feeling of inadequacy. In some cases we notice a marked rigidity towards life, an unwillingness to change food and sleep habits, an over suggestibility, a chronic fear of meeting certain groups of people or situations, or a marked sensitiveness. Ee a ee "The treatment of stuttering fails under three headings: (a) physical hygiene, ((b) mental hygiene, by which we mean emotional re-education, and (c) relaxation and training in muscle co-ordination. "(a) The laws of physical hygiene are well known to parents, so we shall not dwell on this phase of the subject. "(b) In mental hygiene the fundamental thing is the changing of the general. Emotional reactions and the correcting of faulty attitudes which give rise to tension. The child must be trained to work successfully rather. Than to day-dream, and to get along well with other children. Some outlet must be found for his fundamental social and biological tendencies and the necessity for winning some success. "(c) Parents should absolutely ignore the child's speech defect as such. They should not ask him to repeat sentences, and should not seem distressed or irritated when he becomes blocked or inhibited. Even slight changes of expression on the face are noticed by the stuttering child. - "The use of phonetics or of vocal exercises, such as in- 464 RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE flection, change of pitch, breathing, etc., is to be avoided. There is no difficulty in the child's speech mechanism. The difficulty is primarily psychological. Talking is to be encouraged, as are all. Situations of a social nature, because through them the child is really being trained to meet life." Since writing is an important form of expression, it seems important to call attention to certain dangers incident to its mastery: by the child. About ninety-five per cent of all human beings are born with a greater capacity for skill with the right hand than with the left. Of the remaining five percent, some are neutral (or ambidextrous), some are slightly left-handed, while others are extremely left-handed. Since handwriting is difficult for lefthanded children, many parents and teachers insist (sometimes unwisely) upon the left-handed child using his right hand. For example, left-handed children who at the outset start with their left hands and are later made to change to their right hands not infrequently develop stuttering, the reason being that since writing is a form of speech, and since the respective areas of control in the brain become definitely associated, any change of handedness for writing purposes naturally upsets this association with the results indicated. In every case of left-handedness, parents should decide at the outset, with the help of ithe teacher, which hand the child shall use for writing. If the child is neutral or only slightly left-handed it is generally safe to insist on the right hand. If the child is extremely left-handed, he should be allowed to use his left hand for writing. In no case should a child be made to change hands for writing, once the habit gets under way.* Questions 1. Observe the language behavior of your own children or those accessible to your observation. What laws of learning and language expression can you see illustrated? Do you know children or adults in your community with speech defects similar to those discussed above? Do such children get the special care and attention they need in school? If not, ask your Superintendent or Board or Education why it cannot be supplied.: 3. What are the new methods of teaching reading? How do they differ from the old? (If you do not know, consult any. Competent primary-grade teacher in your community.) 4, What is the policy in your local schools regarding lefthanded children and their hand-writing? If you are concerned and in doubt about it, talk to the principal or the teacher. — *For further discussion of this subject see Beely, A. L., Aw Experimental Study of Left-handedness, University of Chicago Press, 1918. GOT A DATE TONIGHT? It's great—to have a date, with the right girl or the right man. VOL. XV SEPTEMBER, 1928 NO. 9
SAMUEL By Joshua Reynolds.
THE Relief Society Magazine
VOL. XV SEPTEMBER, 1928 No. 9
What is Prayer?
By Orson F. Whitney
"Prayer is the soul's sincere desire, Unuttered or expressed; The motion of a hidden fire That trembles in the breast."
With my question so well answered, I might now close the discussion, were it not that I wish to present some further reflections along this line of thought. So I continue:
What is prayer? It is not mere lip service—a drawing near to the Lord with the mouth, while the heart is far from Him. There are two ways of offering prayer—orally, or with the voice, and secretly, or in thought, without speech. Both methods are used in addressing petitions to Deity. But neither of them is acceptable, nor of any virtue whatever, unless accompanied by "the soul's sincere desire."
John Stevens McGroarty, the genial, philosophical, broadminded editor of "The Synagogue"—a Sunday supplement of the Los Angeles Times—says, in a recent issue of that paper, something about fasting and prayer that is well worth reading. Along with it, he pays a high compliment to the "Mormon" people. Thus:
"Under the rafters of our far-flung Synagogue, as everybody knows, sit all sorts of conditions of men. People of all nations and of all creeds. The rafters of the Synagogue stretch over all the continents, the Seven Seas and all the oceans.
"Wherefore, it is no news to state that among those who sit in the Synagogue are many people who from their religious creed are known as Mormons. All the Mormons who sit in the Synagogue are also members of the Congregation of the Faithful, because they say their prayers every night and every morning. Every Mormon does that.
"And we are very happy to feel that we have many friends
468 RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE
among the Mormons. We have often made it known that we have a great admiration and even an affection for them. There is so much about them that is admirable, so much that is exemplary.
"Just lately, however, we found out something about them that we had not known before. And it is something worth broadcasting in the Synagogue this blessed Sabbath morning. The thing we found out about the Mormons—and which we had not known before, is that on the first Sunday of each month of the year they fast from food. Good, pious Mormons deny themselves in this way once a month.
"Now, there are many other denominations of the Christian religion that observe fasts as well as feasts. We could name Christians of many varying creeds who deny themselves food on certain days of the year. Which is a good thing for their souls as well as for their bodies. But the Mormons put their fasts to practical uses. What they do when the day of fasting is over is to conscientiously estimate what the food on the fast day, had they eaten it, would have cost. And each Mormon then sends the amount of this estimate to his Church organization. And the Church organization uses the money it thus receives for the support of its poor.
"The result of all this is that the Mormons have no poor houses. Nor does it seem that they have any jails.
"This is what we would call practical religion. It is not religion that is the mere breath of one's nostrils. It is self-denial for the sake of others. It is going hungry that another may be fed. Wanting, that someone else may not be in need."
Then comes this hit at religious bigotry:
"It may be that someone sitting in the Synagogue this blessed Sabbath morning will say that this good report of the Mormon people should not be spoken. Unfortunately, there are many who profess to be Christians, yet who are really not Christians at all. And it is they who will say that it is only their own religion—the creed to which they belong—that should be praised and emulated.
"It was once well said by some wise man, that Christianity should not be condemned, for the reason that it has never been tried.
"And there is a lot in that saying. It really does not seem that the teachings of the Wanderer of Galilee have yet come to full flower.
"The way that we, ourself, feel about it is, that a good deed should be praised and held up for emulation, no matter by whom the deed is done. Even though it be a pagan, a heathen or a heretic who does a good deed, then shall he be praised in the Synagogue. And he shall have a high seat therein."
WHAT IS PRAYER? 469
In another luminous flash from his gifted pen, Mr. McGroarty thus presents his concept of prayer:
"Charles V, who was sometime King of Spain, and at the same time king of a lot of other countries that had been willed to him by his aunts and uncles, once said that Spanish is the language with which to speak with God.
"El idioma para hablar con Dios." He spoke truly enough no doubt. And what he said may still be true, although the scholars tell us that Spanish has changed a good deal, as all other languages have done, since the time of Charles V. It is said that it is a pretty far cry from the castellano of Cervantes, Quevedo and Lope de Vega to the Spanish of Pio Baroja, Pareda and other modern writers.
"Mexico particularly has put a lot of strange stuff in the mother tongue. The Peruvians have gingered it up with the 'quichua' of the Incas. In the Argentine even American slang has its wedge in. And so it goes.
"But, getting back to what the great king said, we may add that God may be spoken with without the use of language altogether.
"It is with our thoughts and not with words that we speak with God. Words are merely the voices of thoughts. And a thought can be a thought and yet be voiceless.
"To speak with God is not a matter of language. It is a thing for the soul to do. And He is always listening."
Mark you, our big-hearted friend, the Rabbi of the "Synagogue," does not say that words should not be used in "speaking with God." That they are "merely the voices of thoughts," is manifestly true. But there are times when thought needs a voice, and so the Lord has commanded his people to "pray vocally and in secret." To speak with God, therefore, is, as we view it, a matter of language, as well as of thought.
Joseph Smith, the first "Mormon" of the nineteenth century, but not of all time—for "Mormonism's" far-flung "Synagogue" stretches its rafters over the prayerful and honest in all ages—when he beheld in vision the Father and the Son, he spoke with them orally at first, and after the power of evil had paralyzed his tongue, went on praying in secret; and it was his secret prayer that shook the heavens, turned the key in the lock, and opened upon the world the glories of a new Gospel dispensation. Satan could and did tie the boy's tongue, depriving him temporarily of the power of speech; but could not fetter his free thought, could not prevent him from sincerely desiring the wisdom of which he stood in need and for which he had sought the Lord in the Sacred Grove that memorable spring morning. Thus the supreme value of secret prayer is strikingly evidenced in Joseph Smith's first and greatest spiritual manifestation.
Let us not, however, underrate oral prayer. When we kneel
470 RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE
in the family circle, or lower our heads and hearts in public worship, the one who voices the prayer is the mouthpiece of all present. That being the case, it is highly necessary that all should hear him and know what he is praying for, so that there can be an intelligent "Amen" from the congregation. But no public prayer can take the place of the silent petition with which, in the solitude of the bed-chamber or other retired spot, we pour out the desires of our hearts to our all-seeing, all-knowing Heavenly Father. Even upon the street, in the office, or in the school room, we ought to have a prayer in our hearts for protection against accident, for the success of any business venture in which we may be interested, or for the mastery of some difficult problem that is taxing our patience and strength. God hears such prayers, as well as those that are uttered openly—if the one who prays does so with full purpose of heart. "And He is always listening."
Prayer is a means of uplift. Every prayerful thought, word or deed is a step toward heaven. Our Lord and Savior was not thinking of his own honor and glory when he commanded his disciples to pray unceasingly and always in his name. He had in mind their welfare—mentally, morally, spiritually, and in every way. Prayer is an expression of faith, and it is by faith—which impels to obedience—that we obtain all our blessings. Eternal justice, without which God would cease to be God, demands a return for what Providence bestows. We must do something to merit what is done for us. The balance is thus preserved, the equilibrium of right maintained. We cannot get something for nothing. We pay for our blessings, in part, by asking for them. But if we do not ask, and still receive, we owe for them. Then why not pray, thus discharging in advance and as far as possible, the obligation?
In closing let me record an incident of my own experience that powerfully impressed upon me the meaning and purpose of prayer. It happened forty-eight years ago, in far-off Liverpool, where I was then laboring as assistant editor of the Millennial Star, the organ of the European Mission. In an overworked, run-down condition, I was endeavoring to produce an editorial article which would be read, upon completion, to the editor in chief—the Mission President—and if he approved it, given to the printer. But I could make no headway, and wore out the whole day in a vain struggle to write something worth reading. Finally I threw down my pen in disgust and burst into tears of vexation. At that moment the Good Spirit whispered: "Why don't you pray?" I turned almost impatiently in the direction from which the
WHAT IS PRAYER? 471
whisper had seemed to come, and said: "I do pray." I was then praying five times a day—first, a secret morning prayer upon arising; second, a prayer at breakfast time with the rest of the household; third, in secret at noon-day; fourth, again with the family at supper time; and finally at my bedside before retiring. "Pray now," said the Spirit, "and ask for what you want." I saw the point at once. It was a special not a general prayer that was needed. I knelt and sobbed out a few simple words. I did not pray for the return of the Ten Tribes, nor for the building of the New Jerusalem. I said, "Father, in the name of Jesus Christ help me to write this article." That was all, and it was enough. I arose from my knees, seated myself, and began to write. My mind was now as clear as crystal, and my pen fairly flew over the paper. Everything I wanted came as fast as I could set it down, and every thought and word was in proper place. In a remarkably short time the article was completed to my entire satisfaction. I read it to the chief; he approved it without the change of a syllable; and it was published.
This taught me a lesson, or rather, it reminded me of one that I had temporarily forgotten and needed to have emphasized. Prayer is not a matter of mere words—not a string of hackneyed, stereotyped phrases. "Prayer is the soul's sincere desire." And it was of such a prayer and no other, that the Lord said: "Ask, and ye shall receive."
None can pray well but he that lives well. Pray and work. Pray devoutly and hammer stoutly. Pray without ceasing. Prayer knocks 'til the door opens. Prayer of faith shall save the sick. He prayeth well who loveth well. What an asylum has a soul in prayer.
REBECCA NEIBAUR NIBLEY
Rebecca Neibaur Nibley
By Amy Brown Lyman
Another noble pioneer woman has passed to her reward in the person of Mrs. Rebecca Neibaur Nibley, wife of President Charles W. Nibley and for many years a member of the General Board of Relief Society. Mrs. Nibley's earthly life closed in the early dawn of July 2nd at the family residence in Salt Lake City, where she was surrounded by her husband and children, who ministered to her during her last illness. The funeral services were held in the Salt Lake Assembly Hall, where hundreds of relatives and friends gathered to pay tribute to her, and where her remains lay in a lovely bluish-gray metallic casket surrounded by masses of beautiful flowers. Bishop James A. Giles of the 14th Ward was in charge; the speakers were President Heber J. Grant, President Anthony W. Ivins and Bishop Nicholas G. Smith of the 17th Ward. Among the musical numbers rendered was the hymn "Come, Thou Glorious Day of Promise," the words of which were composed by Mrs. Nibley's gifted and brilliant father, Alexander Neibaur. Interment was in the family lot in Logan City cemetery; the grave was dedicated by President Joseph R. Shepherd of the Logan Temple.
In the passing of Rebecca N. Nibley, her husband and children have lost a loving, affectionate, and devoted wife and mother; her friends, a true and valiant friend; the Church, a staunch supporter and faithful member. During her long life it had been no trial for her to make personal sacrifices for her loved ones. It had been no task for her to minister to their daily needs, nurse them in times of illness and help to lighten their burdens. She suffered when they suffered, and rejoiced in their joys. She was an ideal wife and helpmeet, devoted and loyal to her husband and his interests, and their success in life was due in no small measure to her ability, devotion, and industry. She worked shoulder to shoulder with him, and her practical wisdom and vision were a great asset in the partnership. She was energetic and ambitious, frugal and thrifty, ingenuous and resourceful. When left to support herself and two children while her husband performed a mission in England, her resources consisted of a small piece of hay land, a cow, a pig, and some chickens. She took care of her garden, raised chickens, and sold milk, butter, and eggs; and, by good management, succeeded in maintaining her family without assistance. During this time $300 in cash was paid her on a debt. This money she carefully kept intact for a new start for her husband on his return.
474 RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE
It takes a great soul to be a true friend. There was no wavering in the friendship of this noble woman. She was dependable, loyal, tender and true; and once a friend, a friend always. No new influence in her life and no period of separation from her friends affected her feelings or devotion to them, and she was never happier than when extending hospitality in her beautiful and well kept home. Fortunate were those who tasted of this rare friendship.
Rebecca N. Nibley was a true and faithful Latter-day Saint, her life conforming to the standards and practices of the Church. She had a strong testimony of the divinity of the Gospel and implicit faith in its teachings. Her life was dominated by these religious ideals, for which she was more than willing to sacrifice. It was an inspiration to hear her testimony, which was forceful and positive, gained through years of varied and remarkable experiences. Her faith in the Gospel, her loyalty to the Church and its leaders, were unbounded. She did not criticize the leaders nor the policies of the Church. In any crisis she was fearless and without any wavering or doubt. Her view point was invariably positive and orthodox.
Mrs. Nibley was a strong character—brave and fearless. She was a woman of honor and principle, a doer of right. She had no place in her life for pretense, for the hypocrite, or for the person who shirked responsibilities and obligations. She could not tolerate the idea of a person claiming to be honest and straightforward who was not so in daily practice. She loved honesty and frankness and was a typical example of the honest, straightforward, frank, outspoken individual. At the same time she was sympathetic and forgiving to those who repented of their errors, always ready to forgive, encourage them and aid them to rise again.
Born in the early days of struggle and privation in Utah and learning early the right values in life, Mrs. Nibley was an outstanding example of the resourceful Western pioneer woman—a constructive contributor to her family, her neighbor, and her community. One would go far to find a more energetic worker, a more frugal and thrifty housewife, a more helpful neighbor, or a wiser community builder. Even in her later years of prosperity she was never idle, never wasteful: and, while she was generous to a fault, she conserved and practiced economies which many in her situation would have scorned. It was her delight to save, conserve, create, and to help others to do the same.
A real philanthropist was Sister Nibley. Her own early struggle and handicaps made her sympathetic and tender toward those who were lacking in opportunity, under-privileged, or unfortunate. Generous to all in need, she was eager to help better the conditions of anyone in distress. Her good, practical advice she backed up with substantial assistance. She was a liberal contributor to her Church and to her beloved Relief Society and was known as a benefactress to hundreds of missionaries and others.
REBECCA NEIBAUR NIBLEY 475
Mrs. Nibley was born March 30, 1851, in Salt Lake City, Utah, three years after her parents reached Utah, and four years after the arrival of the Pioneers in 1847. Her parents were Alexander Neibaur and Ellen Breakel. Brother Neibaur was the first Jewish convert to the Church and was a close personal friend of the Prophet Joseph Smith. They had accepted the Gospel in Preston, England, in 1837, and immigrated to Nauvoo, leaving the latter place at the time of the general exodus of the Saints. The family underwent all the privations and hardships incident to the travels of the Saints and to early pioneer life in Utah.
On March 30, 1869, Rebecca Neibaur was married to Charles W. Nibley in the old Endowment House in Salt Lake City. She was just 18, a beautiful, wholesome, vivacious, quick-witted girl, while her husband was a handsome young Scotchman, who had already shown an interest in the business affairs of the northern part of the state and who was later to play an important part in the economic and financial development of the West. For a few years the young couple lived in Brigham City, later moving to Logan. In 1893 the family moved to Baker City, Oregon, where they remained ten years, returning to Utah in 1903 and establishing a home in Salt Lake City. Ten children were born to Brother and Sister Nibley—four girls and six boys, seven of whom survive her.
Wherever Mrs. Nibley lived she was active in Church work, holding positions in the various auxiliary organizations. She was especially devoted to the Relief Society, joining the organization at the age of sixteen. During the 61 years of her membership she served as visiting teacher, ward counselor, ward president, and General Board member. In 1909 she was called to the General Board of Relief Society in which she labored faithfully until honorably released in 1921, traveling extensively throughout the Church in the interest of the organization. She was a valuable and valued member, her business ability and good judgment being a great asset to the Board. She served in many capacities—as chairman of the Relief Society Home for Women and Girls, as a member of the Magazine Finance Committee, and a member of the Hospital Committee which supervised the purchase of all the linens for the new L. D. S. Hospital, which were contributed by the Board. She was also a member of the Friendship Circle, a group of close friends, who were most appreciative of her interesting personality and many fine qualities.
Mrs. Nibley traveled extensively both in this country and in Europe and was a keen and intelligent observer of all she encountered. She was fond of reading, was a lively conversationalist, a keen humorist, and withal a most interesting and stimulating companion and associate.

VOL. XV - SEPTEMBER, 1928 - No. 9
EDITORIAL
Members of General Board Take Advantage of Summer Courses
There is a growing tendency among American women to be alert to opportunities that will make for greater efficiency in any line of work in which they may be interested. Alertness among the members of the General Board has found expression this summer in various ways. Mrs. Julia A. F. Lund, director of adult education at the Civic Center of Salt Lake City, has been attending the summer session of the University of California, where she has been interested in two courses of study; one is the history and development of adult education in Europe and America, given by Dr. Overstreet; the other, a course in child welfare under the direction of Dr. Stoltz. Adult education is coming to be most significant. Without doubt, there is with many people, a realization of the fact that it "availeth little" for the few to have knowledge unless that knowledge may be shared by the masses. For this reason leaders plan and devise work in which all may be partakers; so that, when the command is issued to advance, all are ready to proceed.
Other members of the General Board who have been taking
EDITORIAL 477
advantage of an opportunity to study, are Mrs. Emma Empey, Mrs. Julia A. Child, Mrs. Ethel R. Smith, and Mrs. Rosannah C. Irvine. They have been attending a rather early morning class in Social Hygiene at the University of Utah, conducted by Dr. Edith Hale Swift. This course is given under the direction of educational measures of the American Social Hygiene Association. Whoever is keeping up with the march of civilization must realize that a change is taking place in the attitude of the public towards sex hygiene. Many feel that the old way of hushing up everything in relation to sex development and sex life is injurious; that silence on this subject tends to debase rather than ennoble and exalt a phase of life that should be squarely and nobly met without embarrassment. That there is something to learn in relation to this phase of our existence is perhaps rather obvious. Just what it would be well to impart to others, and just what modification of past practice should be entered into, is what constitutes the problem. In the meantime it is gratifying to know we are advancing.
Infant Mortality Decreasing
It is a matter of deep gratification to be able to record that infant mortality continues to decrease in the United States. This news comes to us from the American Child Health Association through the medium of its annual report. In 1918 there were one hundred deaths per thousand, or the relatively high rate of ten percent. In 1926 the death rate had been reduced to 73.7 per thousand. Last year, 1927, it had fallen to 64.4 deaths for each one thousand births. This is certainly a notable decrease in less than a decade. If the good work continues, it will be a very short time before infant mortality among children of the United States will be cut in two. To reduce infant mortality is one of the aims of all Relief Society workers and other organizations that have gone forward in the name of the Shepherd-Towner bill. It is one of the aims of all organizations having in mind the welfare of children.
Woman to Represent British Universities Districts
We learn that a woman who is a lecturer in the University of Liverpool is to stand for the British Parliament for a number of university districts. This is a very high compliment to the intellectual attainment of the woman in question as well as a compliment to all women in the civilized world who are connected with university faculties.
Sarah Elizabeth Carmichael Williamson
By Ellen L. Jakeman
Utah's Pioneer Poetess, better known to her contemporaries as Lizzie Carmichael, was born of humble parents at Setauket, Long Island, in 1838. Her parents joined the Mormon Church, and she was brought across the plains at an early age to Salt Lake Valley, where her parents resided to the day of their death. Books were scarce and educational opportunities of the crudest, but she absorbed a wonderful amount of learning, when her opportunities are considered, and her gleanings grew and multiplied like planted grain. She had access to that masterpiece of all the ages, the Bible. Of a pure and religious turn of mind, the influence of this great work is manifest in and through all her poems. Never has a poet combined nobler purity of thought and language with greater variety of subjects. Her study of the Bible gave to her writings its own direct and
SARAH E. CARMICHAEL WILLIAMSON 479
graphic language, while it deepened the natural religious fervor of her mind. Her spirit was tense-strung and fine, her nerves a-tremble with emotion, and her blood strained very thin through too many sieves of the same tissue. There is no doubt in the minds of the pioneers who knew her, or of a later generation who are so fortunate as to be familiar with her poems, especially writers and lovers of literature, that had she retained the brilliant mind of her youth, she would have inevitably taken her place as a queen in the highest ranks of poetry and song. As it was, her career, brief and bright, spread her fame far beyond the confines of Utah. Her artistic temperament found little in the necessarily rude frontier life to feed the hunger of her soul for the beautiful, though in castellated rocks and deep-cut canyons of our rugged Wasatch hills she saw all the grandeur that are theirs.
MOON-RISE ON THE WASATCH
The stars seemed far, yet darkness was not deep; Like baby eyes, the rays yet strove with sleep; The giant hills stood in the distance proud, On each white brow a dusty fold of cloud; Some coldly gray, some of an amber hue, Some with dark purple fading into blue; And one that blushed with faint crimson jet— A sunset memory, tinged with cloud regret.
Close to my feet the soft leaf shadows stirred; I listened vainly, for they moved unheard— Trembled unconsciously; the languid air Crept to the rose's lip and perished there.
It was an hour of such repose as steals Into the heart when it most deeply feels; When feeling covers every shred of speech With one emotion language cannot reach.
And Nature held her breath and waited there, An awed enthusiast at the shrine of prayer; Like a pale devotee, whose reverent lips Stifle the breath that burns her finger-tips.
The crimson-tinted cloud paled, with a start, As though new hope chased memory from her heart; A gleam of whiteness stirred the vapor pale, As beauty's finger moved a bridal veil; A fleecy mass, wide-fringed with silver light, Drooped on the summit of the proudest height; Then, floating northward, swept in folds of grace From the white beauty of the moon's meek face.
480 RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE
How still, how pure, that chastened lustre bowed Its glance of radiance from its veil of cloud! How meek the loveliness, how kind the power, Whose arm of purity embraced the hour! How beautiful the misty robe that trailed O'er bloom that brightened, over stars that paled— Though its white fold caught in a dusky cave, Or swept its fingers o'er a gleaming wave, Piled on the sward a moss of woven gems, Or dragged to tatters through the forest stems.
A wave of beauty, only too complete, Surged o'er my head and widened at my feet; The skies seemed bowing with their wealth of light, Yet earth sprang heavenward, 'twas so more than bright: My heart found no expression—sought for none; Why analyze the bliss it fed upon? All its sensations blended into one— Solemn, yet shadowless—most glad, yet deep; I could not smile, yet had no wish to weep.
My restless thoughts seemed into one compressed; The eloquence of all things seemed possessed, Yet no expression: narrowed to my breast; My soul seemed to expand, my heart to melt, Blending with all that could be reached or felt. I had no wish unsatisfied, because My mind's volition felt superior laws. It seemed a ripple moved upon a tide, Whose heaving billows bade me onward glide; A breath born upward by a tempest weight— A trifling circumstance controlled by fate; Something of little worth when moved apart— One trembling fiber in Creation's heart.
Because so few spoke her language or comprehended her flights of intense feeling, she grew up shy and reticent. She wrote many small poems in her early years that were never offered for publication, but were treasured in manuscript by those whom she loved, and may be irretrievably lost. When, in her seventeenth year, she began publishing, few could believe that the poems she offered to the local newspapers were from her own pen. They were of such a lofty nature, direct and clear-cut in thought, trailing blossoms of speech and crusted with jeweled words. No one will ever know just what was said when she presented that bit of dramatic perfection: "Lucretia Borgia's Feast" to a local editor. He rejected it on the score of disbelief in her authorship. Humiliated and shamed, the poor child went to a friend, a high Church official and wept out her story. His
SARAH E. CARMICHAEL WILLIAMSON 481
gifted mind and soul could meet hers on its own ground. He told her that he knew the work was hers, and that her rare genius was the gift of God; that while it might bring her much suffering, it would be a source of exquisite delight; that she should never lose it so long as she used it worthily. He went with her to the man who had rejected it, vouched for her and her work, and the poem was published as it appears here. When Edward W. Tullidge wished to publish a sketch of this wonderful woman in the "Western Galaxy,' no copy of "Lucretia Borgia's Feast" could be found; as it was not included in the twenty-six poems that make the sum total of a slender little volume printed by her friends, but was supplied by the author of this article from memory. LUCRETIA BORGIA'S FEAST Beauty had gathered, to grace the board Where the ruby wave of the wine was poured; There were clasps of brilliants and bands of bloom, Warmth, and lustre, and rich perfume; Passionate music, low-toned and sweet, Or abrupt and quick as a heart's thrilled beat, Or proudly sad, as the voice of song When the chord it touches is deep and strong. The gay, the gifted, the bright, the fair, Of Italy's nobles had gathered there; But the comeliest form of that baccahanal band. With the darkest eye, and the snowiest hand, Who stood by the lord of the highest rank And tasted the wine ere the noble drank, Was the delicate page, whose lip's proud curve Seemed scarcely fitted to sue or serve. Wine! Wine! It flowed in a crimson stream Through the crystal cups, till its ruby gleam Shadowed a blush on the soft white hand That raised the glass from the marble stand. The hours speed on, and the music's tone Speaks of the bright and the gay alone— When sudden it ceases. A voice is heard As clear as the notes of a forest bird; The form of the singer they do not see, And it seemed to them like a melody Living and speaking without control, A beating heart and a breathing soul. "Curse not thy Mother!" "Fiend! Woman! Hush! The name of 'Mother' should make thee blush. I have no mother, and thou no son— Seeker for vengeance, thy work is done!" Then he sank to his knees, and she strove to speak, But he spurned her back with an effort weak. She clasped his form—it was icy mold That shrank from her when his heart was cold. That Sarah Elizabeth Carmichael touched and vibrated all the chords of the human heart, is found in the fact that first and last almost every one of her major poems have been denominated her masterpiece; that they were for all time—human— in that they still speak to the deepest emotions of those who read them, and with a clear, familiar voice. The question of authorship settled, poem after poem followed in quick succession through her seventeenth and eighteenth years. Her patriotic poems were widely copied in the Eastern press, often without credit. Notable among them is: "President Lincoln's Funeral,' too long for reproduction here, as also: "Ashes to Ashes." Here are two poems that touched a nation's heart at the close of the Civil War, and are just as searching and applicable to our own time and recent World War. DEAD Weep for the dead! Not those who gave The dust that fills a patriot's grave; Not for the true arm still and cold; Not for the breast that the grasses fold; Not for the bright form under the mold; Not for the heart that bled. But weep, O weep for the coward vain! Dead, for it had no pulse to drain; Dead, for it could not feel a pain; Dead to the core—dead! Dead as a soulless sentence spoke; Dead as a useless promise broke; Dead as a sightless eye awoke: Dead! SARAH E, CARMICHAEL WILLIAMSON Weep for the dead! Not those who went Home by the hand of a foeman sent; Not for the smile we see no more; Not those interred on an alien shore; Not for the life whose pain is o'er; Not for the spirit fled. Yet weep for the bosom numb and still! Dead, for it felt not patriot thrill; Dead for it had no life to spill; Dead to the core—dead! Dead as the hate of an idiot's glance; Dead as the steel of a broken lance; Dead as a last neglected chance; Dead! Weep for the dead. Not those who claim Immortal life on the scroll of fame; Not for the soul who feared but shame; Not for the life that reached its aim, Not for the step that marked in flame Print of a hero's tread. Weep for the dead that breathe and speak! Dead with a life-bloom on the cheek; Dead, for they have no aim to seek; Dead to the core—dead!
