I hold thee near To lips that trembling sigh, And gem thee once more with a tear— Good-bye, right arm—good-bye! Thus the fame of "Our Lizzie," as she was affectionately called, spread abroad. She received the homage of all scholarly people and of many who did not flatter themselves with such a title; but it is as well established as such a thing can be after this lapse of time, that she was never paid anything for her articles. Even her "Stolen Sunbeam" considered one of the finest poetical conceits ever penned, was a gratuitous contribution to literature. This poem was selected by Bryant for his great collection, "A Library of Poetry and Song." He took the liberty of retitling it "The Origin of Gold," but here we give it the author's original naming. THE STOLEN SUNBEAM There's a light that burns with a quenchless glow, In the wide, deep caverns of earth below; Like the fire that lives on the Parsee's shrine In the amber torch of the lighted mine. Burning forever, steadily bright; Proud and passionless, still and fair; Burning forever without a glare; Burning forever so still and deep; A quenchless flame in a dreamless sleep; And time's broad ocean may roll its waves While space hath room for the centuries' graves, It hath no billows to dim the shine Of the wizard faggot that lights the mine. Beware! Beware of a starless beam! The nightmare spell of a miser's dream! Emotionless ever, its subtle art Tugs at the strings of the world's strong heart. The stars of the earth at its bidding stoop; Awed by its menace, life roses droop; And the fairest blossoms that earth can twine, Fade near the taper that lights the mine. SARAH E, CARMICHAEL WILLIAMSON 487 ' The Fallen looked on the world, and sneered: "I guess," he muttered, "why God is feared; For eyes of mortals are fain to shun The midnight heaven that hath no sun. I will stand on the heights of the hills and wait Where the day goes down at the western gate, And, reaching up to its crown, will tear From its plumes of glory the brightest there; With the stolen ray I will light the sod, And turn the eyes of the world from God." He stood on the height when the sun went down— He tore one plume from the day's bright crown. The proud orb stooped till he touched its brow. And the marks of that touch are on it now, And the flush of its anger forevermore Burns red when it passes the western door! The severed plume, above him whirled, In flames of torture around him curled, And he dashed it down from the snowy height In broken masses of quivering light. Ah! More than terrible was the shock Where the burning splinters struck wave and rock; The green earth shuddered, and shrank, and paled, The waves sprang up and the mountains quailed: Look on the hills—let the scars they bear Measure the pain of that hour's despair. The Fallen watched while the whirlwind fanned The pulsing splinters that plowed the sand; Sullen he watched, while the hissing waves Bore them away to the ocean caves; Sullen he watched, while the shining rills Throbbed through the hearts of the rocky hills; Loudly he laughed: "Is the world not mine? Proudly the links of its chain shall shine; Lighted with gems shall its dungeons be— But the pride of its beauty shall kneel to me!" That splintered light in the earth grew cold, And the diction of mortals hath called it "Gold." Many of her contemporaneous admirers consider Lake Tahoe her finest production. When this was written not a great many people had seen that beautiful sheet of water—a lake crystal clear, situated on the summit of the Sierra-Nevada Mountains, which separate Nevada from California. Tourist travel has given its beauty to thousands, who have felt the charm they could not express. It is one of the spots she visited as a bride. LAKE TAHOE Lake Tahoe, sweetest lake of lakes! Carmichael presents such a bewildering array of beautiful poems, and such soul-searching, emotional themes that it is indeed hard to choose among them. "Allie's Baby Prayer" has been printed, anonymously printed, many times; but it shall see the light now in its proper setting, and be duly credited to its gifted author. ALLIE'S PRAYER We listened—'twas a little foot, Placed lightly on the stairs; "What is it, darling? "I forgot— Forgot to say my prayers." The mother took the little hand, And kissed the meek, low brow. And watched the tiny, white-robed form, Close down beside her brow. Ah! Pride-chilled hearts were beating near, World-darkened eyes were there; But every head was bowed to hear Sweet Allie's baby prayer. And I have knelt where holy words By earnest lips were spoke; Have felt the burning gush of thought Their eloquence awoke; SARAH E, CARMICHAEL WILLIAMSON 489 Have listened when the pleader's voice Sank quivering to a sigh, And I have bowed my head and thought *Twere beautiful to die; But never have I seen the awe Whose robes were folded there— Whose stainless fingers wove the threads Of Allie's baby prayer. It went away—that little foot— As lightly as it came, The sweet lips spoke a low "Good night," And syllabled a name; The light reflected from her hair Shone through the open door; We caught a glimpse of that white robe The angel pleader wore. Then eye met eye, and souls bowed down In deep contrition there; Stern hearts were melted by the breath Of Allie's baby prayer. Among those who read her poetry and appreciated her glorious gift was Dr. J. M. Williamson, a young army surgeon stationed at Camp Douglas, under Gen. P. E. Connor. Mr. Williamson's culture and refinement, chivalry and deference, was a balm to her soul. Their romantic courtship in 1866 was followed by marriage in 1867. Because of her terrible inheritance, the marriage was the cause of much apprehension and adverse criticism by the best of friends of both parties; but it is claimed that their union was ideal for the brief period that was theirs before the crowning disaster took them. Because she was so universally beloved by all who have had occasion to write of her and her sublime genius, not one has given a name to the surety of the doom that hung over the golden singer of the Wasatch. They are to be commended for their delicacy, but now after nearly a hundred years, and not one soul left to be wounded by it, the truth may do good and no harm. Sarah Elizabeth Carmichael was the victim of an unwise marriage. The daughter of double cousins; one of a family of seven, she and one sister were all who survived infancy. The sister, like those who died, was below normal in intelligence. Her parents were disturbed by the genius of their gifted daughter, and absolutely unable to comprehend her. Much of her writing is tinged with sadness, that will be better understood when the reader. Knows of the dark cloud that hovered over this sinless young girl; and be able to appreciate the passages that seem personal and prophetic. 490 RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE That Dr. Williamson was disgusted by the calm appropriation of her labors without remuneration is a reasonable conjecture. He it was who wished her to do herself justice in literature with a price, induced her to begin the writing of a book, historical and biographical in character, of the Mormon people and prominent members. 'There is no hint that it was to be sensational or antagonistic in character; but she did not even complete the first chapter, becoming insane about a year after her marriage. Under this terrible calamity Dr. 'Williamson proved himself one of the honorable of the earth. He gave up all ambition for himself to care for this woman whom he so tenderly loved; exhausting all the scientific lore obtainable to bring back reason to the fragile body it had inhabited. The delicate thing that had fled seemed ever hovering near. Indeed one writer hints that there were lucid intervals and during those hours she wrote other poems, but if so there is no vestige of proof. Broken hearted, Dr. Williamson died in 1882, leaving his considerable property to his wife, with J. R. Walker and Boyd Park as sole executives. The frail young wife was scarcely conscious of her loss. Her parents were dead, Mr. Walker died, her sister died, and Boyd Park waxed old. Nowhere in the documents I have been permitted to examine is it spoken of, but at some time she was committed to the asylum at Provo, with special privileges and personal attendants. I saw her there in the nineties, a slender figure in a close. Fitting black dress, with a white crepe. Shawl over her shoulders, at Sabbath services—with them, but not of them. When the end was near, she was brought to her old home on State Street, Salt Lake City, to die, and was buried in the old Salt Lake Cemetery. Seven years after her death, Alfred Lambourne published an article in the Deseret News, from which we make a brief excerpt: In an apparently unvisited grave in one of the upper avenues of our City Cemetery, a grave overrun with rank grasses and weeds, and over which the head-board—the name upon it hardly decipherable and already sloping to its fall—lies the body of Sarah Elizabeth Carmichael Williamson. That neglected spot, however, is hallowed in being the resting place of a sweet woman and a true poet. We yield reluctant justice to the dead, And light the torch of fame when life hath fled. There can be but one thought of solace for the wasted life of the loved, envied, and admired child of genius—there is a plan of progress and achievement beyond this world which will provide recognition for all she has missed or suffered in the clouded pathways of the world. (Copyright applied for; all rights reserved) The Russell Sisters By Annie Wells Cannon Among the contributors to the Woman's Exponent were two young women of rather unusual literary attainments, Sarah E. And Isabel M. Russell. Schooled only in the crude educational institutions of pioneer days, these two sisters evidenced a keen sense of culture and possessed the rare gift of poetry. They came of a family widely known for its artistic and literary achievements. And, true to their heritage, did not conceal the light within. In files of old magazines and newspapers one often finds many gems of thought published over some fanciful name; the author is never known because either from modesty or fear of criticism the real name is concealed. Like many such, these two young women when they began to write for publication concealed their identity by the use of the pseudonyms "Hope" and "Millicent" respectively. Both have now passed to the great beyond, Sarah some years since, and Isabel, lovingly known as Aunt Belle, only a few months ago. It was the fact of her passing that called to mind some incidents in the lives of these two sisters and the family of which they were a part that prompted the writing of this article., The experiences of the Russell family are much the same as those of other pioneers who braved the long journey from comfortable eastern homes to the desert valleys of the West. The marks of toil, privation and hardship only intensified their faith and fidelity, and never caused them to lose the sweet refinement and spirit of that earlier part of their life when their surroundings were more comfortable. The Russells were among the first families in Canada to give a refuge and a sympathetic hearing to Parley P. Pratt when he went there with his message of the restoration of the gospel. Isaac Russell and his wife Mary Walton Russell made great sacrifices for their faith. They owned a large tract of land and other property. And had many comforts and advantages, all of which they laid on the altar to help build up the Church; and when they journeyed valley of the Great Salt Lake, they came as other poor emigrants, sharing' all with the Saints. Isaac Russell was one of the elders who in company with Brigham Young and Heber C. Kimball introduced the gospel in Great Britain. When he left his wife in Ohio to go on that mission he sold his flute to buy her some meal and left her there almost penniless. The*mother, Mary Walton, had wealthy relations in England who, when she became a widow and was left with six children, offered her and her children a 492 RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE home and support. But to accept this offer meant to renounce her faith, and this she could not consider. So she struggled on, finally reaching the valley in the goodly company of her chosen people. The courage of the mother is exemplified in the daughters, who not only shared with her all the trials of pioneer life but ventured even farther into unknown lands and helped to colonize in Arizona and Mexico. Here these loyal women toiled to make homes and give happiness to many in the communities where they lived, exercising all their talents and energies as only helpful, unselfish women can under the stress of straitened circumstances. Isabel became the wife of B. F. Johnson with whom she went to Arizona in 1882. Here she taught music and worked at the tailoring trade until 1889, when the family moved to old Mexico locating at Colonia Juarez. Later they moved to the picturesque valley of Chuichupe in the tops of the Sierra Madre Mountains. Here Aunt Belle served as the president of the Relief Society until the exodus of the Latter-day Saints from the Mexican colonies. All that the family had struggled and worked for over twenty years was left behind; and she never quite ceased to regret the home in the mountains, for she was an ardent lover of nature and here, with her little family, though shut out from the luxuries and attractions of the world, she had created an atmosphere of harmonious living and contentment. Isabel Johnson wrote her first poem while at their home in Missouri when only a girl of sixteen, and throughout the long years she found solace in expressions of poetic thought. One tribute among many paid this good woman at the time of her funeral most beautifully expresses her worth. A friend and neighbor said: "As far back as I can remember Mesa, I remember Aunt Belle coming from the ranch to give music lessons. I remember the cheerfulness with which she went about her work. She was a very deep student and philosopher and improved upon the qualities she had. She was so enriched in soul that everything in nature appealed to her. She took advantage of all things that would add to her knowledge and spirituality. She raised a noble family and was always valiant in pioneer life. With implicit faith and trust in her God that was beautiful, she went on her journey unflinchingly, until at the ripe age of 85 she went back to her God, pure, sweet, and virtuous; and her influence will never die with those who knew her." Two poems culled from the columns of the Woman's Exponent—''Patchwork" by "Hope" (Sarah E. Russell) and 'Three Evening Shadows" by "Millicent" (Isabel Russell Johnson)—are here given. THE RUSSELL SISTERS 493 Patchwork Tis not genteel, they tell me now, To make a patchwork quilt, 'Tis sign of poverty they vow And poverty is guilt In worldly eyes—well let it be, But you and I should clearer see, I think it is a branch of art That forms a good, important part In home economy and joy, And pleasant hours without alloy, May thus be spent in social chat, While fingers fly this way and that Forming designs of light and shade Until a perfect piece is made; And then the quilting, oh how nice! To meet in friendship and rejoice, When work is done the circle spreads Mingling the white and golden heads Of father, mother, sister, brother— (If not your own, why then, some other) In pleasant play or may-be dance While jest and song the hours enhance; From many a patchwork quilt I trace Some well known name, some dear, dear face, And from one star will spring anew, Some time of love and friendship true, Our parents loved these simple joys, Shall we forget—their girls and boys, And in the new scenes scorn the old? Ah no! There lies the purest gold, And is not life all patchwork too Our thoughts and actions, false or true, Pieces that go to form the whole Great plan divine the Gods control; Then be our station high or low Lets cut and fit the pieces so That perfect shape and colors blend, Praying that One above to lend His wisdom where our own would fail Courage when our weak hearts would quail, Then may our life work be replete In all things perfect and complete. —Hope (Sarah E. Russell). 494 RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE Three Evening Shadows Creeping down, creeping down, Shadows with a golden crown; Shadows in the valley lying Gold upon the mountains dying; Creeping down, gently down Shadows gray with golden crown. 'Tis thus the shades of evening fall In youth; when Trustfulness o'er all A tender beauty throws; Holding without its trembling veil Dark hours that droop with sorrow pale With tears, vain hopes and woes. Falling down, falling down, Shadows with a sable crown; Shadows on the heart and valley, Clouds on the hills, in blackness rally, Falling down, dimly down, Shadows deep, with death dark crown. Thus when the veil is rent apart, And troubles gather round the heart, And the pale hours press on; Each with its weary weight of pain Till doubt and anguish cloud the brain, - And trust and peace are gone. Falling down, gently down, Shadows with a snowy crown Trembling hands are weaving now, Flowers pale for painless brow Shadows 'round death's solemn bier Rest to the heart so troubled here. Thus when the ills of life. Are past, And that far shore is won at last, Where shadows never fall; And many are the eyes that weep, Watching across life's stormy deep, Waiting the angel's call. —Millicent (Isabel R. Johnson). Notes from the Field By Amy Brown Lyman SOCIAL SERVICE ITEMS Educational Work. Mrs. Julia A. F. Lund, a member of the General Board of Relief Society, and director of Adult Education at the Civic Center in Salt Lake City, attended Summer School at the University of California. Mrs. Lund took up two courses of study, both of which will be most helpful to her in her future work. One course was the history and development of Adult Education in Europe and America, given by Dr. Overstreet, who is considered the best authority on this subject; the other was a course in Child Welfare, a group discussion course conducted by Dr. Stoltz, head of Child Welfare work in the state of California. Social Hygiene at the University of Utah. A course in Social Hygiene was given at the University of Utah Summer School by Dr. Edith Hale Swift, under direction of Educational Measures of the American Social Hygiene Association. Many down-town people availed themselves of this excellent opportunity of getting expert instructions on this important subject. The General Board was represented in this course by Mrs. Emma A. Empey, Mrs. Julia A. Child, Mrs. Ethel R. Smith, and Mrs. Rosannah C, Irvine. The class met daily from 8 to 9 o'clock during the Summer session. Public Health Nursing. Because of the increasing demand for public health nurses, interest in this profession is growing. Many of the school districts are placing public health nurses in the schools, and a number of counties are making plans to install county nurses. Only hospital graduate nurses are eligible for public health nurse training, and the time required for the course is from 8 to 10 months in universities offering this work. The General Board of Relief Society has recently received six applications for loans from the Clarissa S. Williams Public Health Nurse Loan Fund. The young women applying are graduate nurses who are planning to enter training, either at the University of California or the University of Washington. Within the last year and a half the Relief Society was instrumental in the training of two public health nurses, Miss Irene Harris and Miss Florence West of Ogden, both of whom secured positions immediately after being graduated—Miss West in Box Elder County and Miss Harris in. Sanpete County. By action of the Utah Tuberculosis Association, Miss West was recently appointed director of the Christ- 496 RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE mas Seal Health Camp in Big Cottonwood Canyon from July 9 to September 1, and on September 1 she will take up work for the year with the Nebo school district. Miss Harris has been engaged for next year by the Provo City Schools. Children's Vacations. Through the generosity of the General Board, of some local business men in Salt Lake City, and of a number of Relief Society stake boards, a number of malnourished and under-privileged children of Salt Lake City, will be given the opportunity of spending a few weeks in the country. Plans for the work are being supervised by the Family Welfare Department of the General Board. In addition to this excellent project, the Welfare Department is fortunate in having the further opportunity of sending ten children to the Child's camp conducted by the Utah Tuberculosis Association in Big Cottonwood Canyon from July 9 to September 1. The children selected for this camp will be those most in need of the care which the camp offers. Social Service Institutes. At the request of the Relief Society officers of these stakes, three social service institutes have recently been held in outlying stakes—Maricopa, St. Joseph, and Idaho Falls. The institutes in each covered a period of one week, and were conducted by social workers from the staff of the Relief Society Family Welfare Department at the headquarters office. Miss Genevieve Thornton, case supervisor of the department, conducted the institute at Maricopa; Mrs. Annie D. Palmer, assistant supervisor, conducted that at St. Joseph; and Mrs. Amy W. Evans of the welfare staff, and member of the General Board, was in charge at Idaho Falls. In asking for social service institutes the purpose of these stake Relief Societies is their desire to improve in every possible way their social work with families needing this service. The aim is also to secure as much uniformity in these matters as possible throughout the stakes. To insure this result, it was felt that a general understanding of the basic principles of social work is necessary, together with a knowledge of the most constructive procedure in the treatment of families under care. The ultimate aim is always to bring the family back, as soon as possible, to a normal way of living, and to avoid purely palliative relief, which weakens rather than strengthens a person or a family. The reading assigned and the lessons outlined were designed to meet these aims. In order to get all the service needed for a family, an understanding of, and cooperation with, the other helpful agencies and organizations of the community was provided for; and a study was made of the community, county, and state agencies for health, relief, and other service. NOTES FROM THE FIELD 497 The general plan of the institutes was as follows: No meetings were held in the morning. This time was left free for private consultation with the field worker on any matter or problem upon which any president felt she would like special advice. In one stake the regular meetings were held both afternoons and evenings, while in another a longer session was held in the afternoon. In addition to Relief Society president, social service aids, stake presidents, and board members, Bishops were invited; and all showed a good spirit of cooperation with the presidents, though their attendance was more casual. The women were asked to do some preparation work in the way of reading. The Art of Helping People Out of Trouble, by Karl de Schweinitz, Executive Secretary of the Philadelphia Charities, was used as a text. This book sets out, in a very readable way, the major principles of social work, with interesting illustrations and cases in point. A number of these books were forwarded to the stake about two weeks prior to the date of the institute, and the women were asked to read the book and to be prepared to discuss the principles laid down and the instances cited. The preparation was good, and the women showed much interest in this required reading. In addition to assigned readings, each person in the class was given a mimeographed "outline covering the main points of the lessons given by the social worker conducting the class. These outlines were kept by the women for future reference. On all phases of the work the discussion in the classes was lively, and the efforts and ability of the women taking part were very gratifying to the class leaders. The Maricopa institute was held at Mesa, Arizona. In the sessions devoted to a study of community, county, and stake resources, persons representing the Juvenile Court, the County, Child Welfare Board, the State Rehabilitation work and the compulsory attendance work of the schools were invited into the meetings, to discuss proper use of these agencies by the communities of the stake. The proper utilization by the various communities, of free medical sources, was also gone into after consultation by the worker in charge with the county physician, the Phoenix Free Clinic, and some cooperative private physicians. The matter of division between wards and the Phoenix Family Service Society of responsibility for families applying to the Phoenix wards for assistance, was taken up after consultation with the executive secretary of that Society. It was found that cooperation of the Phoenix wards was desirable here in order to avoid having families under the supervision of both the ward and the Family Service Society at the same time. Closer cooperation was welcomed by both the Relief Society women and the Family Service Society of that city. In Mesa good cooperation exists between the Church and the " 498 RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE Community Fund. The amount of money available from this source is not large, but the ward Relief Societies, by holding a bazaar, cooperate in securing it. The fund is in charge of a volunteer, Mr. Charles Flynn, who has served in this capacity for seven years, and who cooperates freely with ward presidents and Bishops of Mesa in the matter of recommending assistance from this fund when it is felt that this is needed for a family. Mrs. Emma Rollins, stake social worker, gives Mr. Flynn a good deal of assistance in investigating cases coming to the attention of the fund. In St. Joseph stake, where wards are separated from the stake house by many miles, a. Three-hour session was held every afternoon for six days. Interest in lesson work was sustained throughout all the sessions and outside reading was reported daily. The State Child Welfare Board was represented at most of the meetings., Several Bishops and one member of the High Council attended. On the Sunday following the institute, the social worker, through the courtesy of President Payne, was privileged to address various departments of the Union meeting. In the department of Stake Presidency and Bishopric, the general plan of the work and need of close cooperation were stressed. In Idaho Falls stake, all the social agencies in the community were invited to participate in the institute. There were in attendance, beside Relief Society ward presidencies, social service aids and stake board members, ward bishops and counselors, high councilmen, stake Priesthood presidency, representatives of the local Child Welfare League, secretary of the Red Cross, public health nurse, county physician, county commissioner, Judge of the Juvenile Court, probation officer, and superintendent of the L. D. S. Hospital. Aside from the regular course, many community problems were discussed, and by all, a better understanding obtained of the work of each agency. In all three stakes, time was taken at the last session held for discussion of cooperation between Bishops and ward Relief Society presidents. Appreciation for the good support they feel they have from each other was expressed by both Relief Society presidents and the Bishops present. A few presidents expressed the feeling that they need a more definite time for regular consultation with their Bishops, while others reported a regular conference period with them. Mrs. Mamie Clark, president of Maricopa stake Relief Society, Mrs. Ethel D. Payne, president at St. Joseph stake, and Mrs. Clara Brunt, president at Idaho Falls, deserve much credit, as do all those who took part in contributing to the effectiveness in these institutes. Two of the Salt Lake stakes, Liberty and Grant, have recently been active in studying social work. During the past season, NOTES FROM THE FIELD 499 official workers from each of these stakes have met weekly at the headquarters of the Relief Society for ten weeks, covering a good, deal of work in the principles of social service and in the treatment of families needing care. The use of community resources was gone into in detail, this problem being always more complicated in the larger cities. The women showed decided interest and eagerness to do their work in the most helpful way. In these Salt Lake City stakes, instruction in social service work and the discussion of the problems has a double value: (1) The Family Welfare Department assists all stakes of the city in doing active case-work with the families needing attention and thus comes into close touch with the ward presidents, social service aids and the Bishops. (2) This co-operation results also in the acquisition of knowledge necessary to care for families constructively and in the bringing about of a better acquaintance and a greater personal appreciation of efforts of ward workers and the Family Welfare Department workers. These two stakes met separately to study principles of social work and the best methods of caring, for families in need. In each case the Relief Society stake presidency, the ward presidents, and the ward social service aids took active part. At the end of the tenth week these groups decided to continue meeting once a month as a case conference to discuss difficult problems of timely interest. These meetings have continued through the spring, and are just now adjourning for the summer. Both the stake women and the general office feel that these meetings have been very beneficial to all and that they are of definite value in securing greater uniformity of work and in bringing about a better understanding of the work generally. The two stake Relief Society presidents, Mrs. Winifred B. Daynes of 'Grant stake, and Mrs. Hazel Greenwood of Liberty stake, attended the sessions and took active part in the discussions. At the close of the Liberty stake classes a joint meeting with the stake presidents, Bishops, and Relief Society workers of the stake, was held at the home of Mrs. Hazel Greenwood, Relief Society president. In this meeting, cooperation between Bishops and Relief Society presidents and between the wards and the Family Welfare Department of the general office was discussed, the purpose being to secure as close a working relationship as possible between these groups. In general a very good spirit of helpfulness and willingness to be of mutual service to each other was shown. The need of close cooperation in all parts of social service work was clearly indicated. The diligent efforts of stake presidents and their assistants in helping to carry out arrangements for these classes and institutes has been very much appreciated by the General Board and by the. Welfare Department staff. Guide Lessons for November LESSON I Theology and Testimony (First Week in November) "PEARL OF GREAT PRICE" "Again the Kingdom of Heaven is like unto a merchant man seeking goodly pearls, who when he had found one pearl of great price sold all that he had and bought it." Matthew 13:45-46. Evidently the purpose of this parable was to awaken interest in the value of seeking the Kingdom of Heaven, and the purpose of this lesson is to awaken interest in a Book which clearly points the way to the Kingdom of Heaven. "The Name and Place as Scripture." By reference to the title page of the volume it will be seen that it is "A Selection from the Revelations, Translations, and Narratives of Joseph Smith, first Prophet, Seer, and Revelator to the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints." This Seer was a "Choice Seer,' and this book contains choice selections from his inspired productions. As an illuminator of truth it is a pearl; as concentrated knowledge, it is of great value. It can be read aloud clearly, in less time than it takes to attend a theatre; and yet there are paragraphs that may hold the attention for hours. It deals with the revelations of God to man, from the answering of a simple question as to which church was right, up to an explanation of the universe. The "Pearl of Great Price" is one of the four standard works of the Church, and this position recommends it as a field of profitable study and a safe source of reference. The Contents. The Book contains the visions of Moses under the title of "The Book of Moses;" "The Book of Abraham;" and "Writings of Joseph Smith." The consistent division of the contents into chapters and verses and the extensive marginal references make the Book in its present form an up-to-date student's text, lacking only a concordance to bring its study on a level of convenience equal to that of its three companion volumes of Scripture. GUIDE LESSONS FOR NOVEMBER 501 THE BOOK OF MOSES. General View. This part of the "Pearl of Great Price" is a revelation to Joseph the Seer of what the Lord showed to Moses concerning the creation and the history of man down to the flood. In many respects the revelation is a reproduction of the events as recorded in the Bible; but new light is thrown on, and we get the story with more simplicity and directness. In fact it may be said that many new and precious truths have been restored in this latter-day presentation of the Visions of Moses. Some Doctrines and Principles Illuminated. 1. The Personality of Man's Spirit. In his visions Moses saw God with his Spiritual eyes, that is, with the eyes of his spirit; he heard the voice of the Lord with the spiritual ears, and conversed with the Deity with a spiritual tongue. The communication between Moses and the Lord was, so far as the man was concerned, a spiritual communion. It was a case in which the Spirit of a mortal was called into the presence of God with His glory not all veiled, and there in the spirit was shown and told things to be remembered and revealed by the mortal man: a circumstance in proof of the possibility of a mortal remembrance of what is learned through the spirit only. 2. The Personality of the Evil One. No one can consistently believe in the Visions of Moses and deny the personality of Satan. From a human testimony point of view, the evidence of Satan's individuality out-weighs the testimony concerning the: Personality of God. Moses viewed Satan with his natural or physical eyes, and God with his spiritual eyes. The contest between Lucifer and Moses points to four facts: First. That the Devil is a person. Second. That the Evil One can be seen by the natural eye. Third. That man can resist the Evil One. Fourth. That the Evil (One can be banished by man in the name of Jesus Christ. The Attitude of Moses is a Key to Conquest in the Field of Temptation. He felt and knew that he was a son of God and therefore standing upon the apex of self-respect; he then weighed the tempter with a demand for light. "Where is thy Glory? Is a good question to have in readiness for the tempter. 3. The Fatherhood of God. The Lord made plain his parental relationship to man by saying 502 RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE to Moses: "Thou art my son," and frequently addressing him as "Moses, My Son." Moses was born a son of God in the premortal state; but as a man he became a son of God through baptism. 6:66-68. The tenderness of God as a parent was shown by something stronger than words when the Almighty wept at the contemplation of what the wayward of his family would suffer. Wrong-doing has a double terror when seen as something that hurts not only man but his Maker also. 7:28-31. 4. Obedience the First Law of Heaven. The first commandments after the fall required, not blind obedience, but the obedience of confidence. The upward climb of the race began with the obedience of confidence, the obedience of faith. It leads heavenward. 5:5-7, Entrance into the Kingdom of Heaven is impossible without the child attitude, the willing attitude, the trusting attitude, and the attitude of perfect confidence. "Except ye be converted and become as little children, ye shall not enter into the Kingdom of Heaven." Matt. 18:3. So spake the Savior of mankind, and then he added: ''Whosoever, therefore, shall humble himself as this little child is greatest in the Kingdom of Heaven." He knew that the foundation of greatness is humility, the only safeguard against humiliation. He was and is the way and the life. How often he taught the lesson of the obedience of confidence by declaring that his will was subordinated to the will of his Father. 5. The Earth Affected by the Conduct of Those Who Live On It. The Earth is heard to mourn: "Woe, woe is me, the mother of men. I am pained. I am weary because of the wickedness of my children. When shall I rest and be cleaned from the filthiness which is gone out of me? When will my Creator sanctify me that I may rest, and righteousness for a season abide upon my face?" 7 48. We know that a part of the earth may be affected by our conduct all the time. No one can say that his hand steals or that his tongue lies. The body is a tabernacle in which we live, it is an instrument which we use. Why is the cheek flushed with hope and paled by fear? There is more than sentiment in dedicating a home and in praying for the earth to yield. It is not inconsistent to believe that the things which respond to the mind may have some of the universal mind in them. "The wind and wave obey His will' may be as philosophical as it is poetic. GUIDE LESSONS FOR NOVEMBER 503 In the light of our study it would seem that the goodness of man gives happiness to His Creator and to the earth on which he lives; also that the evil which man does and says is a source of sorrow to his God and to the earth itself. The cliff that sends back the song may not be conscious of the reaction; but it is more or less affected, and it is better fitted to echo harmony than it was before. So the violin is made sweeter-toned every time it is made to produce good music. A part of the earth was so sanctified by the righteousness of the people that it became heaven—the abode of God—that part of the Earth did not mourn, 7:16-24. LESSON III Literature (Third Week in November)
ELSIE CHAMBERLAIN CARROLL
One of the most prolific writers among the women of the Church is Mrs. Elsie Chamberlain Carroll. For many years her poems and stories have appeared in practically all of the Church magazines, so that her writings are known wherever these magazines have had circulation. She was born and reared in southern Utah, the daughter of Thomas and Elinor Hoyt Chamberlain, who, in the early history of the Church, were called with their parents to settle the Muddy Mission, and who later helped in the establishment of the United Order at Orderville. When the order broke up, Thomas Chamberlain was given his share of the common property which he had helped to accumulate. It consisted of a tract of farming land about three miles north of Glendale, known as Lake Farm because of the beautiful and natural lake which nestles at the foothills on its northern border. Here Elsie spent her childhood, living a healthy, normal life with her many brothers and sisters, the Chamberlain family being one of the largest in the Church. Elsie's mother, a natural nurse, took care of members of the family when they were ill, and of other persons in the community who required her services. At her death, which occurred in 1927, the devotion of the family is revealed through a tribute written by Mrs. Carroll entitled Our Mother
No matter what the trials may be That cross our future way; No matter what the pains we bear; How dark may seem this day; We know our lives have been more blest, Than lives of many others, For God had few such gifts to give As she, our queen of mothers.
For us she suffered to give life; For us she toiled and smiled; Her willing hands for us ne'er tired; Our pains she shared, beguiled. Though shadows often crossed her years— Such burdens as crush others— Her courage ever pierced the dark: A symbol for all mothers.
506 RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE
Her lips spoke only words of good— Of wisdom, peace, and cheer; Her soul breathed only faith That banished doubts and fear. So patient! Gentle!—every thought A loving care for others: A life of service, sacrifice— A model for all mothers.
Now God has called her home to those She loved, who went before. Our world is desolate and dark; Gone is our joy of yore. But gone can never be the light She gave to us and others. Oh, may we worthy be of her— Our Mother, Queen of Mothers!
When Elsie was fourteen, she moved with her mother's family from the farm in Long Valley to Kanab, where her father had purchased a mercantile business. This place became her home until her marriage. She attended the grade school and had two years of high school in Kanab, Then she went to the Brigham Young University, where she finished high school. From that institution she has taken also the bachelor's and the master's degree. In 1907 Miss Chamberlain married Charles Hardy Carroll. The romance leading to this marriage started in the childhood days when they sat across the aisle from each other in the little log school house in Long Valley. Among Mrs. Carroll's most treasured keep-sakes are a number of valentines yellowed with age; these she received from her childhood lover on consecutive valentine days from the time she was eight years of age for several years thereafter. The message on the first one reads:
Elsie, my darling, your eyes are so bright They hold every bit of my heart with their light. And if, when we are older, my bride you will be, I am sure we'll nothing but happiness see,
Another bears this inscription:
Charming little Elsie, you've stole my heart away, But I'll try to live without it if you'll send me yours, for pay. And in the years that's coming, how happy I will be If you'll frown on all the other boys and save your smiles for me.
These childhood sentiments seemed to be prophetic of a happiness that did come with a later marriage and that lasted unbroken for seventeen years until Dr. Carroll was called home in 1925. Dr. C. H. Carroll was a graduate of the Brigham Young University and a teacher at that institution both before and after he
GUIDE LESSONS FOR NOVEMBER 507
received his medical degree. He did his medical work at Cornell and Chicago Universities, taking out his degree from Rush Medical College. At the time of his death he was medical director at the Brigham Young University and a popular physician and surgeon of Provo City. During the time that Dr. Carroll was studying, Mrs. Carroll did English work at both Cornell and the University of Chicago. Mrs. Carroll is the mother of two children, Helen and Charles. Helen was married during the month of June to Donald Lloyd. A matter of more than usual interest to the family attaches to the June Commencement of 1928; for at that time Mrs. Carroll took her master's degree, her daughter Helen took her bachelor's degree, and her son Charles was graduated from high school. Since childhood Mrs. Carroll has been interested in writing. When she graduated from the eighth grade, she wrote a little two-act dramatization, which her class presented; and while at the B. Y. U., working on the staff of the White and Blue. She has won several prizes. Her first story in any of the Church magazines was a prize story written the year after she was married and published in the Young Woman's Journal. She wrote the story and decided not to submit it. Her husband found it in the waste-basket, copied it, and sent it without her knowledge to the office. The story won the prize of twenty-five dollars. Most of Mrs. Carroll's efforts have been in the field of the short story, but she has written considerable poetry. The Relief Society Magazine has published a number of her best poems. "A Mood," expressing a longing for the loveliness and inspiration of Western nature, was written while she was in Chicago when her husband was taking his medical course.
A Mood
I'm sick of the dirt and the strife and the din; Of political scandals; of rumors of sin; Of the pomp of the rich; the wail of the poor; Of the incessant grafting; the glitter and lure; I'm sick of the faces I see without end— The faces of strangers with never a friend; I'm sick of the tumult of passions that play Such a havoc with peace in my heart every day: The passions of hate, of envy and pity— O, I'm sick of it all, I'm sick of the city!
And I long for a glimpse of a mountain so high That its snow-covered summit is kissed by the sky. For the glint of a sunbeam, unsullied by smoke; For the calm of a silence that's never been broke;
508 RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE
For the flash of a bird's wing high over green trees; For the smell of the woods wafted by on cool breeze; For the deep sense of homage that bids me to kneel And pour out my love for all that I feel. Oh, I long once again to sip from those fountains Of courage and faith to be found in the mountains.
The World War aroused emotion of varying sorts in the hearts of mankind. This narrative poem was written during the war:
The Vision
The moon peeped in a window where A white-faced mother kneeled in prayer, And wrapped her in its shimmering light, And heard the prayer she breathed that night.
"O God, it is so hard to pray With battles raging every day; My boy's across the blood-tinged sea! E'en prayer brings little peace to me.
"They tell me he is big and tall. Ah me! He was so pink and small When I went near the gates of death To give to him of life's sweet breath.
"It seems but yesterday he slept Safe on this breast. The tears I wept Were from a heart o'erflown with joy. What pride, what love, I gave my boy!
"What happy work! I'd dream and plan The things he'd do when grown a man. Was all my love and dreaming done To make a target for a gun?
"I know my heart is hard tonight; I somehow can't shut out the sight Of bloody forms and reaching hands Across the sea in death-strewn lands.
"It is my baby over there. God, can't you take a mother's prayer And make a wall of it to shield Her baby in the battle-field?
"If not, dear Father, touch my heart And make it strong to bear its part. I would be brave and true as he, But all my strength must come from thee."
GUIDE LESSONS FOR NOVEMBER 509
The moon in pity kissed her hair And swiftly wrought a vision fair. It was the cross of Calvary. But lo! Its burden was not He
Who gave the world its joy. The martyr was a soldier-boy. A great white flag above unfurled: "Democracy for all the world!"
"Dear God," she cried, "I see the light. His is the cross of Human Right. As Christ once suffered, gladly he Now gives his life for Liberty.
"No longer is it hard to pray For now I see the breaking day When that great flag shall be unfurled And wave unstained o'er all the world.
"And if he dies—my boy—if he Can never more come back to me,— I'll humbly, proudly bear my loss— My boy's a savior on a cross!"
Mrs. Carroll has always been interested in young women and exceedingly successful in her contacts with them. During the time she was dean of girls at the Provo High School she wrote the following poem, which was read at the Girls' Day Program in that institution:
The Modern Girl
The modern girl with a fluff of hair, With a dimpling cheek and a smile, Eagerly searching the zest of life; Practicing charms to beguile; The modern girl with a don't-care shrug, With a wilful tilt to her chin, Watching the whirl of the world go by, With never a care what traditions have been; The modern girl in a flapper's guise; With brow unafraid and serene; The worry of elders, perhaps—but she Knows in her heart she's a queen.
And so as a queen her trust she'll keep— Her trust to the ages of time. She still holds it dear, in her larger sphere That womanhood spark divine.
510 RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE
The modern girl, she will carry on As the girls of the past have done. She'll meet her life as they met theirs, With a larger victory won.
A number of the most telling poems written by Mrs. Carroll are those which voice the deep loss she sustained in the untimely death of her husband. The union of Dr. And Mrs. Carroll was one of great happiness, and the separation sounded the very depths of her soul. One of the poems bearing on this event was read at the Conference last April. Another, which has been set to music by Professor William F. Hanson of the Music Department of the Brigham Young University, is called "The Void."
The Void
I cannot see your dear, dear face, I cannot hear your voice, nor feel The loving pressure of your hand. I wait in vain your footstep now, And wake with empty arms that reach In longing, and a soul that bleeds And throbs and aches through endless hours.
You must be somewhere, somewhere, dear. If only I could know that you Are still that YOU I love, That you are happy, dear; And that you know how hard I try To keep my courage strong for you Because you asked me to be brave.
If only you could stretch your hand From out the great, vast dark abyss Of doubt and mystery and fear And let me know you know and love— O then I could be brave No matter what the trials that come; O then I could be brave—but now!
The music to "The Void" may be obtained at a small cost from Professor William F. Hanson.
CLAIRE STEWART BOYER
Mrs. Claire Stewart Boyer has brought to us in her poetry a significant touch from the home, and has also written poems that reflect the birds and trees of her native environment here in the mountains. Over thirty years ago a baby girl arrived at the home of Professor and Mrs. William M. Stewart in Salt Lake City, Utah. As a boy had been desired and expected, the newcomer had to be held
GUIDE LESSONS FOR NOVEMBER 511
on approval until all members of the family had voted whether or not she should remain. Fortunately for her the ayes had it, and for a brief period life revolved about this fourth child, who was to be known as Claire. About that time the kindergarten movement was waxing strong in Utah, and at the age of four Claire rode several miles every morning on the handlebars of her sister's bicycle to attend kindergarten. Thus began her educational life, which was rich and full in its entirety. The Training School was Professor Stewart's joy and pride. Here were teachers, brought from all over the United States because of their rare understanding and abilities. And upon the growing mind of the little girl each teacher stamped a significant impression, which will remain ever as a distinct force in her life. It was Elizabeth Kimball, teacher of the fourth grade, who discovered a spark of literary talent in the child, and who sought ardently to develop it. Subscriptions to St. Nicholas, Youth's Companion, and the Juvenile Instructor, luxuries to children in those days, were secured, and an intense love of literature resulted. At home every new educational feature was installed as soon as it came out. A sand table and blackboard occupied the entire side of the library, and all the blocks and colored balls and sense developing games that were just being introduced into the schools, together with great cases of fascinating books were the most prominent furnishings of the room. Here was indeed a paradise for children in the nineties. During the summer months the Stewart family went to their ranch in Provo canyon. Here were spent the happiest days of Claire's life, for here she enjoyed communion with nature and a more intimate companionship with members of the family than was possible during the winter months. Her father was a great idealist and an intense lover of nature. The beauty of Pine Valley at dawn overwhelmed him with ecstasy. Many mornings each summer the little girl would be called from her bed, and a moment later would be standing with her hand in her father's gazing silently at this five o'clock glory. Not until many years later was she able to express those moments in poetry. "The Hill Wife" and "Dawn" are recollections of such mornings. Her only attempt at the time to express the beauties of nature, was the habit of walking alone up the canyon road, and trying to make up phrases that would describe what she saw and felt. But these oral creations were all lost on the wind. In high school she was again inspired by a teacher, Dr. Adam S. Bennion. Here also were established most precious friendships, one of which resulted in a close study of modern poetry, which resulted in the composition of quite a number of poems molded upon the forms of Amy Lowell and her contemporaries. At the University of Utah she won literary prizes and honors and became editor of the Pen, the literary magazine of the University. She was especially encouraged in poetry by Charles Wilbert Snow, the Eastern poet, who said in parting, "It is up to such Western-born hearts as yours to write the glory of this country. We Easterners can't. It is up to you to immortalize your meadow lark and your sea-gulls." Those words, cherished for over ten years, were instrumental in the execution of the poems "Sea Gulls" and "The Meadow Lark." Claire Stewart graduated from the University in 1916 and taught in the state high schools until 1919. In 1918 she was married in San Diego to Lieutenant D. A. Boyer of Springville, Utah. They had been college chums and co-participants in dramatics at the University under the direction of Miss Babcock. A few weeks after their marriage Mr. Boyer sailed to France and Mrs. Boyer began writing poetry in earnest, from two to five poems a week, completing in the year a volume of love and war poems. After the war Mrs. Boyer wrote only occasionally, when inspired. Some of her best poems of this period have appeared in the Relief Society Magazine. They are "Her Things," "Child," "Aunt Em" and "If Ye Have Faith." Other poems have been published in New York and Boston magazines. Recently the muse has been with her constantly, and this year she has written more and better poems than ever before. She has compiled a volume entitled "Wife O' the West," which she hopes to publish soon. They are most of them home poems and observations on life. Several of these follow. Mrs. Boyer is the mother of two sons, and of a daughter who died in 1924. She has some of the idealism of her father, whose advice always was, "If you cannot realize the ideal, idealize the real." Her mother's ambition and persistency in the accomplishment of the tasks she sets herself, have always been an inspiration and an incentive to her to go on in the face of many discouragements. There are two great urges within her which cry for development—the desire to write and the desire to teach, inherited from her mother and her father respectively. She has private students in both reading and writing. At present she is very proud of a class in "Writing for Magazines" the members of which are publishing stories, poems, and plays in prominent magazines. From Mrs. Boyer's biographical sketch we learn that "The Hill Wife" and "Dawn" were inspired by her early morning walks with her father. "The Hill Wife" was published in the Relief Society Magazine some time ago. "Dawn" we shall include in this lesson:
Dawn
The jeweled fingers of the Lady Dawn Caught a cloud-cluster idling in the air, And turned it to a wreath of primroses To nestle in the glory of her hair;
GUIDE LESSONS FOR NOVEMBER 513
Then flinging scarfs of gossamer aside, Like rainbow colors free to dance and play, She bared one shoulder from the coverlets And pursed her coral lips to kiss the day.
As examples of her nature poems and particularly of those growing out of her native environment we include "The Meadow Lark," "My Mountains," and "Buds."
The Meadow Lark
A melody pierces the perfect dawn! I bound from my bed like a startled faun, And dash the dripping sleep from my eyes— A meadow lark carries my heart to the skies As I look up.
Like waters that leap in the laughing sun And sing with the splendor of day begun, The throbbing tones challenge and lure and beseech, Telling me God is within my reach If I look up.
My Mountains
You don your gowns for me: your blue March gown With snow-spun lace revelers; your April frock Of timid green and gems of amethyst, Which puts a sacred hush upon my love.
Then summer comes and you are mad with joy, You pose before me in your gown of blooms: A robe of saffron over emerald, Three shades of laughing blue, a scarlet scarf, And you expect me to retain my heart.
Not half content with these, you mock my love In Autumn dress, a fluttering gypsy maid With chestnut skin, your lips ripe-berry stained, Your skirts long sweeps of radiating rays, Crimson and gold—chaotic harmonies.
When I would speak you suddenly grow cold, I kneel in silent worship at your feet, And when I raise my eyes I see you robed In chaste white garments for your burial.
So must each lover, over-awed by love And over-hushed by beauty, be content To watch the passing of the one he loves, And wait the coming of another Spring.
Buds
I never see a rosebud in the spring, First blush of joy to an expectant bower,
514 RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE
Without a melancholic wondering Why we pick buds not leaving them to flower.
The loveborn softness of its petals warm, Its dawn-enfolded baby coloring, It breathes again; I hold within my arm My precious rosebud of a former spring.
I know now why God takes the infant buds From out the arms of Mothers in the Spring, It is a mortal and immortal dream To pluck and hold the only perfect thing.
In the sketch, you will note that Mrs. Boyer has lost one of her children. Her poem "Boys' Day" as also "Buds" reveals much of the mother heart and interest in children that was manifest in the poem she read at the April Conference.
Boys' Day
I plucked a perfect rose bud in the spring, Symbol of one who died in infancy; I started with it toward his tiny grave Thinking how Life had made its mock of me.
For it had robbed me of my only son, And left me gaping before empty years; So I went blindly on in graying grief, Seeing the world through mists of unshed tears.
I took the bud in trembling memory, And through the streets my way I slowly made; A gruff policeman pushed me back apace, "We're roping off here for the Boys' Parade."
And then I looked around and saw the lads, Bright eager boys the age my son would be; I looked into their burning eyes and lo! My own Lad's youthful soul communed with me.
One boy looked proudly up into my face And then glanced shyly at the rose I held, I swallowed hard, but stooping, slipped the bud Into the happy youngster's coat lapel.
His eyes shone and he doffed his cap to me, Embarrassed, but with grace the gesture made, The tiny grave would never miss the bud— And I stayed on to see the Boys' Parade.
Mrs. Boyer's husband was one of the men who was sent over seas. It would be strange if the World War and particularly the condition in which she found herself separated from her young husband, did not lead her to write some things in relation to the
GUIDE LESSONS FOR NOVEMBER 515
War. In addition, Mrs. Boyer has given us some of the very best Christmas poems that we have published in the magazine. We are happy, because it is characteristic of her writings, to include as her last poem in this lesson—
"Frankincense, Spices, and Myrrh"
He sat at the door of his Belgian home Re-made from the War's debris, And he thought of the Christ in the manger born And the Christ on Calvary; He thought of the nails in the Savior's hands, And his war-racked memory Saw his own blown off by a hand-grenade For the love of his own country; He thought of the eyes of the dying Christ As He uttered, "Lord Forgive," And he thought of his own burned out by the men Who had dared him to laugh and live.
Within the house lay his wife and babe— A son he had heard them say— And he sought the bed with a heart-sick soul And he knelt on the floor to pray; "Of all the joys stored up above Thou hast given the greatest to me. So God accept the life of a man Who can neither touch nor see; Let me die of joy at Thy great reward Ere my own son's pitying glance Fall upon him whose eyes and hands He gave to help save France."
They carried him out to the open door And bade him rest nor think; They brought his book and read to him, They brought him food and drink. He sat at the door of his Belgian home Like one whose mind is gone But he listened to those who moved about And his lips kept murmuring on— "Oh God let me lie where I long to lie— Neath the soil of my native land; And let him, my son, grow up to see The Peace of the World at hand."
It was Christmas eve and three great men Had met at a gay chateau, They had traveled far but their rendezvous Was not for the World to know.
516 RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE
They had knitted brows and they wore with grace The scientific mien, They carried gifts in their skillful hands, Great gifts that were quite unseen.
"We have the joy of discovery," One said: "We have the power, And if God will we shall prove to Him We need but the man and the hour."
The Belgian sat at his cabin door Long after the sun had set, And the stars were hid and the night was dark For the fog was thick and wet; But there came a light through the muggy night, And he felt its piercing ray, Some steps he heard and a human voice,— Three journeymen on their way.
A word and a thought and a prayer to Him And the Wise Men bowed them low And began the task that their hearts had dreamed And that only their minds could know.
A year and a day they worked away With a joy that none could see, As they thought of the Christ in a manger born And the Christ on Calvary. And one of them made a pair of hands, And one of them grafted eyes, The third restored his memory, For the three were skilled and wise.
And the man who had prayed That he might be laid Neath his harried country's sod, Bowed his head at the gifts that the Wise Men gave And wept before his God. And the three who had plead that they might be led To this newer Bethlehem, Gave thanks to the Lord of All the World For the star that had guided them—
It was Christmas day when they stole away, And they left a happy three: A mother, a babe in a cabin born, And a man who could touch and see. Unknown they had come, their service done To "one of the least of these"— Night of the Christ Child once again, Once more the gift of Peace.

QUESTIONS AND PROBLEMS
Elsie Chamberlain Carroll
1. Do you think it natural for one born in the peaceful vales of Utah to experience a mood such as Mrs. Carroll voices in her poem "A Mood?" If you have had experiences somewhat similar, relate them.
2. Do you recall among your friends persons whose attachment began in childhood and finally resulted in marriage?
3. Underline in Mrs. Carroll's nature poems a group of words that you think are particularly apt.
4. Select from her poems in this lesson the two that you like the best.
5. Do you hold the same opinion that Mrs. Carroll expresses in relation to the modern girl, or is your idea different? If so, why?
Claire Stewart Boyer
1. What are the two different pictures presented by the two writers in their war poems?
2. Where in her poems has Mrs. Boyer made reference to the loss of her child?
3. Do you think that giving a rose to the living was a more practical thing than carrying it to her baby's grave? Which do you think would really do the mother the most good?
4. Which poem is devoted to one of our mountain birds? Does it coincide with your experience with the bird?

LESSON IV Social Service (Fourth Week in November)
THE CHILD STUDY COURSE
Lesson 8. (a) Bridging the Gap Between Our Knowledge of Child Well-Being and Our Care of the Young, and the (b) Relation of Nutrition to Mental Development.
We now enter upon a new phase of our study of the child, his nature and his needs. Up to this point (part one of the text) we have been concerned with the fundamental principles of child nature—the laws of psychology, character development, learning, etc. From now on (part two), however, we are going to examine the principles of child-care as they are illustrated in our knowledge of such things as nutrition, mental development, mental hygiene,
518 RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE
delinquency, adolescence, care of intellectually inferior and superior children, etc. (We are making one lesson out of two chapters for the reason that Chapter VIII, Bridging the Gap Between Our Knowledge of Child Well-Being and Our Care of the Young, is largely a summary of the seven chapters which follow it. The valuable parts of the chapter will be discussed in subsequent lessons. For this reason, the reader might very well omit it.)
A. Bridging the Gap. This excellent statement (Chapter VIII) of the fact that society knows a lot more about children than its members put into practice, is made by Dr. H. H. Goddard, a very able authority on feeble-mindedness and delinquency. It was he, by the way, who first adapted the now-famous Binet-Simon intelligence tests to American conditions. He is now professor of psychology at Ohio State University. He makes three important points to which we should like to call the reader's attention.
1. "The gap between our knowledge of child well-being and our actual care of the child is enormous." The author argues that if the care of youth were "efficient and intelligent," society would be getting an increasingly stronger grip on such chronic social ills as juvenile delinquency, crime, insanity, etc., while as a matter of fact, conditions in this respect are getting worse. It might very well be objected, however, that social conditions are not so black as Dr. Goddard paints them, and even if they are, the situation is not due solely to society's inability to rear its children according to scientific principles. It is very probable that many of our social ills are also due to defects inherent in the social order.
2. His second point is that notwithstanding our elaborate knowledge of individual differences, we still act as though people are fundamentally alike. It is interesting as well as surprising to note that one must either get into the hands of a physician, a lawyer or a social worker before his "case" or his "problem" is individualized! Teachers and parents, speaking generally, have neither a technique nor a philosophy for dealing with children individually. When parents and teachers do individualize children—and many do—it is usually by rule of thumb methods. One of the most imperative needs in education is for a scientific procedure for individualizing normal children in the home and in the school.
3. Dr. Goddard's biggest and best-stated point is that the child is endowed by nature with certain strong impulses which must be socialized by habit-training. "In the modern world," he says, "we live close together and in a cooperative society. We have divided up the work of life, so that we are each dependent
GUIDE LESSONS FOR NOVEMBER 519
upon all the rest. Under these conditions, the instinct to hoard and accumulate becomes stealing. The instinct to deceive becomes lying, and unlimited sex activity becomes immorality."
Questions
1. Discuss the relative merits of the following frequently-quoted aims of public-school education: the acquisition of skill, the acquisition of information, the development of character, the development of wholesome personality, preparation for vocation.
2. Assuming the fact, why is there such a wide gap between what we know and what we do about child care? Consider, for example, how little we do to prevent the spread of scarlet fever, to keep children from being hurt or killed by automobile, etc.
3. What special provisions, if any, do your local schools make for (a) superior children, (b) mentally defective children, (c) children with a special talent or disability? To what extent is religious education in your community (e. g., Sunday School, Primary or Religion Class) influenced by the fact of individual differences?
B. Relation of Nutrition to Mental Development. Dr. Emerson, professor of children's diseases at Tufts Medical College, Boston, has given us in Chapter IX a nice, simple statement of the bearing of nutrition on the child's mental development. He states clearly and with emphasis the outstanding fact in this relationship, namely, that mental development accompanies physical development; that mental backwardness goes hand in hand with physical backwardness. There is no one fact in the entire science of child development quite so well established as this. In a recent study of several hundred gifted children by Professor Lewis M. Terman of Stanford University, this principle is again corroborated. The causes of malnutrition as Dr. Emerson sets them forth, are not "lack of food" as many parents have supposed, but a complex of factors calling for expertness in diagnosis and treatment. It will be very striking to many persons of the "new" as well as the "old" schools of child care to hear the child specialist say: "We can discover which of the causes of malnutrition are operating in any given case only by complete social, physical growth, and mental examinations. Each of the three is essential." The mental aspect of nutrition is so important, yet so rarely recognized, that we are including here a few excerpts from a chapter on "Learning to Eat," from Blanton and Blanton's recent book, Child Guidance (Century, 1927). On the perplexing subject of thumb-sucking, for instance, we read: "Since thumb and finger-sucking must be considered as an
520 RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE
indication of the appetite or the state of metabolism of the child, mechanical restraint such as elbow cuffs or aluminum mitts, or pinning the sleeve to the bed, should not be employed. The remedy lies in diet and sunshine.
"In nearly all infants and young children there is a tendency to suck the fingers or thumb when sleepy. This, one can afford to ignore, unless it is carried beyond the third year. It is a normal infantile form of gratification." On the subject of the child's refusing food in order to gain attention, we have the following explanation: "Often, when the appetite is poor or the child has been unwell, he has to be coaxed, petted, cajoled and urged to continue his feeding in order to empty the bottle or breast. As a result he develops a method, perhaps subconsciously, whereby he gets attention by refusing his food; and unless he is very hungry, he is apt to resort to this procedure to get this attention." The infant must not only learn to eat, but must learn how to eat with others, in the approved fashion. To parents with problems of this sort, the Blantons say: "To require children to sit with adults and accept the adults' rate of eating; to watch the adult dally over a special food which to him is delectable; to sit through the conversation of parents often without saying anything or getting any attention, is destructive of good discipline.
"Women who do their own housework often do not realize that it is actually more convenient to feed children before the family sits down to the table. A small table for the children can be arranged in the kitchen, and a little festival made of the meal." And finally: "The child's meal hour should not be looked on as an opportunity for a lesson in eating only. The mother should take this occasion to demonstrate to the child—by example, not by precept—some of the social graces requiring tact and skill. At least one meal a day should be made a "party" with the child specially cleaned and dressed and on his best behavior."
Questions
1. What are some of the mental or behavior characteristics of malnourished infants and children?
2. What are the five chief causes of malnutrition, according to Dr. Emerson?
3. What is a "nutrition class"? Are there any such in your community?
4. Just how much malnutrition is there among the school children in your community?
5. What is the general nature of the health work in the public schools of your community? Is it adequate? Does it include any mental hygiene?
