LESSON II Work and Business (Second Week in December)
TEACHERS' TOPIC FOR DECEMBER—THE HOME
IDEALS OF A LATTER-DAY SAINT HOME
Summary
"My son, hear the instructions of thy father, and forsake not the law of thy mother, for they shall be an ornament of grace unto thy head, and chains about thy neck; bind them continually upon thy heart, and tie them around thy neck."
"Youth is the period of discipline; and discipline, true and thorough, is a blessing that lasts beyond this life."
Character building is the most important and most satisfactory work a home can do. Habits and ideals formed in the home will influence the destiny of its members. How vital is the parental problem! It is within the possibilities of the home to be so conducted that it will impart a love of righteousness and justice to all, and the every day necessity of self control. The home should be a center of culture and refinement; here the value of faith and virtue should be implanted, and an inspiration to a strong purpose and a lofty aim.
The home should disseminate amongst its members a true
GUIDE LESSONS FOR DECEMBER 563
spirit of helpfulness, and a willingness to perform the duties of life for which God has given them power. Within the home should be the spirit of brotherly love, to be generously used in the affairs of life, both private and public. The Word of Wisdom should be the dominant note in the health program of the home. All should be taught to know the truth and act in accordance with its dictates. By example teach the value of industry and thrift, "The hand of the diligent maketh rich." Teach and uphold the sacredness of marriage and the evils of divorce. "Man is that he may have joy:" What greater joy than to be of value and service in the community. "God has given you yourselves, now what will you do with this gift."
LESSON III Literature (Third Week in December)
GLADYS ANN WAGSTAFF
Gladys Ann Wagstaff, a poet who has brought to herself considerable honor and to the people who read her poems joy and enrichment of life, was born in Salt Lake City August 9, 1900. She obtained her education in the public schools of Salt Lake, the Salt Lake High School, and later in the University of Utah. She left the University of Utah to take a business course and for a number of years was serving the business world. At odd moments in her life she found time to write poetry. When just a tiny girl she took, she says, "immeasurable delight" in competing in poetry contests and the like. This competitive activity won for her buttons, badges, and small monetary prizes, all of which sent her "winging to the Seventh Heaven." Sensitive to joys and sorrows, she spent "many childhood hours plunged into darkest depths over some imagined hurt which a 'thoroughly normal' child would have utterly overlooked." Painful as these hours were to her, she realizes, as many other artists have realized, that of her sensitive emotions her poetry is born. To use her own words, she says, "I attribute that ability to feel as wholly responsible for my first gropings for expression. Not for just a passing whim, surely, did God imbue me with highly sensitized emotions. Consequently, on those rare occasions when 'inspiration' really comes, expressing the feeling in verse comes as easily as the unfolding of a flower. Writing, for me, when inspired, requires no striving."
564 RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE
Since leaving school our author has taken several courses in the construction of poetry—endeavoring to master technique and the forms and beauty of poems written by the old masters. In addition to all of the local papers, her verse has appeared in The New York Times, The San Francisco Examiner, The Long Beach Telegram, The Chicago Daily News. In standard periodicals such as: Good Housekeeping, The Delineator, College Humor, Love Story Magazine, Motion Picture Magazine, Vogue, St. Nicholas, and in many poetry journals, The Lariat, Lyric West, Palms, etc. Gladys Ann Wagstaff was married to Earl William Pinney August 18, 1926. She has a daughter born April 10, 1928. The Lilac appealed to Miss Wagstaff. As a result we have "Lilac-Time," which we include.
LILAC-TIME
Tonight, My garden is a place of rapturous delight, For every blossom-laden lilac bush Lifts tapered, scented fingers To the far stars! A young, May moon, Caught like a silvered, slim canoe In the topmost branches of a tall birch, Gives to each fragrant, flowering tree A shadow lovelier than itself!
Tonight, There is a soft stir of something glad And gently gay in the sweet stillness

Odorous blooms of phantom purple breathe Into the mauve, suede shadows by the wall An aromatic scent. White pebbles in the path Gleam mistily. Two scarlet tulips are Romancing gypsies in the moon's pale light!
Tonight, The lilac branches sway small, incensed urns— My garden is a place of mystical delight

"Enchantment," which we include, breathes the charm of April days.
ENCHANTMENT
One whole, green-gold, enchanted April day, In gay abandonment I threw away. All day, not one thing useful did I do, Just dreamt the blossom-scented hours through.
I found a hillock, low and warm with grass, And lay and watched the winged, wild things pass;
GUIDE LESSONS FOR DECEMBER 565
I listened to
the thrill in a bird's call And saw a shower of cherry petals fall. A shy wind from out of woodland spaces Brought violet fragrance from mossy places. And the April mist in the springtime sky Gold-powdered the clouds as they drifted by. Life and its problems were all lost to me, I saw only loveliness—lazily— Green boughs, gold sky, and lilting, wild bird call, And I, enchanted—glad—and that was all! In the nature group we include also "Lake Mary." This lake has appealed to a number of our Utah painters. We are delighted to have it make appeal to one of our Utah poets. LAKE Mary Poised like a jewel in a crown of pines, Worn on the brow of earth, Emerald green 'neath the noonday sun, Rose-gray at the day's chill birth. Calm, when the moon leaps up from the crags To the sky's starlit pathway, shimmering, Touching with wave-lips the shadowy forms Of the mirrored pines' silvered glimmering. But reaching out for the sheltering shore When the wild-winged things at the morn Cry challenge—and small things hide away And wave lips from pine shadows are torn! Love songs appeal to our auther rather frequently. A very outstanding poem is "A Love Song," after the Chinese, which we include. A Love Sone (After the Chinese) In the golden morning I walk down by the river side, A thousand silver butterflies cling to the water flowers And the lacquered petals of the lilies open in shy delight. In my enchantment I see strange flowers that are like thy face And the sound of the water is like the whispering of thy voice, And the sound of the wind in the marshes is thy voice, calling. Thou art tall among thy kind, as the water willows, Tall as the green rushes and luscious as the Springtime; Thine eyes are as the twilight over a summer sea And thy lips are as the peach blossom, flower pink. Thy breath is as the perfume of my garden— I dream—I dream amidst invisible fragrances. * * * 566 RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE In the cool of the evening I walk beside the lake, I walk in solitude and regard disconsolately the images— The shadowy images of flowers and reeds in the still water. There is the delicate promise of Springtime in the silence, But I am apart from the Springtime—for I am old. I am as old as the idol of Lo Han Dung upon the Emeporor's palaces, In my desolation I see not the pale stars in the violet sky, I see only the grace of thy body as the willows Sway. Afar the voices of the flower girls are singing in delight, Their hands, lotus drenched, weave the song as they sing; Their tiny, scarlet feet dance upon innumerable petals, And thou, who should now walk beside me—art among them. A poem published in the Ladies' Home Journal in 1925 entitled "To the Diva Mother" will find quick response in the hearts of all who read it. It was written to Madame Ernestine SchumannHeink, during her concert given for the Disabled Veterans of the World War, in Salt Lake City, June 23, 1924. To The Diva Mother I was one in that great throng Of yesterday, Filling the vast tabernacle With a surge of patriotic memories; And I stood between two veterans Blinded—both, And heard you sing. While all the tears within my being Swelled into a sob against my throat As the first note of "Taps" Slips from your lips— Sweet Touching to life A thousand poignant memories And made them live again Within the breasts Of those two buddies. I closed my eyes And stood there—blinded, too * * * Then, leaning close, That scarred and aching "Vet" Of the World War— With tears upon his wounded face Said brokenly: "God! Ain't she great!" GUIDE LESSONS FOR DECEMBER 567 We published "Those Yonder Hills" in the Relief Society Magazine for June, 1927. The author furnishes us with this note concerning that poem. "The mountains written of are the Wasatch range of eastern Utah. In early Spring they appear as though great patches of snow has remained from the winter months. Snow, indeed! Waxen, fragrant snow—myriads of pure white Sego Lilies (the State flower of Utah) growing in massed profusion over the hills!
We are closing our group of poems with a Thanksgiving Song.
THANKSGIVING SONG
Not for the great gifts you have given, God, Nor for Your eternal mercy, this song; For these You've known my heart's deep gratitude. But for the little joys the whole day long, The small delights that crowd through every hour, And ecstasies that bless my Everyday— The little, home-sweet joys which mean so much— For these, dear God, in humble thanks I pray:
For the pale, primrose breaking of the dawn, Sifting to gold upon my window sills, Bronzing the elm's last brave and clinging leaves And building burnished castles of the hills;
For the spicy, rain-sweet November air Pressing my eyelids at an open door, And for the early sunlight, hesitant, Offering shy friendliness upon my floor;
For the warmth and comfort of thought-filled rooms And things dear loved—a slender, teakwood stand Upon which sits a smug, green Chinese god, Exhaling incensed breath upon my hand,
His eyes, triumphant and intolerant, Bring memories of a slow, southern sea— Of grave, Chinese philosophy which says: "Love lives, endures through all Eternity, Life is but a jest for idle lovers * * * "
Beside a favorite book, a bowl of blue Brimming with gold-lipped, fringed chrysanthemums; And dusk—within this room—the soft mauve hue Of twilight creeping down against the hills, And starlight loveliness when day is done— The hushed serenity. For these, dear God! For these—and for the smile of my loved one!
What we enjoy particularly about Gladys Ann Wagstaff's poems is her ability to make clear the lovely picture her mind
568 RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE
conceives through tender, colorful words. There is a gentle sweetness in all she writes that is refreshing and refining to the soul.
RUTH HARWOOD
Ruth Harwood is the daughter of J. T. Harwood, the well-known Utah painter and Harriet Richards Harwood. She tells us that it is not surprising that she should have a taste for sketching and drawing because of her father's recognized talent and the fact that her mother, too, was gifted in this line. That her mother was gifted in sketching should not be a surprise to our readers for Ruth Harwood's mother is of the same family as Lee Greene Richards, the well known portrait painter of Utah. In the December, 1927, issue of The School Arts Magazine Miss Harwood has given us a unique statement of her life which we include.
"I believe that fortune has smiled on me doubly in making it possible for me to earn the necessary bread and meat of life at one art while the other can be kept sacred and undisturbed by any grind of existence.
"As my father and mother were artistic, the desire to draw came both hereditarily and environmentally but that more precious spark of poetry came unexpectedly and has cast a secret glamor over the world ever since.
"Lyrics do not flow as readily to the happy heart as to the wistful and so in more prosaic hours one branches into long narrative poems, and short stories and even embryo novels.
"Then there are drawings, decorative designs with beautiful dancing figures illustrating poetry themes, to be made. There is a whole world of these fancies to be born yet, but some day, perhaps, the workmanship will come.
"The days go on, working, living, and once in a while there is a red-letter day. It was such a day when the word first came that the annual poetry prize of the University of Utah had been given to me—just for the happy songs I had woven together for myself. That was the first time my songs had ever reached out and brought me happiness.
"There was another such day when there came word that a student in the art department of the University of California had won the yearly poetry prize. So many coveted friends came to me on the wake of that success, and then, my mother was alive to be happy too.
"Then there was a turbulent year filled with romance and my first taste of death. I dressed one day in a black shroud, marched around with many others in a sweltering heat and came home with M. A. In art from the University of California. That was the first time my mother was not there to rejoice too, but my father was there, kind and patient, trying to take the place of both.
GUIDE LESSONS FOR DECEMBER 569
"A wonderful red-letter day when a librarian friend showed me a book from London of a hundred best poems of the year from English and American writers and there was my name and one of my poems. Lesser red-letter days scattered along with poems and drawings and articles appearing here and there in magazines! Always working eagerly, impulsively and dreaming of bigger things!
"This summer another shining day with word that the prize for the best sonnet on Browning from the Poetry Society of America was for me. I immediately burst into a dozen more sonnets.
"You ask my hobby. My profession is art, my ambition writing, so perhaps my little house is the hobby. I love it that much. If it looked the way I would want, it would have arches and a swooping roof and a host of modern conveniences inside as I do not crave domestic pursuits.
"But the supreme view! Fifteen feet of window toward the bay and at night Berkeley, and Oakland and Richmond twinkling below as far as the eye can see * * * then the black water and the soft glory of San Francisco in the distance and over all a dome of stars, except when the fog creeps in and wraps its fingers around the hilltop.
"My father, one of Utah's finest artists and art director of its state University, has been such a blessing in reclaiming the small garden spot from the wild brush and rabbits that skip about ready for any chance green that may be struggling for existence.
"Two years now I have been away teaching art, one as supervisor of art in the New Mexico State Teacher's College and one as design instructor in the University of Utah. That is a long time to be away from California and what joy it will be to be back on the hilltop with my friend and my work and my poet self."
This summer Miss Harwood has been abroad with her father, an experience which will be enriching to one gifted as she is gifted. She tells us she makes her living through her sketching and that writing poetry is a diversion that feeds her soul. As she feeds her own soul so does she feed the souls of others. A poem known as "The Shoe Factory" (Song of the Knot-Tyer) has proved to be the most popular of Miss Harwood's poems. It is a poem that dignifies manual labor. Consequently we hail it with pleasure. It was published first in "Poetry," and was selected by an English anthologist for publication in his volume, "The Best Poems of 1922." It was conceived after a visit to a shoe factory by a psychology class for the purpose of investigating some phases of mental reaction. It may be found in Stevenson's Home Book of Verse—and Cooper's Poems of Youth.
THE SHOE FACTORY (Song of the Knot-Tyer)
They told me When I came That this would be drudgery, Always the same Things over and over Day after day— The swift movement In the same small way.
Pick up, Place, Push, And it's tied, Take off, Cut, And put It aside.
Over and over, In rhythmical beat— Some say it is drudgery, But to me it is sweet.
Pick up, Place, Push, And it's tied, Outdoors The sky Is so blue And so wide!
It's a joyous song Going steadily on, Marching in measures Till the day is gone.
Pick up, Place, Push, And it's tied, Soon end Of day Will bring him To my side.
Oh, I love the measures Singing on so fast, Speeding happy hours Till he comes at last!
570 RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE
GUIDE LESSONS FOR DECEMBER 571
Among Miss Harwood's numerous poems is one entitled "Silver Morning," which we feel sure will appeal to our readers.
SILVER MORNING
God has dipped this morning In a silver pool, And left it iridescent, Glistening and cool.
All the sky is silver, And the hills between Veil their verdant beauty With a silver sheen.
Even buds are silver On the waking trees, And the larks discover Silver melodies.
And the rippling river Croons a silver song To the sentient willows As it purls along.
And the shining morning That must pass so soon Leaves a silver echo In my lilting tune.
The Acacia seems to have made very special appeal to Miss Harwood as she writes a poem entitled "Acacia Rapture."
ACACIA RAPTURE
It matters not how many years Of waking springs I see, Each fresh time there appears Acacia with its wealth of golden filigree I stand before it, rapture mad, As to some deity.
I fancy that the fervent earth Has climbed all year to this, And that acacias in their worth Are to her as the utmost kiss.
It matters not how many years The gold acacias break, They make me mad and glad to tears, And turn me robber for their sake.
572 RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE
She refers to California in a poem called "Yearning" which we include.
YEARNING
O to be in California in the spring! While torpid earth is held in winter shrouds, To see her wreathe herself in pearly clouds And break into a song of burgeoning!
And O, to watch the barren hills unfold; First comes the mossy carpeting of green, Fog-misted, sometimes, to a silver sheen, And then to watch them flare to mauve and gold!
And O, to see acacias burst in bloom, Like clustered sunshine billowing the trees, To hear the droning music of the bees, And scent the air weighed heavy with perfume!
To think she's showing now her pageantry In all the glory of spring's verdant dress And flinging, open-armed, her loveliness! To think of spring! * * * And I not there to see!
Also a poem entitled
PASTEL
To keep this evening's loveliness I seek, This sunset hour in my garden spent, Among my iris where each purple cheek Of velvet softness lulls me with content.
A hush of happiness has seemed to fall About my garden. Bloom and brush and tree Have felt the magic touch transforming all Into a misty quiet harmony.
O, sweet, my garden lit with sunset rose! O, soft, the blossoms folding close for sleep! O, frail, my song that strives before it goes This evening's pastel loveliness to keep!
Her poem entitled "Vagabond Song" carries in its lines the abandoned joy of one who really lives close to nature.
VAGABOND SONG
Because I have so few of goodly things That money brings, perchance the world is bold To scoff at me, because in lacking gold, I could not hope to know the joy life brings.
But O! I have a heart that gaily sings, And feet that swiftly dance, and wealth untold, For I have eyes to catch and soul to hold The gold of sunsets and the jewels of springs.
GUIDE LESSONS FOR DECEMBER 573
And I find gems in all the stars that shine; And dazzling diamonds strung on spider's lace; And glistening silver on the water's face; And full red rubies sparkling on the vine.

I doubt if you, in any gilded place, Feel richer in your wealth than I in mine!
A poem entitled "Poetry Magic" is interesting because it really reveals something of the way in which the poet works.
POETRY MAGIC
My poetry Is like a magic wizardry. For with deft hands I pluck a few Glad-chosen words, And build for me A rainbow tinted bridge; And leave the sentient solemn earth, And dance down my fairy bridge, And find some secret glowing place Of dream-lit wonders; And wander there, And thrill and sing, And twine dream flowers in my hair, And dance and fling My carefree arms into the air.
And so—when suddenly You speak to me, You must be patient Until I can return from wanderings A thousand worlds away.
QUESTIONS AND PROBLEMS
1. Which one of the authors uses one talent to earn a living and the other for self-expression?
2. Name the flowers that the two poets we are studying mention in their poetry.
3. Tell the circumstances under which a poem was born in the Salt Lake Tabernacle.
4. Repeat the tribute to the singer made by one of the disabled veterans.
5. What do you know about the enlistment of the sons of this singer in the World War?
6. Which poem refers to the state flower as it blooms on the mountain side? Repeat the lines that refer to the flower.

LESSON IV Social Service (Fourth Week in December)
THE CHILD STUDY COURSE
Lesson 9. Nervous and Mental Hygiene in Children.
(Based on Chapter X. The Child: His Nature and His Needs)
The last lesson—The Relation of Nutrition to Mental Development—will have convinced the reader of the general importance of mental hygiene in the life of the child. The mental hygiene movement is one of the most recent and in many ways the most important developments in the fields of psychology and education during the past twenty years. Dr. William A. White, the author of this well-written chapter, is one of the outstanding mental hygienists (sometimes called psychiatrists) in America. He is at present superintendent of the government hospital for the insane at Washington, D. C.
A. Some Principles of Mental Hygiene
Perhaps the best way to get the "meat" out of the present lesson is for the reader (and class-leader too) to select from Dr. White's chapter principles such as the following:
"Children are not just small adults." (p. 195.) "Then again, the child is not an isolated being." (p. 195.) "The whole developmental period of childhood has these two aims: the maximum unfoldment of the individual possibilities consistent with the necessary degrees of conformity to social standards." (p. 196.) "Strength of character, just like muscular strength, is developed by overcoming difficulties, not by following the path of least resistance." (p. 198.) "The impetus and initiative must come from within the child * * *" (p. 200.) "Every exaggerated character trait is evidence of an unbalanced personality make-up and is evidence also of the existence of the opposite trait." (p. 201.)
To Dr. White's excellent list of mental hygiene principles, we add a few of our own, as follows:
1. Most mental handicaps are preventable.
2. Activity is the normal characteristic of childhood; physical and mental inactivity are pathological.
3. The differences between personalities are so great as to make it dangerous to prescribe the same treatment for all individuals.
4. Mental poise is facilitated by an alternating program of work, rest, and play.
5. Almost all persons have some degree of inferiority-feeling. Compensations for actual or imagined inferiority are quite
GUIDE LESSONS FOR DECEMBER 575
normal. The problem of child guidance is therefore one of facilitating appropriate compensations.
6. Every child and grown-up person should experience success or superiority in some field or situation, with sufficient frequency to prevent the development of an inferiority-complex.
7. All children and grown-ups normally demand a confidante, i. e., some understanding person who will listen without moralizing.
8. Energies, impulses, etc., cannot be suppressed. They may, however, be sublimated, i. e., guided to expression on higher planes.
9. Many personality problems are overcome when the handicapped person is able, through the assistance of others, to objectify his own problems, i. e., to analyze his own difficulty as though it were the problem of another.
10. Punishment is a dubious method of dealing with children's conduct problems. The following suggestions of Felix Adler are well worth contemplating in this connection:
a. Never punish in anger. b. Distinguish between the child and the fault. c. Do not "lecture" children. d. Do not threaten them. e. While insisting upon obedience, demand nothing which is unreasonable. f. Do not employ corporal punishment; it tends to brutalize the child, to break his spirit, and to weaken his sense of shame.
QUESTIONS
1. Why is mental health more important than physical health?
2. How do you explain the increasing interest in mental hygiene?
3. What does Dr. White mean by the phrase (p. 197) "reality may be overwhelming?"
4. What is a feeling of inferiority? What are its causes? What types of inferiority feeling (popularly called "complexes") have you observed in children and adults? How should a child with an inferiority feeling be dealt with in his home and in the school?
5. How are "phantasy" related to inferiority feelings?
6. Is wholesome personality in a child as important as his mastery of the three R's? Then why do we fail to emphasize and train for it in our schools?
B. A Good Book for Parents
There has been so much written on mental hygiene that is either over-technical or unsound that we are giving a short review of "incorrigibility" and "bad habits"
576 RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE
or synopsis of a recent book which we can safely recommend for further reading by the parent with an especially difficult problem-child. The book is written by Dr. Erwin Wexberg, and is called Your Nervous Child: A Guide for Parents and Teachers (New York: Albert & Charles Boni, 178 pp., $1.75.)
Dr. Wexberg speaks as a physician. He had a wide experience with children's cases in Vienna, where he was associated with the famous Dr. Alfred Adler. The book comprises three well-rounded chapters on the symptoms, causes, and treatment of nervousness in children. While the manifestations of nervousness may take the form of disturbances of nutrition and urination, night terrors, stuttering, masturbation, lying, etc., the basic condition is that of "a child who has lost courage to fight his way through, or is struggling along the wrong road."
Chief among the causes of nervousness in children, Wexberg lists: The Feeling of Inferiority, The Fatherless Boy, The Youngest Child, The Only Child, Sex, The Spoiled Child, Egoism of Parents, Vain Mothers. With almost uncanny insight he explains how bodily infirmities (such as hare-lip, prominent ears, protracted sickliness) strengthen the feeling of inferiority and cause the child to be nervous. It is not too much to say that the author's discussion of sex as a cause of nervousness and psychic homo-sexuality, is the best and most straight-forward thing anywhere in print accessible to the layman.
The chief prophylaxis and cure for nervousness in children (except, of course, where it is due to organic causes) Wexberg insists is "correct" education, the task of which is "to do everything that can help a child become an independent and courageous man * * * ready and prepared to adapt himself to the community to which he belongs, and to render his best service where he has chosen to serve." Independence and courage are the keynotes of this "correct" education. The author is averse to marks and reports, yet he would "blame mildly and praise in a friendly fashion." He adduces new arguments against all forms of punishment and shows the futility of moralizing. He concludes his effective plea for freedom and the early psychological weaning of the child with the rather startling statement that "children should be treated as adults, not as children."
There is only one important point upon which we differ with Dr. Wexberg and that is in regard to his assumption that only the physician is competent to deal with these common (functional) forms of nervousness in children. If parents and teachers cannot sooner or later learn to deal with most of these difficulties themselves, then progress under our system of family life is impossible. Such intelligent understanding of these matters on the part of the average parent, is, after all, the real reason for the parental movement.

XV NOVEMBER, 1928 No. 11 Disarm By Minnie Johnson Hardy Spring has come to the desert, and yucca blossoms so white, Waxen and fair and fragrant, bloom in the morning light; A wood-dove coos in the thicket; but what is this Voice I hear? As the soft wind stirs the chaparral, it comes to me sweet and clear. It comes from the graves of dear ones, who wore the blue and the gray, Where flowers and flags are drooping, in loving memory today. It comes from the restless ocean, that cradle so blue and deep, Where many a brave young sailor has gone to his last, long sleep. From the graves of our splendid heroes, who, by some sad mischance, Have folded their hands forever, '"SSomewhere on the fields of France." The red poppies bloom in'Flanders, but what do the white crosses spell? Let your heart speak, dear mother! You know full well—too well. In honor today of our heroes, our flags now float at half-mast; We have closed a chapter in history, on a sad mistaken past. "O nations of Earth, awaken, be not slaves to war's wild alarm," 'Tis the voice of our cherished dear ones—''Peace—Disarm— Disarm." "Peace, peace on earth, O my brothers; it is our dear Father's will; Hear ye not his voice commanding," "My children, ye shall not kill?" "Cease making men into soldiers, cease making guns to destroy, Cease building monsters-of-the-deep to slay your neighbor's boy." A mockingbird sings in the chaparral, but still on the wind that Voice, "Let Brotherhood rule in the future, Live, Love; In peace rejoice." It echoes from city to village, from palace to cottage and farm; "Let not our sacrifice be in vain, Peace—Disarm—Disarm." Ina Coolbrith By Kate Thomas We are pleased to present to our readers a sketch of the life of Ina Coolbrith, a pioneer of the west and a niece of the Prophet Joseph. Elder Joseph Fielding Smith, Church Historian, tells us that his father kept up a correspondence with the author during his life and that the family has been aware of her literary achievements for many years.—Editor's Note. At the death of Ina Coolbrith, "the poet-laureate of California," a friend of hers told me that she came of Mormon parentage, but never spoke of it. However, the Los Angeles Times of March the seventh came out with the following: "Poetess' Past Uncovered. Ina Coolbrith Revealed as Mormon Leader's Niece, Pioneer of West, and Jack London's Mentor. "Robert H. Davis, in a copyrighted article in the New York Sun today, lifts the veil surrounding the early life of the late Ina Donna Coolbrith, poetess, and reveals her as a heroine of the Overland Trail, the niece of the founder of the Mormon religion and the "literary mother" of Jack London. "Ina Coolbrith died February 29, 1928, in Berkeley, California, at 86 years of age, regarded as one of the most noted poets of the West and a contemporary of Bret Harte, Mark Twain, Joaquin Miller, Prentice Mulford, Louis Agassiz and others who contributed to the literature of the nineteenth céntury. "On her arrival in San Francisco soon after the close of the Civil War, Davis says she became an associate of Harte in the editorship of the Overland Monthly. Her poems flamed through its pages, and her personality made her queen of Russian Hill, San Francisco's Mount Olympus. From 1874 to 1893 she was at the head of the public library at Oakland. "Through the instrumentality of one who was close to Ina Coolbrith, Davis offers the story of her genesis. She was born in Illinois, March 10, 1841, the daughter of Don Carlos Smith, a brothet of Joseph Smith the prophet, founder of Mormonism. And Agnes Coolbrith. "The family history became disrupted with the death. ™: her father and two uncles, who were slain by a mob June 27, 1844, in Carthage jail, Hancock county, Illinois. There are no available records as to what happened to her two sisters. "In the mid-Fifties Ina and her mother, who had remarried, left Illinois and crossed the plains over the Old Overland Trail with James Beckwith, Indian scout, arriving at Salt Lake when Ina still was in her teens. INA COOLBRITH 581 She vigorously opposed the polygamy of the Mormon colony, and a few years later went with her mother to Los Angeles, where she began her education as Ina Donna Coolbrith, taking the maiden. Name of her mother. She remained in Southern California until well into her twenties, turning a deaf ear to all offers of marriage. "In San Francisco she was elected as the only woman member of the Bohemian Club, and twenty different clubs and societies carried her in their 'memberships. In 1915 the poet laureateship of the state of California was conferred on her by the Governor. "While she was in the West, Davis says, Jack London came to her a ragged, barefoot newsboy and asked what she considered it best for him to read. She shaped his career. "She was talent's confessor," Davis continues, "the inspiration of youth, the kindly guide to all beginners, but none shared the secret of her girlhood." This sounded so near to home that I made inquiries about her and learned that she was much the type of the pioneer mother of Utah, kind, wholesome, old-fashioned, and motherly, with an intense love of the territory she had chosen as her abiding place, together with a strong desire to magnify the talents God had given her. Had she lived till March the tenth, she would have been eighty-seven years old; and her friends, west and east were planning a celebration. It made me think of "Aunt Em" and the good times held upon her honored birthday. Miss Coolbrith had been ill for several months; and while her death was not a surprise, it was a real sorrow to many people. She was the connecting link between the old California literary group and those of the modern day. "She belonged," stated one of the daily papers, "among the first picturesque group of pioneers, who came to the state in covered wagons. She came with her parents from Springfield, Illinois, in the days when the gold lure was drawing thousands across the plains." For years she was a librarian in Oakland, then was chosen librarian to the Mercantile and Bohemian Club libraries in San Francisco. At her home in San Francisco she became the center of a coterie of literary people, chief among them being Mark Twain, Bret Harte, Joaquin Miller, and Robert Louis Stevenson. The locality was spoken of by wits as the "poet's corner." During this period she published her first book, A Perfect Day and Other Poems. It is said that as a very young child she formed the idea of proclaiming the beauties of California in verse. She was bedecked with the flowers of her adopted native state when a passing Mexican called attention to her by calling out, "Look at the pretty little Americano!" so the story goes. The prettiness, in her simple mind, came from her decorations, and she determined then to make them known to everybody. She was locally famed as a poet, and her second book, Songs From the Golden Gate,
582 RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE
brought her much attention from people who were watching the growth of the then crude Pacific coast; presently she was referred to as the "Sappho of the West." This success induced her to go to New York, but she was not at home there and was very glad to return to California. She lived in various California towns and was in touch with phases of California from the Indian and Spanish population to the mining camps. Her best poems seem to have been written in Oakland. At the time of her death she was a resident of Berkeley. Her last poem, "The Vision of St. Francis," was printed in northern California newspapers last November. Laureateship was bestowed upon her by the governor through the legislature in 1919; "loved, laurel-crowned poetess of California." She has lived in the golden state almost eighty years. She was six when "dogged by Indians and harassed by hunger the little family reached California by way of Beckwith pass, named after the famous scout, Jim Beckwith, who piloted Miss Coolbrith's party." Eighty years within its borders! No wonder she wrote:
CALIFORNIA
Upon my fresh green sods No king has walked to curse and desolate; But in the valleys freedom sits and sings, And on the heights above; Upon her boughs the leaves of olive boughs, And in her arms a dove; And the great hills are pure, undesecrate, White with their snows untrod, And mighty with the presence of their God!
There was nothing profound in her verse. She was a rhythmical, light, lyric poet, as notice:
MEADOW LARKS
Sweet, sweet, sweet! O happy that I am! Listen to the meadow larks across the fields that sing! Sweet, sweet, sweet! O subtle breath of balm, O winds that blow, O buds that grow, O rapture of the spring!
Sweet, sweet, sweet! O happy world that is! Dear heart, I hear across the fields my mating pipe and call. Sweet, sweet, sweet! O world so full of bliss— For life is love, the world is love, and love is over all.
Nothing could be simpler. It is the rhythm that attracts. Note it also in:
WEST WINDS
I would you might sing me, summer wind, A song of a little chamber! Sing soft, sing low, how the roses grow, And the starry jasmines clamber, Through emerald rifts how the moonlight drifts, And the sunlight's mellow amber.
Sing of a hand in the fluttering leaves, Like a wee white bird in its nest; Of a white hand twined in the leaves to find A bloom for the fair young breast; Sing of my love, my little love, My snow-white dove in her nest, As she looks through the fragrant jasmine leaves Into the wasting nest.
Tenderly, tenderly, summer wind, With murmurous winds caresses, O wind of the south to her beautiful mouth Do you cling with your balmy kisses? Flutter and float o'er the white, white throat, And ruffle the golden tresses.
"The long year groweth from green to gold," Saith the song of the willow tree: "My tresses cover, my roots unfold," O summer wind sing it to me! Lorn and dreary, sad and dreary, As lovers that parted be— But sweet as the grace of a fair young face I never again may see.
And for those who have enjoyed the literary lessons there is a distinct pleasurable truth in the last stanza of:
SUMMER PAST
Now the summer is all over! We have wandered through the clover, We have plucked in wood and lea Bluebell and anemone. We were children of the sun, Very brown to look upon; We were stained, hands and lips, With the berries' juicy tips.

584 RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE
Now the merry days are over! Woodland tenants seek the cover, And the swallow leaves again For his castle nests in Spain.
Shut the door and close the blind: We shall have the bitter wind, We shall have the dreary rain Striving, driving at the pane.
Send the ruddy firelight higher, Draw your easy-chair yet nigher, Through the winter bleak and chill We may have our summer still.
Here are poems we may read, Pleasant fancies to our need; Ah, eternal summer-time Dwells within the poet's rhyme!
All the birds' sweet melodies Linger in these songs of his, And the blossoms of all ages Wait their fragrance from his pages.
"In the light of today's criticisms and preferences," says an Oakland Tribune editorial, "it may be said that there are many followers of poetry who do not appreciate the values in that which Miss Coolbrith wrote. * * * She was an artist of high ideals, a writer who would not stoop for effects, and one who, with her loved memories and associations, clung fondly to the style and manners of that time in which she was so conspicuous a figure. Not only as a poetess was Miss Coolbrith loved. She had the gifts and graces to inspire others and to her came many who were later famous. * * * When the Bohemian Club of San Francisco departed from all precedent and made her its only woman member, it did so to honor the artist and friend of artists. Miss Coolbrith was the proud champion of pure, classic art, and a generous benefactor to youth seeking to express itself in any worthy way.
"There are older people in the Eastbay who remember her as the rarely beautiful young woman who presided at the Oakland library, where she directed young reading with a wisdom and friendliness which made a lasting impression. To the poetry of the West and the Nation she made a contribution which was recognized on two continents, and in the hearts of her friends she dwelt secure."
INA COOLBRITH 585
The San Francisco Examiner comments: "Wherever Ina Donna Coolbrith sat, in the company of men and women of her day, she was the center of attention. With the white scarf over her gray hair in these later years, she suggested somewhat the pictures of Queen Victoria; but Ina Coolbrith, even in illness, left the impression of vigor. Her humor and appreciation remained alert; her voice was deep and strong; her faculties did not desert. She was ever constructive and helpful. All through her years she was a source of inspiration to others."
Ina Coolbrith had met Whittier, Longfellow, Lowell and others of the earlier day poets. Of the later, Edwin Markham and George Sterling were her friends. On one of her birthdays not many years back, one of her best friends and warmest admirers, no less than "the Poet of the Sierras," Joaquin Miller, was asked to make a poem about her. His reply was, "I am not equal to doing her halfway justice. Her whole life has been a poem, a sweet pathetic poem." It makes one wonder just what the pathos might have been. But I was told by one who seemed to know that Ina Coolbrith, through her intense love for children, had given to certain children of others her whole heart and a devoted care and had reaped the usual reward of the unselfish by receiving in return small gratitude and little love. So wags the world.
Thanksgiving By Mrs. Merling D. Clyde
There's thankfulness within our hearts That those we love are near; The face of friends; the kindly word; The voice; the smiles that cheer.
We're thankful for enough to eat; A place to keep us warm; The knowledge that a Higher Power Will keep us safe from harm.
We're grateful for the sunshine bright, And for the winter snow; For rain, and trees; and for the flowers; For each dear day we know.
Mother's "Outside Interest" By Katharine C. McKay
Margaret Morrill read the editorial twice and then hardly grasped its meaning. It had something to do with women having an interest apart from the home. It did not appeal to her. She read little, anyway, and then only the women's page in Farm Journals or articles about poultry. Tonight being Sunday night and she a firm believer in keeping the Sabbath properly, she could not knit, darn, or sew, as was her custom. It would soon be nine o'clock and her bed time. With a sigh she laid the magazine down and looked about her. Tom and Mary, home from school over the week-end, were seated on the davenport, Tom listlessly turning cards, endeavoring to amuse himself with solitaire, Mary deep in a novel she had brought home with her. She knew they were both bored. Somehow they never seemed so very happy at home any more. During the first two years at school they had come home regularly every week-end. This year their visits had been very few, dances and parties offering excuse to stay in town. Tom Senior went in often, too, and went shopping with them or to theaters; but she, with her milk, chickens and turkeys to care for, could never accept their invitations. It made Mary quite out of patience. "Why on earth does Father keep a hired man when you do all the work? What's Jim good for anyway, if not to tend chickens and turkeys? And Annie is as good help as you could find anywhere." Tom would add, "Let up a little, Mom, and enjoy life. We only live once." And Ethel, the married daughter living in town, urged her, too, to take things easier. None of them seemed to understand that tending a garden, making butter and watching the growth of her fowls was her life—that she would be lost without her farm tasks. She glanced at her husband. He, clad in a silk dressing gown and slippers, Mary's idea of the proper way to dress for the evening, was sunk deep in a big leather chair, thoroughly enjoying his paper. She was sitting in an old rocker, an eye-sore, Mary called it, that was a remnant of less prosperous days. A faded cushion covered the board seat, a velvet tidy embroidered by her mother in the long ago, adorned the back. It was not very comfortable, but she was used to it; and besides, after she had done the supper dishes and tidied up the kitchen, it was practically bed time and foolish to think of getting comfortable. These new chairs, like the other new furnishings that Father and the children had insisted upon, while very elegant, were not restful to her. She was afraid of spoiling the upholstery with her rough
MOTHER'S "OUTSIDE" INTEREST 587
farm clothing, and could never rest her feet in comfort on the lustrous rugs for fear she would leave a trace of the hen-yard. The bright shining kitchen with its washable linoleum and rag rugs was more to her liking. No one was paying any attention to her; she might as well retire but she hated to just get up and leave without a word, so she ventured, "Them turkeys—"
"Those turkeys." Son and daughter spoke in concert, but neither looked up.
"Those turkeys," she corrected meekly, "that I bought from Ambrose ain't—"
"Aren't," they chorused again.
"Aren't what he made 'em out to be. I'm glad I didn't give him what he asked. They're worth what I did give, but I wont make much on them. Rate about third class, I imagine." She ceased and waited for a comment from one of them. There was no reply. After a moment Tom laid down his cards. "You're a good bargainer, Mom. If anyone could get the best of you it would be old Ambrose, and you can beat him. Are turkeys pretty high this year?"
"Will be by Christmas," his mother answered quietly. He was only trying to be polite. She knew that no one but her had the slightest interest in either old Ambrose or the turkeys. In fact Mary had threatened to wring the necks of the entire turkey flock, they gave her such a pain. An idle threat, as Mary could not be hired to go near a turkey unless it was picked, stuffed and roasted. Tom Senior, feeling a little ashamed that his son should show such manners, folded his paper and sat up attentively. "I didn't quite hear what you said, Margaret. Did Ambrose cheat you?"
"No, but I didn't make anything, either." Not much encouragement there. "How do you want that new hen-house fixed? I forgot all about it, but I'll tell Jim in the morning."
"I told him a week ago and it's all done now." Father, chagrined, resumed his paper. Tom, relieved of having to take part in an uninteresting conversation, spread the cards in front of him; so Margaret reached for her magazine. After all there might be something in that editorial—she'd think it over. With a quiet goodnight she took it to her room. Tom and the children would not retire for hours. After his perusal of the paper he always went through their financial problems with them, discussing their school and entertainment, even their clothes. She should have done that at least, but Father handled the funds
588 RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE
and Mary wound him around her finger, so she always went to him for everything. Alone in her room, she sat down on the edge of her bed to read the article a third time and see if it was really worth while. The writer, a woman editor, considered it almost a necessity that for her own sake a woman have something to occupy and entertain her besides her home. While her children were little, it was all well and proper to center all interest in the home; but when they entered high school or college, it was Mother's business to look to herself. She cited instances of women who had gone back to school teaching—had become buyers for local stores; one even had studied law. Mother Morrill thought it all over. It was evident that she needed something. She was not contented and pleased with herself, and her husband and children desired her companionship less all the time. She must face the matter squarely. She forced herself to recall an incident that had happened at Ethel's last winter; one which she put entirely out of her thoughts lest it hurt her too keenly. She had been upstairs getting Ethel's baby to sleep and had come down so quietly that her daughters, in conversation in the living room had not heard her. They were evidently discussing the coat she had just purchased. "I'd like, just for once, to drag Mother into a decent store and make her buy something with a little style." It was Mary speaking. "She acts actually afraid of Main Street."
"This coat isn't so bad," Ethel had said, "And as Mother says, it's very good material and will last a life time. Worse luck." Both girls laughed. "Doesn't that make you sick? This good material stuff gets on my nerves—I've heard it so long and so much. Really, Ethel, I believe Mother likes to look like a hick."
"Mary, for shame."
"I can't help it. Sometimes I'm positively ashamed of her; aren't you?—her hands and her hair—and then such awful clothes! She could dress better. I actually feel sorry for Dad when they go anyplace in town together, there's such a contrast."
"You mustn't even think of such all again, Mary. After all she's our mother and—"
Margaret Morrill had not waited for more. Quietly she had gone back upstairs. She told herself, with the good common sense that she possessed, that Father would never be ashamed of her—they had struggled and suffered too much together—and that Mary, when age had made her a little wiser, would get over all this foolishness. So she resolved from that moment to forget it entirely. Now, thinking over this evening's experience and many similar ones, and again using her common sense, she decided that
MOTHER'S "OUTSIDE" INTEREST 589
there must be something wrong with her. She looked at her hands—pretty hands they might have been, but the nails were broken and bruised, and the hands themselves were coarse and rough, covered with scars and deeply lined. She went to her mirror. Her face was not so bad—the complexion so beautiful in her youth had not been hurt by good soap and water, healthful food and sunshine. Her cheeks still possessed the ruddy glow so earnestly desired nowadays, but her hair—it was awful. However that could wait. The thing of importance now was that Mother had decided to have an "outside interest," and henceforth all her efforts must be turned to deciding what that should be. For the next week she read the paper and all the magazines industriously, especially the part concerning women and their work. The first time she asked for a part of the paper Tom Morrill looked up in surprise; but she was so casual, so matter of fact, that he forbore comment. At the end of a week her decision was made; so she spent her time planning how to carry it out. Much to her surprise, the children came home the following week end. Tom Senior brought them and seemed quite proud of his achievement. "I made Tom give up a stag-party and—what was your sacrifice, Mary?"
"Nothing but a luncheon," Mary answered carelessly. "But why, Tom?" Mother asked.
"I'll have to be with the sheep at least a month, so it will be our last time together for a while. Where will you go, Mother, Ethel's or Carrie's?" Both children waited expectantly. Mrs. Morrill hesitated, to enjoy the children's discomfiture. "Carrie's I guess. She's been wanting me for some time." There was positive relief manifested in their faces. "You'll like it at Aunt Carrie's, Mom; she has so many chickens and things," Tom said; and Mary added, "And Ethel's baby is so cross, you'd not enjoy a minute there." Well, that was settled, quickly and easily. Then the letter was sent to Carrie, letting her in on the secret and outlining some of her plan. Carrie was just finishing breakfast and getting the children off to school, hers were still in the "grades," when the letter came. She cried a little as she read it. "I wonder if my children will ever be ashamed of me," she thought, as she watched them, still almost babies, trudging off. "But Maggie will make it all right; she always does—I'll bank on her"; and with a sigh almost envious, she started to gather her dirty dishes. "Your station is Greenfield, Madam," the conductor said, as
590 RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE
two stations out of town Mrs. Morrill started down the aisle, suitcase in hand. "I forgot something," she replied and brushed by him. Back in the city she went at once to a hotel, a good, clean, reliable one, though not in the most fashionable part of town, and took a room and bath for two weeks. She examined her check book. It showed a goodly sum. All her chicken, egg and turkey money had gone into it, and nothing had ever been taken out. When she had wanted to help, Tom had always said, "No, Mother, that's yours and you might need it some time. We'll have to be lots worse off than this before I'll take a penny of it." So it had grown—she was almost amazed to see how much. Her first plan had been to venture into one of those shops that Mary had wished to "drag" her in and buy clothes suitable to a woman of business; but on second thought she decided she could probably do better if she went looking as she did. Accordingly she set out, the address she sought on a newspaper clipping in her hand. It was on a side street in a most undesirable part of the business section of town. It would have to be moved—but not immediately. Its location would do fine for the present, as there would be no chance of meeting the children. Before a dirty window bearing the sign "Wholesale Poultry" she stopped. There was no sign of life within, but the door gave to her push and she found herself in a large room, barren and untidy. A counter, covered with worn oil-cloth and containing a roll of paper and string, projected to the center near the front. Behind it, along the walls and ceiling, empty hooks were visible; at the rear a space, probably a refrigerating plant, was boxed off. The prospect was not very encouraging. At her entrance a man seated behind the counter, using it as a prop for his feet, had straightened up but did not deign to rise. He watched her with interest as she surveyed the room. At length he spoke, "Can I do anything for you, Madam?"
"I should like a few moments of your time to talk about your business." He looked at her clothes, substantial enough—but—and the worn leather bag she carried, and decided she was a solicitor or canvasser, perhaps a book agent. She drew a chair to the opposite side of the counter and seated herself. Ordinarily he didn't care for this kind of companionship, but he had nothing else to do this morning and she might prove interesting. "Your business is not very good, I imagine," she said, looking around. "Good? It's rotten. I just barely make enough to keep alive and am lucky to do that."
"How much is it worth, do you think?"
MOTHER'S "OUTSIDE" INTEREST 591
The question surprised him. He hesitated before replying but decided she could mean nothing serious. "It ain't worth nothing. I'd sell the whole works for half a dollar."
"I want to buy it." He was stunned for a moment, but instantly his business sense came to the fore. "Business ain't always so bad as this," he said, "I'll make you a good price," and he named what to Mrs. Morrill seemed an immense sum.
"I'll give you just half," she said, "cash."
"Why Ma'am, the property's worth more than that. I can't give it to you."
"I know what the property's worth and the business, you admit, is no good. I'm offering you a fair price and cash. Will you take it?" It was too good an opportunity to lose, and the owner of the Wholesale Poultry Business knew it. "Yes," he said. And so Mrs. Morrill acquired her "outside interest." The days following were exceedingly busy ones. Herself to care for first, Mrs. Morrill visited some of the best shops and put herself in the hands of the capable clerks. They turned out a most satisfactory product. Then one day she ventured into a beauty parlor—for a shampoo and manicure—she told the enquiring attendant and was whisked away to a clean little white curtained alcove. The girl ran her fingers through her long luxurious hair caressingly. "Golly," she said, "You don't see hair like this nowadays. The way you do it no one would dream it was so pretty." It was what Mrs. Morrill was hoping for. "How can I do it?" she asked. "Not so tight. You could have a beautiful natural wave if you'd train it. I'll show you when I get it dry." And so she fluffed and fussed; and Mrs. Morrill went away with combs, pins and nets, well tapered fingernails, light fluffy hair, and a sense of pride and well-being never hers before. She discovered that she would have to make regular visits to markets and farmers, and that necessitated a car. So she purchased a neat little roadster and took lessons in running it. Her shop underwent a complete transformation. She cleaned and scoured, added new furniture, more hooks, and installed a complete modern refrigerating plant to take the place of the unsatisfactory one on hand. She found she would either need a stenographer or learn to typewrite herself. The business could not warrant a stenographer yet, so she took a business course three nights a week and spent the other nights in practice. She had to talk long and hard to the retail merchants before she met with any success; but at length they came to realize that "she knew her stuff" and that they could do better through her than
592 RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE
from the farmers. She visited all the farmers in person within a radius of sixty miles and corresponded with those farther away. The business boomed. The little shop on Second Street radiated prosperity. Help had to be hired, trucks to be purchased. Mother Morrill was busy every minute of her day, but she went through it all as calmly and serenely as though she were used to running a railroad. Mary tore open her note. Half to herself she exclaimed, "Well, what do you think of this?" Ethel, standing behind her, responded, "Simply that Mother's done what Dad and you kids constantly urged—taken an apartment for the winter."
"Did you get one, too?"
"Yes, for myself and family. I bet Mother's cooked up a good old-fashioned meal. I've been looking forward to it all day."
"But, Ethel, we haven't even asked her to come to town this winter. She always made so much fuss over her everlasting turkeys. You don't suppose—she couldn't have brought them with her—could she?"
"Silly, turkeys would do fine in an apartment. I think Mother has just decided to give in and spend the winter here, and I'm mighty glad. The rest will do her a world of good."
"It will kill her. She has to be slaving or she isn't happy. Something wonderful must have happened to jar her loose from those turkeys." Tom was equally surprised. "My gosh," he expostulated on reading his mother's note, "An invitation to dinner." He glanced at the note again. "Did you notice, girls, it doesn't say supper? There's something queer." A few minutes later the phone rang. It was Tom Senior. "Do you know anything about your mother, Ethel? I was to meet her here when she came from Carrie's and she wasn't on the train."
"She's in town, Dad, at an apartment. We're all going up to dinner—invited for six o'clock."
"What? I'll be right up." Promptly at six o'clock the Morrill family rang the bell of apartment 5. Susan West answered. "Where's Mother?" they asked. "She ain't come yet." Susan threw the door wide, "Come in and make yourself to home. I'm looking for her any time." They looked at each other in amazement. "You working here all the time, Susan?" Mary asked. "Yes, your ma brought me in. I like it fine, too." More amazement. Susan departed to the kitchen. The family surveyed the room.
MOTHER'S "OUTSIDE" INTEREST 593
"It's perfectly charming," Ethel said at last; "done in exquisite taste."
"I'm glad Mother brought my chair in," Tom Senior was already in it. "You can't find a more comfortable piece of furniture than this."
"Thank heaven she left that old one of hers at the farm. I detest it."
"Mom seemed to like it though. Where on earth is she?" Tom voiced the question uppermost in all minds. Mary, after opening all doors and peering restlessly here and there, had sauntered over to the window. "For the love of Mike," she exclaimed. Tom was at her side, "Is that Mother?"
"Good night!" It was too much for Tom. The family all gathered round. A smart little roadster had driven up to the curb, and from it had emerged—Mother. "That can't be your mother, children?"
"Looks like her to me; but, oh boy, what a change!" Mother was coming up the stairs. She let herself in and ran from one to another, embracing her family. They met her in a daze, standing awkwardly—speechless. "Well, my dears, be seated and tell me how you like the apartment." They sat down, their eyes watching her stupidly. "Mother," they all began at once. "Aren't you starved?" she said, "I am. I'll see if dinner is ready." She pulled off her gloves, of soft fine kid, and revealed white well-cared-for hands; her coat, a creation, she removed unaided—both father and son were too confused to offer assistance. Then she removed her smart little toque. An involuntary "Oh!" escaped from the group when they saw her beautiful hair. She laughed, a little tremulously—"I'll see Susan"—and disappeared. "Goodnight—Irene!" It was Tom again who broke the silence. "What is it? What has happened? Isn't she a peach?" Mother came back then and ushered them to the table. Father at length found his voice, "I can't eat a thing, Margaret, till you explain this to us. What have you done?"
"I've gone into business," Mother answered with a calm she was far from feeling, "the wholesale poultry business—and I'm doing well. I'll tell you all about it later. Now let's eat, and afterward I'm treating the crowd to a musical comedy." None of them knew what they ate, they were too busy watching Mother. For the first time she held the reins of the conversation in her hands; she discussed the range with Tom Senior,
594 RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE
school with Mary and Tom, and the babies with Ethel, receiving only half-hearted replies from them all. It was very late that night before any of them retired. Mother had to go over and over her story, while the family made an effort to grasp it. "I've a position waiting for you, Tom, for Saturday and after school," she said; "I believe I can make you into a fairly good buyer, you're a lot like me. The salary won't be much at first, but will help out a little, and you won't be such an expense to your father."
"Bully for you, Mom; what time shall I appear in the morning?"
"And you, Mary, will be expected to take over the entire management of this apartment. I am away so much I can't attend to it properly."
"I'll love it," Mary answered, "It's so pretty and cozy." Then she wandered to her mother's room and started examining clothes. "Mother," she called, "These gowns are marvelous. You must go with me tomorrow to get a party dress. Dad has given me the money. Will you?" Mother smiled happily, "Of course, dear." At last the children were persuaded to retire. As they were leaving, Tom said, "My frat is entertaining the mothers at tea tomorrow, Mom, will you go?" Mother hesitated, "I'm pretty busy—"
"You'll have to come. I've got to show you to the fellows—they'll die of envy." Mother stretched out her silken-clad feet from which she had removed her slippers, and sighed—she was so happy. Tom Senior went over to her, he lifted her in his arms and going back to his own chair held her on his lap. It was the first time since Mary was a baby. Her eyes filled with tears. "Mother," he kept saying, and repeated over and over, "Mother." At last he said, "You've given them both something to do, Mother, are you leaving me out?"
"Oh Tom," she said, as she snuggled in his arms, "I could never leave you out; you're too much a part of me. You'll have to stand behind me in this business. It's going to be very hard sometimes."
"That I will, little woman," Tom answered; and, his masculine pride coming to the front, added, "You need never worry, I'll take care of you." And Mother, her face hid in his coat, smiled.

VOL. XV NOVEMBER, 1928 No. 11
EDITORIAL
The Red Cross to the Fore
The West Indian hurricane that wrought such havoc in Porto Rico and made its way up the Florida coast destroying from 2,500 to 3,500 lives, according to the best figures obtainable and much property, emphasizes once again the value of the Red Cross. The disaster unit of this organization was ready on the instant to go into the field and begin relief work. With great courage some of its members rode forth on a quaking sea and reached the seat of trouble. From them came messages of the extent of the catastrophe as well as an intelligent report on which a budget could be planned for adequate relief. This disaster is surely a most forceful reminder of the necessity for an organized agent being ever in readiness to face the disasters that invariably follow in the wake of these tremendous upheavals of nature that sometimes occur on the sea and sometimes occur on the land. How many lives have been saved, how much suffering averted by this particular sort of "preparedness" nobody can estimate, but that the salvage of life has been great surely none will deny.
It would be to the everlasting disgrace of a nation terming itself Christian if after two thousand years of the teachings of the blessed Master some organization did not come into being that
596 RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE
could in a measure cope with the exigencies of such untoward situations as follow tidal waves, earthquakes, cyclones and the like. It is a most appropriate thing that the cross symbolizing all the mercy of the Christ should enter into the name of this organization—an organization that all people, irrespective of race, color, religion or social standing must call blessed. Reverently we think of it; reverently we write of it. May its power for good increase in every land and clime on which the sun shines and the moon breathes forth a benediction. Utah Stake Observes Fiftieth Anniversary Not long ago in the city of Ogden the fiftieth anniversary of the organization of the Weber Stake Relief Society was observed. Following that came the beautiful pageant in the Tabernacle, which heralded the news that the ten stakes of Salt Lake City and Salt Lake county were harking back fifty years to the time when the original Salt Lake Stake was organized. On the 27th day of September, 1928, the Utah Stake Relief Society, in a fitting program, observed the date of its fiftieth anniversary. There were on the stand four women responsible at one period and another for leadership in the stake. These women were Mrs. Martha A. F. Keeler, Mrs. Inez Knight Allen, Mrs. Electa Smoot Dixon, and Mrs. Achsa E. Paxman. Mrs. Paxman is the present incumbent. An outstanding feature of the celebration was a representation in pageantry of the women of Utah Stake who were ward presidents before the stake was organized. This feature of the program was carried over by women of the Society, many of whom were relatives of the ward presidents they represented. They were gowned in the fashions of that past period. For instance, Mrs. Grace Cheever, who represented Lucy Smith, wore a costume that was her own mother's, thus reviving the dress in vogue half a century ago. Professor J. M. Jensen wrote some verses characterizing the life and labors of these first presidents. The verses were read to musical accompaniment by Miss Elaine Paxman, daughter of the president. A feature of the gathering was the assembling of persons who had worked in the Relief Society fifty years ago. The history of the organization was presented by Virgie C. Murdock, counselor to President Achsa E. Paxman. A solo, Mother Machree, by Mrs. Allie Webb Clark, was electrifying to the audience. Flowers were presented to past presidents of stakes and to the members of the General Board who were there. The celebration was featured by two events, the presentation of a silver watch to Electa Smoot Dixon in recognition of her devotion during her term of office and the report by President T. N. Taylor of the opening of a box which was owned by the Relief Society and marked to be opened in fifty years. The box contained the photographs and EDITORIAL 597 pamphlets and papers that had to do in the main with the Third Ward Relief Society. Counselor Jennie B. Knight, Mrs, Inez Knight Allen, and Miss Alice L. Reynolds represented the General Board at the gathering. Our Educational World October sees practically every American college in full swing. Nobody whose opinion is valued pretends to doubt that education is a very important business and that it is becoming increasingly more important as the world advances. Crowded colleges of late have been a matter of much pubiic comment and much private distress to heads of institutions compelled to take care of thousands of young people. Yet it will undoubtedly be a surprise to many people to learn that one-fourth of the people in the United States are engaged in either getting or giving education. Education bids fair to be the nation's biggest business. That it will be, in time, is inevitable. Fortunately we have not carried through all of the problems that were known when the world was young; some have been solved. Constantly an ever-advancing world has brought to us problems unknown to the infant world with its primitive civilization. The problems of a higly specialized civilization can be met only by increasing knowledge; and it is for this purpose that colleges are established, extension courses offered, correspondence schools organized; for it is necessary that light and knowledge shall reach into remote places. No helpful changes, no matter how desirable they may be, can be brought about unless the masses as well as the classes are well informed. While we were in Paris in 1925 we saw on several occasions youths and maidens passing the Pasteur Institute with long loaves of bread under their arms unwrapped, exposed to all the dust of the street. In America today there is scarcely a hamlet that is so out of step with progress that it does not have bread wrapped in paper properly waxed or oiled. It is of little value to France that one of the ablest of her men should have added materially to the germ theory of diseases, if the people go on from decade to decade exposing their bread to all the dirt of a modern city street. The difficulty with France is not that there is a lack of intelligence in upper circles; the difficulty lies in the fact that she does not get her story of scientific achievement with its application over to the people at large. The possession of knowledge by the few does not turn the trick. The Relief Society through its educational program and its social work is helping to spread material that will enable its members to be in the ranks of the great army of progress that is daily rising on stepping stones of its dead self to higher things. Why Make a Budget? Jean Cox The homemaker who said to the automobile salesman, "We haven't made a budget yet, so are not ready to investigate any automobiles," had the right standard for financial success in the home. This home, by the way, represented a close partnership, as the wife felt some definite responsibility in helping to meet necessary payments on land, machinery, new home and furnishing. Her responsibility as a member of the firm extended to personal expenditures as well, since she was just as careful of what she spent as if she were entirely responsible for meeting the bills and notes necessary for an expanding farm business. The Home-Maker's View It may be interesting to note that this homemaker had earned money for several years before her marriage and knew not only the value of money but also the importance of accounts and budgets before her salary check became past history. Her own financial independence had convinced her that money has only a limited purchasing power, and her experience had convinced her that if the dollars are used to satisfy one want another desire will go unsatisfied. In her home, limited by conditions imposed by a new country, this wife and mother continued to spend the income so as to satisfy the greatest possible number of family needs. Success in satisfying needs is largely dependent upon careful planning. It is said that the woman of yesterday thought and thought and then spent, while the woman of today spends and spends and then thinks and thinks. Giving thought as to how to spend after the purchase is made is parallel to locking the gate after the horse is gone. Neither worry nor regrets will make money available for the comforts that should have been purchased with the part of the family check frittered away with large and small extravagances. Attempts to justify this kind of spending frequently accompany the off-hand remark, "I should worry; Dad has to pay the bills." This is, to say the least, characterless conversation. What is a Budget? One of the big reasons why the average person does not radiate much enthusiasm for budgets is due largely to the fact that the term budgets and accounts are used interchangeably. WHY MAKE A BUDGET? 599 Accounts are only records of expenditure, they are memorandums of expense, but budgets are like the blue prints of a building; they are the plan ahead of time for spending the income. Making a budget is merely a device for thinking out the division of the income so as to obtain major satisfactions and pleasures. It helps to divide the weekly, monthly or yearly income so as to cover the needs of the individual and family. Another reason why budgets are apt to be in disfavor is due to the fact that the budget cannot be imposed upon the family or individual. When this is attempted vexation results. A plan ahead of time for spending your money is necessarily different from the division best suited to the needs of your neighbors. The right division for the individual family is only possible when it is based on actual record of expenditures. With this record at hand, careful analysis is necessary in order to determine what expenditures are to be definitely classified as Must Haves or May Haves. How Budgets Must Differ Miss A., in her bachelor quarters, spends more than the ordinary fifth of her salary for rent, but she is convinced that in order to be reasonably happy and comfortable she must have the apartment rather than a room. In order to keep within her living expense allowance, she spends less for food because she prepares a part of her meals in the small kitchenette and also does her personal laundry. Miss B. Has only a room at less cost than Miss A's apartment, but necessarily spends more for food and running expense than Miss A. They both receive the same salary and are able to make practically the same investment saving each month. Each one is spending in accordance with the plan she has worked out, in order that they may have peace of mind in their living arrangements. Budget specialists, in banks and investment hvuses, have worked out different devices to help their patrons decide whether or not it is possible to make readjustments of their opinions as to how many wants they must or may satisfy on their income. Determining the best expenditure of funds is dependent upon judgment. As a device for determining between essentials and non-essentials, it may be wise to list the "must haves" in one column and the "may haves" in another and then divide the income proportionately between the two. MustHaves and May-Haves Miss Agnes Donham, special lecturer and writer on household budgets, divides family and personal expenditures into two big classes—Must Haves and May Haves. The must haves deal 600 RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE with stern reality such as minimum essentials in shelter, food, ciothing and running expenses and advancement on the same income. Different families have different standards as to minimum requirements for health and happiness. The Jones', for instance, feel that considerable sacrifice is commendable in order that the Jones' children may have the opportunities afforded by a better neighborhood than the ordinary budget division allows for rent. The Browns, in contrast to their old friends the Jones', are anxious to trim their expenses for shelter and chothes and incidentals in order that William Jr. May have opportunity for musical education. The following Budget Wheel worked out by Miss Donham is a good device to help analyze and classify expenditures. Where the income is low, more than a fifth of the income is spent for food. This extra amount is usually taken out of the fifth allotted to development and clothing. The housekeeper anxious to spend wisely should be interested in keeping accounts and then classifying expenditures according to the division suggested: WHY MAKE A BUDGET? 601

There is good psychology in the emphasis given savings in this budget wheel. The time is past when to save what isn't spent for others things is sufficient. Purposeful savings must be planned for and the amount must be taken out before expenditures are made. In the more recent books on household accounts the arrangement of columns differs from that of the earlier household account books.
