Representative of Needs One of the biggest arguments for systematic household accounts and budgets lies in their value in character training for the younger members of the family. Children should be taught appreciation of what is done for them by their parents. This should help them to understand what they cost their parents in terms of dollars and cents. Frequently, unruly boys and girls have never been made acquainted with the amount of income the family has available for its needs, and only where there is understanding among all of the members of the family does the budget become a family budget, representative of the needs of the different members of the group. Unlimited and uncontrolled spending is not conducive to good morale in the home. Let the carefully worked out Children Number in family 602 RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE budget determine the amount of spending money each member of the group should request. Stabilizes the Family Budget planning gives stability to the family. Social workers find that 9/10 of the broken families break down on the financial rocks. One well known attorney says that 95% of divorces are directly or indirectly dependent upon questions of family finance. Much of this failure in homemaking is due to the fact that either one or both of the contracting parties have either failed to think or failed to face financial facts that needed careful consideration. Careless thinking in terms of income and outgo result in the accumulation of more bills than available funds can pay. The result usually is financial disaster, unhappiness, loss of confidence and legal separation. A budget helps you to know how you are using your life. Record of plans for and expenditure of your funds help to tell the kind of a person you really are. Comparatively few people have had the opportunity of buying all that they desired. Very few of those who have achieved have been able to develop in their chosen field, without sacrifice and careful planning. If your expenditures show many expenditures that mean little or nothing in lasting satisfaction, it is possible that your present living is not purposeful and worth while. To Think in Terms of Budgets It takes considerable discussion to help people think in terms of budgets. Budget experts are often of the same opinion as the old darkey who says: "T tell 'em what I'm going to tell, I tells 'em and den I tells 'em what I've done tole 'em!" Many people get the idea that accounts and budgets are merely devices for saving. That is not the case. The economist does not stand for pessimistic saving, for life is not made for saving. People who have only money enough to get along with should not be asked to save. The thought behind the saving is to make life more abundant. The idea of planning before spending is to help people live up to better ideals for deferred purchasing power means more abundant life. Working to save and saving to live more completely represent two definite ideals. Consider Relative Values Another use of the budget idea is to show the relationship between income, house value and furnishing. Where the income is WHY MAKE A BUDGET? 603 $3,600 a year a fifth of it may be spent for shelter which should include heat, taxes and depreciation as well. The value of the home is partly determined by its actual renting value. An apartment, for instance, rents theoretically for 10% of its total value. A person living in an apartment where rent is $75 a month is living in the equivalent of a house valued at about $7,000. Few people have any idea of the total value of their house furnishings. This, of course, is difficult because different articles need more frequent replacement than others. Then, too, hangings and furnishings are sometimes disposed of before they are really worn out. Even with these difficulties the average family should know approximately how much their furnishings are worth. If you queston this, make an estimate as to the value of your furnishings, then sit down and list the furnishings you have in each room. The next step is to try to duplicate at a furniture store or a second hand store what you have in your home. Probably considerable surprise will result from the grand total. The question of "How much should be spent for furnishings?" should be carefully considered. Home economists who have made a careful study of this feel that not more than 25% of the house cost should be spent for the furnishing of the home. This percentage should be taken into consideration in planning a home for the total investment of the house, lot and furnishing should not be more according to Dr. Andrews than the family income for three years. The Family on Economic Bases Is your family on a staple economic basis? What determines economic stability? Does spending money for auto, theatres, new house, expensive furnishing, elaborate clothing, travel, etc., give assurance of certain financial freedom? This freedom is short lived, however, if there isn't proportionate savings and reinvestment for the rainy day ahead. If the income is sufficient to warrant expenditures for Iuxuries then some savings are necessary, if the plan for spending is approved by budget specialists. Dr. Benjamin R. Andrews thinks that the family ambitious for an auto should have an equal amount in the savings bank for a rainy day. The most accepted reasons for saving are the emergency, dependence of old age, care of dependents, building a home and education of the younger members of the family. The most generally accepted views for living within a budget are to live more completely, to be safeguarded from financial disaster, to live harmoniously with the other members of the group. Marilie's Ghost By Helen Kimball Orgill There are ghosts; but the one which haunted Marilie was different from the ordinary run of them. Hers was the ghost of a story that wanted to be written. The Alden family came from Boston to Alberta. The mother and father had engaged in pedagogical and other educational pursuits; but one day a newspaper article had attracted them, depicting the wonderful opportunities of the Northwest. A spirit of adventure seized both parents. What could be more thrilling than the prospect of owning acres of rich prairie land, acres which could be made to yield a bounteous living? In addition would there not come renewal of health and strength? So they went, selling all possessions which could not be taken. It was a far cry from teaching school in Boston to homesteading in western Canada. Years of disillusionment followed. They both pined for the cozy comforts of the old home. True, health and strength had come to them, as well as the children; but they wearied of the unceasing struggle incident to life in the rigorous North. It had been fine as long as the novelty lasted; but now, feeling unable to overcome the longings for the old home conditions, they once more disposed of their belongings, sold the land to which they now held title, and went back. But in the meantime Marilie, eldest of. Three daughters, had met big, handsome Jim Graham. Besides, youth is more easily transplanted; so she had no desire to follow the rest of her family. Jim weaved wondrous romance as he gazed across the wide stretches of rolling hills. How he loved the prairie, with its sunny skies, invigorating climate and green grass. All that was needed to make his prospects perfect was the addition of Marilie to grace his humble abode. She in turn absorbed some of his enthusiasm. So they were married, with the future looming brightly with rose-hued dreams. With foresight they planted many trees, building always with an eye for the future. Then came Betty, the wonderful first child, followed by the boy, Danny. There was indeed something to work for now. In the meantime there was a gradual stirring in Marilie's being. During her high school days, Marilie had shown undoubted literary ability. Her composition work had called forth unstinted praise from the instructors, MARILIE'S GHOST 605 "There is no literary height you may not attain to," one enthusiastic professor had declared. With the passing of the years that followed, these words were almost forgotten. The days and months seemed so crowded with matters very foreign to a literary life. But in her young married life, with the two children to care for, strangely enough, ambition was reborn, and with it a sense of guilt for neglecting a God-given talent. There were tremors in her very soul as glimmerings of this power, this ability to write, was making itself felt. And all nature, as viewed from her eyes, took on a cloak of beauty. Before, she would rush to the spring for water, and only thoughts of the work in hand came to her. Now she invariably paused as different shades of vegetation met her gaze. The aromatic odor of bergamot and various herbs soothed her senses as poetic phrases rushed to her brain. After such experiences there was nearly always something burning or boiling over on the stove, or perhaps dinner was late. In a word, something seemed to go wrong about the house. Marilie began to glimpse the struggle ahead. At any cost, Jim and the children must not be neglected; on the other hand, she was determined to cling to a career of writing. One task must not suffer at the expense of the other. But her own strength and ability to follow this straight line had not been figured on. Story writing is very engrossing, and a pioneer life anywhere | is a continual struggle. A gradual slighting of her home was the inevitable result. It showed itself first in the untidy appearance of the children. Jim was often annoyed by missing buttons. The house work no longer went like a clock. Jim was unusually patient, realizing the sacrifice Marilie had made in marrying him. The true nature of existing conditions dawned upon her one day, as Betty was coming to the house with her father. The window was up and she glanced out through the curtain in time to hear Betty remark, “Mother's been writing again." The father placed an arm about her shoulders as he answered, "My poor little girl." Marilie felt the blood rush to her temples. It was not so much what was said as the idea that they were suffering together, sympathizing together, while she was the cause of it all, and, therefore, not included. So, came the determination to give up all thoughts of a career. But as time went on, this well-meant resolve weakened, and she found herself trying to eke out spare moments in which to set down the ideas which continued to fill her consciousness. It was early in the spring, too early for any work to be done on the land. Jim and some neighbors were planning to hunt for 606 RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE some of their stray horses. It would mean two or three days absence at least. A te Marilie knew that here was an opportunity to go to her beloved writing. Besides a few chores to do nights and mornings, there was nothing rushing. Betty and Danny had built a play house of cobble rocks in the coulee near by, and when the weather was favorable, spent much of their time there. They had chosen a dry 'place, but a considerable amount of mud almost surrounded it. Marilie felt elated. She would write that story now with no fear of a disturbance. For months it had loomed up like a spectre, staring at her from all angles. What a relief it would be to get it safely on paper, if only to rest in the bottom of her trunk. Soon the story was being formed into written words, phrases, and sentences. They fairly leaped from her pencil point. Marilie almost wondered where they came from—surely not from her brain. Of course not; she was merely a medium, whereby a masterpiece was brought into being. Exultingly she wrote on and on, regardless of time. When her note book was full, she reached up on the shelf for some brown wrapping paper and continued. Her pencil broke, and not deigning to lose time, she tore the wood away from the lead with her fingers. After a time Betty came in.' "Mother." No answer. ) "Mother, listen. Danny won't keep. His sunfens on, His feet are getting wet." Marilie looked in her little girl's direction, then went on writing. Betty went out, but soon came in again. "Mother, his feet are sopping wet." Still no answer; so she went back to play. A half hour later, the story was completed. She placed it in the bottom of her trunk, then gazed defiantly across the room. She challenged her ghost. Immediately afterwards, a brooding sense of something gone wrong overshadowed her. Where were the children? There was a faint memory of Betty's coming in, but what Betty wanted she could not remember. Starting down the road she met them, Danny holding Betty's hand. She sighed with momentary relief. Betty pointed down at her brother's feet. "Danny, Danny," cried the mother. "You wouldn't listen to me," accused the sister. Marilie shot her a comprehending gaze, but said nothing. Had not Danny been the "croupy kind" all might have been well. As it was, his mother knew what to expect. Hurriedly she and Betty made preparations to get him into MARILIE'S GHOST 607 a warm bed. But before this was accomplished, the tell-tale cough was heard. Before night had set in, Marilie felt inadequate to the occasion. Never had an attack been so intense. Betty offered to ride the pony over to Belmont's ranch and zet someone to go for the doctor; but a snow storm came up, increasing in its fury as the evening wore on. So the mother knew the fight must be made alone. ' Valiantly the little girl stayed by her mother's side until persuaded to go to bed. One by one the remedies were tried out. The croup simply would not loosen. How she prayed as she worked! "Of course, it's all mv own fault," she moaned. With the first signs of breaking day, her prayers were answered. 'The poor, little, nearly strangled fellow breathed more easily, and Marilie sensed that intense joy which verges on pain. In the morning she felt like a reborn person; and the tormenting ghost, like an emissary of satan, knew when he had been worsted, and did not return. The next few years bore record of a mother's faithful devotion in the Graham household. Prosperity came in time, and two girls and another boy were added to the happy family. Frugality becomes a life-time habit, if kept up for a number of years. Betty had finished high school before a trip back to her Boston home was contemplated by Marilie. It was finally decided that she should go unaccompanied by her husband, but should take the youngest boy. Betty agreed to keep house for the summer, taking Mother' S place to the best of her ability. So for a month and a half, Marilie enjoyed the dear companionship of her now aging parents and old friends. At the end of this time, she was loath to leave; but her own hearthstone was calling, and she felt that she must go, even though all letters received reiterated the statement that all was well. So she and little Bud again found themselves in a comfortable Pullman, once more bound for home. At the little Canadian station Jim was impatiently awaiting the arrival of his wife and son. When they rounded the last hill which brought the farm buildings into view, the sun was just slipping out of sight over the western horizon. How good it seemed to be back! At sight of the familiar place an exclamation escaped Marilie's lips. "O, you've painted things up; and if I don't declare, you've built an addition to the house. "Yes; thought we'd get it done while you were away," he tried to say it in a matter-of-fact way. Marilie was plainly puzzled that it had all been done with no 608 RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE helpful planning from her; but Jim would offer no further explanation. Whole-heartedly the children welcomed her. After greetings were over, there was an expectant pause and Danny spoke, "Let's show her what we've done." She was ushered into a modernly appointed sitting room and library combined. Somewhat bewildered, Marilie looked from one to another of her family. "You see, Mother,' Betty was explaining, "we all know and realize how you've sacrificed your girlhood dreams so that we might be properly cared for. We appreciate it; and after talking 't all over, Daddy suggested that we fit up this room for your own private study, and we're to see that you have all the time you want to enjoy it and none can enter without your consent." Deeply moved at this symbol of their gratitude, Marilie could not speak for a moment.  "Eas it come too late, Mother?" queried Betty, mistaking the silence. "Why, bless you, no, my darlings." She was smiling happily. "Maybe I'll have something worth while to write about now I've really lived." Later, when the children were in bed and Jim had gone for a last nightly look around the stables, Marilie passed over to one of the windows in her study and stood gazing out at the flickering shadows of her prairie home. She was thinking, thinking espe- "Tas it come too late, Mother?" Marilie knew that it really had come too late. All down the years her very heart's blood had been given unstintingly for these she loved. It had been give, give, give. She had lived on an intellectual plane with them instead of growing mentally, as_she had fully intended when the writing had been given up. Day by day, with no serious thought independent of their welfare, she had watched these young strangers growing up around her. Continually she excused herself for reading recreatively rather than educationally. Some time, some time, I'll study, she had promised herself. But always she was so busy; and when a few moments were snatched from the day's routine, it seemed so much more restful to read some light story, which would carry her away on wings from the usual happenings of her existence. Now she felt spent, just a littie weary. The fires of youthful ambition were burning low. Could the loss be made up? She knew, within her heart of hearts, that as her life had been spent in giving so manifoldly, she had received in return something far more precious. What it was she couldn't say; but, anyway, it had enriched her being, making it finer than it otherwise would MARILIE'S GHOST 609 have been. Selfishness had no place in her make-up. Perhaps this accounted for the purity of her soul. No creative work on earth can be compared or purposely substituted for motherhood, no matter how opinions may differ on the question. And so, with a thankful heart, Marilie decided that all was as it should be, and knew that, under such conditions, the purest of inspiration would aid her in all future attempts at a literary career. Gratitude By Julia Collard Baker My dreams once held a swelling germ, of high ambitious flight; And worldly Cynics smiled to note that kindling burst of light. When whisked away by atheist's sneer, Faith made me understand. That reaching upward I could hold that flame within my hand. A flower I tended, watered, nursed, ah deep the joy that thrilled me; Uprooted by the storms of night, memory and longing filled me With hope of June, with perfume of the rose that blushed, Shine of the sun that spoke to me, of winter winds now hushed. A little singing bird I found of plumage strangely fair; I pressed it close against my heart, with none its song would share: Till gladdest music from its throat swelled out upon the air And little children caught the song to heart, and held it there. A child was laid upon my breast, on her with generous dower Was lavished Faith, the wild rose's bloom, the Songster's magic power., That radiant life was called above, by Heavenly mandate wise, Which bade me rise and claim the light of service and sacrifice. This day a rapture stirs my soul, nor from it would I flee— The flame of hope, the wild rose scent, song of a bird in glee. Dear God, I thank Thee for the right to Faith, and hope, and light, And memory of the life that sleeps in peace within Thy sight. Pioneers By Lais V. Hales "One Man's Life"—-HERBERT QUICK On the tenth of May, 1925, Herbert Quick, the great novelist of the Middle West, died suddenly. Only a few days before his death he had arranged with "The Saturday Evening Post' to publish in installments his autobiography entitled "One Man's Life." This autobiography has since been published in book form and is a lasting monument to the pioneer life of Iowa. It was begun on the author's sixty-third birthday and tells the story of pioneer days in Iowa as seen by a small boy, a farmer, a teacher, a lawyer, an editor, and a novelist, all of which Mr. Quick successively became during his lifetime. Early in the Spring of 1857 his parents set out for a new and different world. They turned toward the west and soon gazed with dazzled eyes "sheltered under the cupped hands of toil, out over a vast sea of grassy hillocks." These limitless, treeless wastes were the feared and loved prairies of Iowa and it was here that Mr. Quick was born and lived. He lived with the prairie in all her different moods. He saw it struggle with fierce storms, watched the plow destroy it, helped destroy its winding trails, and finally saw it conquered by the great steel engines. This prairie land which was like nothing else in the whole wide world, he came to love. He fished in its small, clear pools fringed by tall grasses. He came to know intimately its animal and vegetable life. Many times he witnessed the great prairie fires in all their terror and beauty and exulted in the new green life that sprang up soon after the fire was gone. He saw this prairie an unending sheet of snow in winter and knew of the great cold waves and blizzards which swept over it, freezing people to death in their beds and destroying their livestock. He watched the unbroken sky-line and clear pools disappear and tall groves of trees, plowed fields, farmsteads, and towns take their place and he felt that a thing of great wonder and beauty was passing away forever. This Iowa prairie Mr. Quick has preserved faithfully and sympathetically for us in his autobiography. He has honestly pictured it as it appeared to our weary pioneers as they looked out over its limitless stretch and thought of the homes they had left. About Mr. Quick's prairie there is beauty, mystery, cruelty, and wonder. Almost classic is Mr. Quick's description of the "chronicle of the wheat," a thing always so intimately connected with the life of the pioneer. For many years, after the first honk of the wild geese in spring, he helped clean and sow the seed wheat. He watched the sprouting of the seed, the young shoots looking like "the points of bright green nails driven up from PIONEERS 611 below." He saw the wheat grow to maturity and helped to harvest it. Over it all he many times shed tears of pure delight. But a time came when it no longer stood clean and green in the field. Now it was spotted and black with rust. The poetry was all gone out of it. And he watched the farmer, in his ignorance and helplessness, sow the sick wheat year after year, reaping no harvest, until he had spread the disease far and wide over the fertile ground. Not until years later did he see fields of waving corn where the wheat had once stood in all its glory. How well has Mr. Quick expressed the '"'weariness" of the home-loving pioneer woman with but one desire—that of a roof over her head. The meagreness of her life, her delight in small pleasures he sympathetically shows us. In this age of books and magazines almost to the point of satiety, it is difficult for us to understand the time the pioneer woman spent in solitude—mental solitude. This tragic phase of pioneer life Mr. Quick witnessed in his mother and the women with whom she associated. As we read the book we feel the delight that its author derived from writing it. His fine, cheerful personality colors every sentence, Even his tragic youth, marred by infantile paralysis, from which he never wholly recovered, he cheerfully recalls. There is about the book the wholesomeness of the prairie where he lived and worked out his life. He was warmly interested in anything which touched the pioneer and he tells us of their lives in a very companionable honest way. We feel his utter honesty and sympathy with his subject and know that we can here find an authentic description of the early life of Iowa. He has preserved in "One Man's Life" for all time something very fine which has passed away forever.

Notes from the Field By Amy Brown Lyman
Cache and Logan Stakes. Cache and Logan stakes joined in decorating a float, called "The Desert Blossomed as the Rose," which won first prize in a parade held in Logan, on July 24. The float contained over fifteen thousand sweet peas, fifteen dozen gladioli, eight dozen blue delphinium, $10 worth of moss, and hundreds of yellow and lavender flowers. Only fresh flowers and greenery were used.

Summer Outings for Children. Through the cooperation of the General Board with a number of stake Relief Societies and with other organizations, seventy-one children from Salt Lake City, needing fresh air and sunshine and good food, were given an opportunity to spend some time in
614 RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE
the country during the summer school vacation. Sixteen children went to North Davis stake, twenty-five to Franklin and Oneida stakes, eight to Kolob stake, and four to South Davis stake. SUMMER ACTIVITIES:
Juarez Stake. The Relief Society women of Juarez stake were greatly favored during the summer by attending a course of special lectures given under the auspices of the stake for class teachers, by Dr. Amos N. Merrill of the Brigham Young University, Provo, Utah. Among the subjects discussed were "The Relief Society, Its Place and Function in the Church," "The Role of Women in the March of Human Progress," and "Methods of Attacking Local Problems."
North Davis Stake. Among the topics discussed in the ward conferences which were held during the summer in North Davis stake were the following: "What does it mean to sustain a ward officer?" "What the Relief Society does for its Members," "What is Relief Work?" and "How do the Ward Relief Societies Cooperate with the Bishopric in Relief Work?"
Carbon Stake. The Carbon stake has conducted a campaign during the summer among the various wards in the interest of civic pride, the slogan being "Beautify Back Yards." Castle Gate ward received the cash prize for having conducted the most effective campaign. The members of the stake board were hostesses to the class leaders and executive officers of the fourteen wards of the stake at the annual convention held in the tabernacle at Price, Utah, on August 28. A luncheon and exhibit of needlework, fruits, vegetables and flowers were held in connection with the convention.
Bear River Stake. The Bear River stake held a semi-centennial review during the summer, which was adapted by Mrs. Della Marriott from the Relief Society Review, (written by Claire Stewart Boyer and presented by the Salt Lake county stakes last April) for the celebration, making a complete history of the Relief Society work in Box Elder, Malad and Bear River stakes. The Bear River stake grew out of the Box Elder and Malad stakes, which joined with

the Bear River stake in celebrating the semi-centennial. The review also included the history of the Lamanite Relief Society at Washakie. In connection with the class leaders' convention which was held early in September, an exhibition of summer work and a flower display were held.

The Big Horn stake board met in May and outlined the following summer program which was used successfully by the wards during the summer: July 3, Testimony, subject, Temple Work; July 10, Pioneer Days in the Big Horn; July 17, Better Films; July 24, Folk songs and dances; July 31, One-Act Play; August 7, Testimony, subject, the M. I. A. Slogan; August 14, Art in the Home; August 21, Open-Air Social, the Priesthood as guests; August 28, One-Act Play; September 4, Testimony, subject Signs of the Times; September 11, Sketches of Lives of Political Candidates; September 18, Demonstration of Table and Food Decorations; September 25, One-Act Play.
For the year 1927, the attendance of the Big Horn stake Relief Society at regular meetings was about 8% below the general average of the Relief Societies of the Church. In order to raise the standard, an attendance contest was arranged between the wards to be on the percentage basis. It was agreed that at the end of the year the winning ward should be entertained by the ward having the lowest average. To date, the attendance has increased over 17%. Records are being sent to the wards listing their standing in the stake in attendance at regular meetings, at officers' and prayer meetings, the percentage of teachers' visits made and the general activities each month. This is a splendid way of checking up and has kept up the interest in the contest.
In April, Miss Elsie Witchen, a representative of the United States Children's Bureau, gave a series of lectures in Big Horn County, followed up by children's clinics, the Relief Societies cooperating. The clinics were held in four different towns, examining two hundred eighty-five children. Of this number twenty-one had rickets; one hundred sixteen were under weight and two hundred thirty-seven defective. It was something of a shock to find so many physical defects, and steps have already been taken to overcome this condition. Seven flower shows have been held in the stake during the summer, showing the increased interest in careful planting, selection and display of flowers, and greater abundance. The aim next year is a shrub for every family. During the month of September, class leaders and teachers conventions were held. The stake was divided into two groups for these conventions, one group meeting at Burlington and one at Lovell.
Guide Lessons for January
LESSON I (First Week in January)
THE NEW COURSE
A number of appeals have been made from the field to have the course of study begin after the summer vacation. As a result the executive committee took the matter under advisement and decided to outline a course for six months beginning in January and ending in June, the course for the following year to begin in October when work resumes after the summer vacation. The three courses presented will be: first, one in practical religion; secondly, one in modern drama and, thirdly, a continuation of the lessons in social service. The course in practical religion will consist of lessons on the following subjects: conscience, purity, honesty, temperance, industry, loyalty. The course in literature will consist of six modern plays, each emphasizing a social problem of a nature that we trust will be interesting to Relief Society members. These dramas are: Nowadays, by George Middleton; The Devil's Disciple, by George Bernard Shaw; He and She, by Rachel Crothers; What Every Woman Knows, by James Matthew Barrie; Joseph and His Brethren, by Louis N. Parker; and The Doll's House, by Henrik Ibsen. The social service lessons, which during the past year have been devoted to a course in child-study, will resume lessons on the same subject. The books containing the dramas will be for sale at the Deseret Book Company, 44 East South Temple Street, Salt Lake City, Utah. A price list will be published by the magazine, as soon as the books are received by the Deseret Book Company.
EVERY DAY ETHICS AND PRACTICAL RELIGION AND TESTIMONY
A series of six lessons will be presented under this title. The major objective of the lessons as a whole is to increase an interest in a thoughtful search for the right, in a judicious choice of the right, and in acting right for the love of right itself as well as for the love of others and ourselves. At the same time we shall keep in view the fact that as the mariner's compass must constantly be adjusted by observa-
GUIDE LESSONS FOR JANUARY 617
tions of the upper deep, so human standards of conduct must be tested by divine standards of righteousness. Ethics and theology must be pursued as separate studies, one dealing with doctrines and creeds and the other dealing with codes of conduct; but in life each becomes the complement of the other, one emphasizing duty to God, and the other placing emphasis on duty to humanity. When Joseph the Egyptian slave plead for purity he made his plea in the name of ethics (faithfulness to his master), and in the name of religion (faithfulness to his God.) Gen. 39:9. The Decalogue begins with Theology and ends with Ethics. The Sermon on the Mount combines theology and ethics, making of two laws one complete law providing for the salvation of man. The love of God and the love of man, operating together, create a condition productive of eternal life. The first of the thirteen articles of our faith is purely theological; the last one is sweepingly ethical. Through skepticism and arrogance a person may be led to deny the existence of God; but nothing short of depravity or despair can bring one to a denial of the existence of goodness.
CONSCIENCE
Conscience is our ethical judgment resulting from our knowledge, our mental certainty as to what is right and what is wrong. The race-conscience was born in the Garden of Eden. Its birthday was the date of the fall; up to that time it could consistently be said of the human family, consisting of one couple, as it can still be said of every child, that it is neither moral nor immoral; it is merely non-moral, having no knowledge of good and evil from which to make moral judgment; it is innocent, though not necessarily harmless. Ethical experience brought into existence a moral responsibility which has increased just to the extent that the light of moral truth has been reflected on the mind of mankind; always and ever bright in spots and dim in places. In the main, the difference between the conscience of a cruel race of savages and the conscience of a kind and cultured people is a difference in moral intelligence. Crime is evidence of moral decay; habitual criminals, no matter how physically perfect and intellectually strong they may be, are moral cripples, and the danger of trusting each to carry loads of ethical responsibility becomes at once apparent. Since the conscience of the individual, in its birth and development, follows the course of the race conscience, it is governed by the same laws.
618 RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE
We shall consider seven of the laws governing the conscience. And this examination may help in the every day living of a life that is full of material for character growth, the highest aim of learning.
1. Personal Interest Clouds Conscience: Nations are loath to sign a compact, much less to give a bond, that they will not justify in themselves what they condemn in others. It is quite impossible for parents to see the faults of their own children as clearly as they see the faults of the children of their neighbors. Not many guests can see the hypocrisy of a host as clearly as did Jesus at the feast given by the Pharisee. Even in our dealings with the Lord our ethical vision is sometimes dimmed by the dust of dollars. The "conscientious" payment of tithing might be modified by putting it to the test recommended by Elder James E. Talmage at a general conference. The suggestion was to this effect: Calculate our income to be tithed as though we were going to receive a ten per cent dividend on it at the tithing office. In ethics this personal interest is called bias, and this law governing the influence of self interest is sometimes stated thus: Bias bends moral judgment.
2. Prejudice Pushes Conscience. "Away with the Indian." "The only good Indians are dead ones." These expressions indicate the state of mind that would precede the conscientious persecution and even the killing of the red man. Here the ethical judgment is pushed from an upright attitude by what is known as prejudice, or pre-judgment. A recognition of this law of conscience has led to an almost excessive demand concerning the qualifications of jurors. The formation of an opinion or pre-judgment on the case disqualifies a person as a juror. When Jesus said, "Judge not," he warned against prejudice. And when he declared that men would kill his disciples and think they were doing God's service, he evidently had in mind the power of prejudice in pushing the conscience to a low level.
3. Indulgence Enervates Conscience. Few men are more often quoted than Pope, and few of his statements are more frequently repeated than the following:
"Vice is a monster of so frightful mien As to be hated, needs but to be seen; Yet seen too oft, familiar with her face, We first endure, then pity, then embrace."
GUIDE LESSONS FOR JANUARY 619
Indulgence is any form of vice; it is to the conscience what hacking on a rock is to a keen knife blade; it dulls if it does not ruin.
4. Custom Controls Conscience. As a rule it is considered right to do what everybody is doing; and sooner or later, with rare exceptions, the conscience of the individual conforms to the conscience of the group whether it be in matters of fashion, business, religion, or recreation. Individual ideality is always affected consciously or unconsciously by the quality of the ideals held up by popular sentiment and community conduct. The problem of keeping the good individual conscience from being swallowed up by a bad community conscience brings us to another law of conscience.
5. Law Lifts Conscience. Law as a rule is the crystallization of the ideality of the best members of society. Law represents ideas as well as emotions. It is the product of deliberation as well as of desires. It calls for a conscience that cuts and cuts deeply when wrong attempts to invade the sacred citadel of right. The Greeks were wont to say: "Hitch your chariots to the stars and let the Gods pull you." We may consistently say: "Fasten your conduct to the law and let the right lift you." When we speak of law we mean good law, law tested by the affirmative answer to the question: Will the world be made better by this law being obeyed.
6. Education Elevates the Conscience. The culture of conscience leads to a condition where wrong-doing is accompanied with so much mental pain that evil will not be indulged in, a condition in which the doing of right will be accompanied with so much pleasure that it dominates our desires and absorbs our efforts. It has been said, "Where ignorance is bliss, it is folly to be wise." In the light of our theology we are committed to saying; ethically, "Where there is opportunity to learn, it is unethical to be ignorant; where a cultivated conscience is attainable, it is wrong to have a crude one." The trustworthiness of conscience depends upon the information behind it. Conscience is one's best guide; but that "best" may be very poor. Conscience must be followed, but it is not infallible; our inner right may be an outer wrong. Our moral judgment should be questioned always when it conflicts with recognized superior intelligence or authority. How quickly Saul questioned his ethical judgment when he
620 RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE
found who Jesus was. With him then it was, not what his conscience would have him do but what Jesus would have him do. If children should be trained in the intelligent revision of conscience to make it fit in with parental conscience or ethical judgment, many a heart ache would be prevented.
7. Passion Paralyzes Conscience. The first criminal pleaded greed and anger as excuses for his crime, but the excuses were not accepted. If at the moment of his infamous act his conscience was paralyzed, he was responsible for its inertness. The over-urge of appetite, the allurements of ultra ambition, the fires of jealousy, the earthquakes of anger—each strikes with paralyzing power at the conscience. Conscience needs and deserves the shelter of self control; character building must fortify against brain storms.
Questions and Problems
1. Illustrate the distinction between religion and ethics.
2. Which of the ten commandments are in the main theological? Which are mostly or wholly ethical?
3. Which part of the Lord's Prayer is strikingly ethical?
4. Show the ethical elements of the thirteen articles of Latter-day Saint faith?
5. What is conscience?
6. State seven of the laws governing conscience.
7. When should we question our conscience?
8. To what extent may we be justly held accountable for the mistakes we make in following our conscience?
9. Illustrate from your own observation the seventh law of conscience mentioned in this lesson.
10. State the procedure suggested for obtaining an unbiased ethical judgment as to what amount we should pay tithing on.

LESSON II Work and Business (Second Week in January)
TEACHERS' TOPIC FOR JANUARY—ACTIVITIES OF THE RELIEF SOCIETY
Purposes of the Work of the Visiting Teacher
I. To be a representative of the unfortunate and sorrowful. At the second meeting of the first Relief Society, the mother of the Prophet Joseph Smith so touched the hearts of the members of the society that they contributed their jewelry that it might be sold to aid the poor. There was then need for some one to seek out the sorrowing and distressed; for the members asked, How can we know who is in need? Thus it was that the visiting teacher was singled out to be a representative of the poor.
II. To be a representative of the Relief Society and its officers. Visiting teachers are authorized to carry messages in behalf of the Relief Society. They thus become the representatives of the organization and the officers of the organization.
III. To be the servant of those who give relief to the needy. People contributing to teachers for charity relief give through the organization, not to it. So the teacher serves the giver by making his contribution valuable; first, by seeking out the poor who are in need; secondly, by causing the money to be pooled that there may be enough to do real good.
IV. To be a friend having charitable and watchful care over the families in her district. It is her business to know the condition of the families in her visiting district. If they are stricken with illness, or if death occurs in the family, or if there is necessity for furnishing food, clothing, or any of the other necessities of life, she should know these wants, in order that they may be communicated to the ward president.
V. To carry the special message provided by the General Board. The teacher stands ready to carry any special message to the people. It may come from her ward president; it may be from the General Board. For a number of years the General Board has furnished a special message under the caption of the Teachers' Topic.

LESSON III Literature (Third Week in January)
BIOGRAPHY
George Middleton, the son of George and Ida V. Middleton, was born in Patterson, New Jersey, October 27, 1880. He received his B. A. Degree from Columbia University in 1902. In October, 1911, he married Miss Fola LaFollette of Madison, Wisconsin. Mr. Middleton is the author of the following plays: "The Cavalier," 1902; "The Wife's Strategy," 1905; "The Sinner," 1907; "The House of a Thousand Candles," 1908; "Rosalind at Red Gate," 1910; "The Enemy," 1911; "The Prodigal Judge," 1913; "Criminals," 1914; "Hit-the-Trail-Holliday," 1915; "Collusion," 1916; "Polly with a Past," 1917; "The Cave Girl," 1919; "Adam and Eva," 1919; "The Light of the World," 1920; "Cercle," 1922; "The Unknown Lady," 1923; "The Other Rose," 1923; "The Road Together," 1924; "Accused," 1925; "Blood Money," 1927. These plays have been produced throughout the United States. Mr. Middleton is also the author of a number of one-act plays produced at various little theatres. Some of Mr. Middleton's best books are: Nowadays, Embers, Tradition, Possession, The Road Together, and Masks. Mr. Middleton is a frequent contributor to magazines on subjects relating to drama and literature. He has been literary editor of LaFollette's Weekly since 1912. At the present time he is president of the Dramatists' Guild of Authors' League of America.
NOWADAYS—BY GEORGE MIDDLETON
The plot of Nowadays centers around Diana Dawson, the daughter of a family consisting of a father, a mother, a son and Diana. The play opens at the Christmas Season. In the home Mrs. Dawson, assisted by Nellie, the maid, is putting the Christmas decorations in place when she is interrupted by the entrance of her daughter who has been in New York for two years struggling to satisfy a soul's craving to become a sculptor. Mr. Dawson, who is a conservative, thinks Diana should stay at home and assist her mother. The mother, on the contrary, who had the same yearning as a young woman to express herself in art, is not only in favor of Diana working in New York, but has gone one step further by supplying her with financial help her father refuses to give her because she is a daughter. Mrs. Dawson is dressing paper dolls and painting their clothes with an elegance
GUIDE LESSONS FOR JANUARY 623
that gives them market value. The money obtained is sent to Diana to assist her in her work.
The editor of the town paper is Peter Rowe, a man who has recognized Diana's talent and has encouraged her to realize her gift. They are good friends and Diana takes advantage of this fact to have Peter see that her baggage is brought to her home safely. Before he arrives she has had a conversation with her father, who believes that she has given up her foolish notion of living in New York and has come home to stay. She assures him that she has not and surprises him by telling him that after all, he has had something to do with her desire to seek a center where she can study. The following dialogue takes place:
Diana (Not taking him too seriously): Why, daddy, how could I stay at home when it was you who made me go?
Dawson (Bewildered): Me?
Diana (Whimsically): Yes. You and the turtle.
Dawson: The turtle?
Sam: She's crazy, all right.
Diana (Fancifully throughout): Yes, the dear, dear turtle. I've laughed so many times when I think of what little things determine our lives. Do you remember that day—long ago—when I was a real little lady, and Sammy wasn't such a gentleman? Of course you don't. Nellie was sick and mother had taken Sammy to the dentist for something and you had to stay home and take care of me. You ought to remember that day: you said you had such a headache when it was over. You were so happy taking a woman's place that you fell asleep from exhaustion. That was my chance. Destiny opened the door and I went out into the garden. It was all flowers and mud. And, daddy, there on the path I saw a turtle: a poor, lonely little turtle; oh, so lonely I felt sorry for it—because you had mother and Sammy and me, and the little turtle hadn't anybody. Somehow I wanted the turtle to have some little turtles so she wouldn't be so lonely. You see, you ought to have told me where turtles and babies came from.
Later Peter Rowe puts in an appearance much to Diana's delight. Peter is patiently waiting for a moment when he can be alone with Diana, for he has something of importance to say to her.
Diana: Why don't you come to New York?
Peter: People see nothing but electric lights there. Here occasionally we can see the stars.
Diana (Going to him): What's the real reason you won't come?
Peter (Eyeing her): Some day, when you're a great success, I'll tell you.
624 RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE
Diana: I'll wager you won't even then. But I've half a mind to be a success just for that.
Peter: I'll wait.
Diana: Won't you tell me now? (He shakes his head.) Won't you tell me a wee little bit of something now?
Peter: Yes, Diana. One of the reasons I drove out—I almost forgot it, seeing you again. Come to the window. (He pulls aside the curtain.) Look across the lake. See it in the moonlight, three miles across? That's gone up since you went away.
Diana: The dome of the new capitol?
Peter: Yes. The architect had a sense of humor. Made it so beautiful every time even I pass it I feel like taking off my hat and praying. Tough on the politicians.
Diana: Do you feel as though you were praying when you see something beautiful?
Peter: Yes; but I do a heap of cussing.
Diana (Mock seriously): Father's terra-cotta has damns written all over it.
Peter (Pointing): There's a vacant pedestal in front of the approach—like an altar. And a statue is to go on it.
Diana: A statue? Is this where I come in?
Peter: You've got me. It's to be symbolic.
Diana: Something everybody will disagree about?
Peter: Yesterday "The Times" heard they'd decided to have an open competition; secret of course, you know. I thought it would be a fine thing for this burg if "the female of the species"—
Diana (Joyfully): Oh, Peter, wouldn't it be a joke if—
Peter (Quickly): An awful joke on your father.
Diana: But wouldn't mother be happy!
Peter: By the way, it was her old friend, Oliver Hardman, who told me. He's coming out to see her tomorrow, he said. But you mustn't tell him your intentions because he's been appointed on the Legislative Committee as judge. He's down to get a line on it. I pumped him a bit. I know what he thinks appropriate.
Diana: What?
Peter: Something they can call "Democracy." No relation to any of our present parties.
Diana (With a flash, glancing at the newspaper Mrs. Dawson has left on the table): "Democracy! (She gazes rapt before her.) I've got it now. I see it, don't you?
Peter: Never have yet in this country.
GUIDE LESSONS FOR JANUARY 625
Diana: That's it!
Peter: Put me wise.
Diana: Oh, I won't tell even you till I see if there's room for it. (Significantly.) But it's got a woman in it.
Mrs. Dawson wishes to return to New York with her daughter and share her attic that is located up five flights of stairs. She tries to explain to her husband that having made a fortune they should go into the city where, with Diana, they may enjoy the art of New York, but her husband does not see things that way. It has never entered his mind that his wife's housekeeping has grown monotonous and wearisome throughout the years. Much to his surprise she takes a firm stand and goes with her daughter, leaving her husband at home. With his son and wife and a baby that apparently is born during her absence. Every week Mrs. Dawson writes to her husband urging him to come to her but he stubbornly refuses. After an interval of months Mrs. Dawson receives a reply to one of her letters in which Mr. Dawson says: "Belle, I am coming to see you. You are as stubborn as I am."
Mrs. Dawson: "I wonder if your father knows I just couldn't touch his check."
Diana: "Of course he knows."
Mrs. Dawson (Going to her drawer and taking out a legal document): Every time I need a good laugh I look at the statement he drew up when I came here with you. (Reading) Bill of Service. One wife at $25.00 a month for twenty-five years—exclusive of gifts for clothes, food and masculine protection, $7,500, deposited to Belle Dawson's credit for whims, foolishness, and Paris.
Into this somewhat embarrassing situation Mr. Hardman comes, who receives the following greeting from Diana:
Diana: If ever you want to find out your real friends live up five flights of stairs without an elevator.
During the winter Mrs. Dawson has enjoyed her daughter very much. Diana has completed her design for the capitol building and submitted it to the committee. The presence of Mr. Hardman, who is a member of the committee, brings to mind the statue, so Mrs. Dawson very naturally asks about the decision of the committee. Mr. Hardman, enjoying the mother's eagerness, says: I have two surprises for you, Diana. And then he remarks, You have won. The news is so overwhelming that Diana doubts it, but the
626 RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE
mother, getting the full significance of Mr. Hardman's remarks, exclaims: Dearest, you've won, you've won! Oh, my girl, I knew it, I knew it! Diana weeps for joy and Hardman, placing his hand on Mrs. Dawson, says tenderly, Let her. When Diana has regained some of her self-possession she says: Forgive me for seeming like a foolish girl. The mother talks of what this success will mean to her daughter and says that she, too, has great satisfaction for, says she: I haven't failed in my motherhood. You are beautiful all through. I'm so happy you have what has passed me by, so happy.
Mr. Hardman (Tenderly): Belle, I'd give up all my position and reputation to be able to talk like that to a daughter of my own.
Mrs. Dawson: You've missed something, too?
Mr. Hardman: A great deal. Did you ever notice how everybody in the world is wanting something the other fellow has?
Diana: The statue seems so unimportant all of a sudden.
Mrs. Dawson: There now. I've robbed you of the joy of success.
Diana: No. Only how can any artist in the world ever create more beauty than life itself makes?
Mr. Hardman: If you feel that, you know the first great secret of success.
Then comes Diana's second surprise which is a visit from Peter Rowe. As Hardman opens the door Peter exclaims, Diana. He stands looking only at her as she takes his hand at the same time repeating his name. Finally Mrs. Dawson remarks: I'm here, too, Peter. The conversation drifts on and Diana, knowing Peter's devotion to her and realizing that he has not proposed because he feels that he cannot provide adequately for her, breaks into the situation by telling him that with a prize of $25,000 she can pay for the marble for the statue and yet there will be sufficient left for them to live in Paris as husband and wife and that it will give him time to complete his novel. She confesses to him that she got the idea for the statue while talking with him. Yes. Democracy. I got the thought that day when you were by my side. It was the result of all we had talked over. I tried to catch it in marble. A man and a woman marching side by side, step by step. I've broken away from the old form that made man lead far ahead with the woman trailing behind.

Peter: You put them on the same line.
Diana: Both looking far ahead.
Peter: With hope in their eyes.
Diana: Yet as I modeled them both, I felt they were not complete without—without—
Peter: The child.
Diana: See how it's carried between them. Not the mother alone, but the father, too, holding the little hands as they climb up the incline—.
Peter: Together.
Diana: Together.
Peter: It's wonderful.
Diana: Peter, doesn't that tell you all my heart is asking? Shall I be kept from my right to that because you haven't a lot of money when I have enough now to start our lives together? What right had you to be silent when it concerned my life, too? Shall you and I waste our years of youth because you wouldn't speak? Peter, we belong to each other. I want you. I love you.
Then they tell the mother they have become engaged. They wish her to accompany them to Paris but she replies: I stayed by, waiting till you two were ready. I didn't know when you'd fix it up. You were both so foolish about it. I knew I'd have to lose you, Diana. I've gone as far as a mother can go with her girl. It will come to you both, some day. I've held on longer than most mothers.
Betty has come along with Peter Rowe to New York. Mrs. Dawson hunts her up and learns from her that Sam has left her, and that she needs help with the baby. Mrs. Dawson realizes that there is work for her to do in helping to rear her son's child. Betty says if she can only grow to be like Diana she will be perfectly happy, but that she cannot do the job herself, that she needs Mrs. Dawson to assist her. At that moment Mr. Dawson knocks at the door. As he enters he says: You win, Belle. We're going to Paris. To which Mrs. Dawson replies, smiling sweetly, You and I are going back home, Will.
Problems Presented in the Play
Women are justified in developing their God-given talents provided they recognize their righteous obligations toward their family and their home. The playwright's business is to present the problem, not to solve it. If he presents his problem adequately and artistically he may be said to be successful. He is under no obligation to answer or solve the problem. That is the business of society to whom he appeals.
628 RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE
Questions
1. What periods of a woman's life, provided she marries, are freest to do work apart from her home or outside of her home.
2. Name some women you know of who have made worthwhile contributions to life in one way or another before marriage.
3. Name some women who have made noted contributions to life in one way or another, after marriage.
4. In what ways have modern inventions assisted women in having more time to develop their talents, or give service apart from or out of the home?
5. Do you think that nowadays a woman can rear her family, take care of her husband, and develop the talents with which God has blessed her for the development of herself and the betterment of the world? If so, why? If not, why?
6. Discuss any phase of this play that appeals to you as being worthy of discussion.
LESSON IV Social Service (Fourth Week in January)
THE CHILD-STUDY COURSE
Lesson 10. Prevalence and Treatment of Sense Defects.
(Based on Chapter XI, The Child: His Nature and His Needs.)
In the last lesson we considered the general principles of mental hygiene as they apply to the child. In the present lesson we are going to see how mental health and progress in school are dependent upon normal vision, proper hearing, sound teeth, right posture, correct diet, etc. This excellent chapter, in many ways the best one in the text, is written by Dr. C. E. A. Winslow, Professor of Public Health, at Yale University, one of the most eminent authorities in the United States. The author's main point is summed up in the apt phrase: "By taking thought a man cannot add a cubit to his stature, but he can add pounds to his child's weight." A. Defective Vision and Hearing. Of the physical defects which rendered more than forty percent of the drafted men unfit for military service during the late war, visual and auditory handicaps were among the most numerous. GUIDE LESSONS FOR JANUARY 629 It is significant, too, that these two defects correspond to the two main senses by which the human being deals with, and makes successful or unsuccessful adjustment to the world about him. One of the marvels of our civilization is the extent to which permanent defects of vision can be overcome by the proper use of lenses, in the form of spectacles. It is probably safe to estimate that among literate people, about five percent of all children, and twenty-five percent of adults wear glasses. The school boy is no longer regarded as a "sissy," merely because he wears glasses. Only a false pride—usually on the part of the mother—would now deter a child from wearing properly fitted glasses, should he need them. It is definitely known that much of the child's school retardation, especially failure to read, can be traced to uncorrected eye difficulties. The same can be said of hearing. Many a child loses interest in school, gets discouraged, runs away, and finally becomes delinquent because in the beginning he could not hear the teacher and the other children clearly. While defective hearing is less responsive to correction than is defective vision, yet it is amazing what can be done by intelligent parents and teachers, if the child's defect is discovered in time. It might be of interest to our readers to know that one of our Latter-day Saint scholars, Dr. Harvey Fletcher, now with the Western Electric Company, New York City, has recently gained national eminence through his invention of the audiometer, a device by which the hearing of school children can be accurately determined in a very simple, reliable way. The device was commented on favorably in the columns of the Literary Digest several months ago. It has been installed in the public schools of Salt Lake City. Questions 1. To what extent are scarlet fever, and the other children's diseases the cause of deafness and ear trouble in children? What is significant about this fact, for the prevention of deafness? 2. Why, until recently, was a school boy wearing glasses dubbed a "sissy?" 3. Can you cite local examples of school failure and character mal-development due to eye or ear defects? 4. How many children in your community are too blind, or too deaf to attend public school? What is the theory and practice of the State School at Ogden, in the education and training of deaf and blind children? 5. Does your school systematically examine children for eye and ear troubles? If not, why not? 630 RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE B. Other Physical Handicaps. In an age of soft foods and excessive sweets, it is imperative that the child's teeth be kept clean and free from decay. Regular brushing and periodical dental examinations are the best preventive measures known. While the school can do much to help children in the regular use of the tooth brush by means of tooth brush drills, lessons in hygiene, etc., the primary responsibility must rest upon the parents. They can do much by reward and encouragement, by furnishing the child with an appropriate tooth brush and dentifrice, to be kept in a proper place and used with religious regularity. Decayed teeth are like diseased tonsils and adenoids; they are the source of an infection which pours a toxic poison into the blood stream. The ultimate effect of this poisonous substance is to lower the threshold of physical and mental resistance, thus increasing fatigue and making learning difficult. It is axiomatic that healthy minds exist in healthy bodies. Character, morality, mental health, and will power are dependent upon physical health. One of the most interesting post-war health movements has as its objective a reduction in morbidity and morality due to heart disease. In many of our cities, notably Chicago, Cardiac Societies, as they are called, have undertaken to educate public sentiment in regard to the nature, causation, and treatment of cardiac disorders. In many school centers, they have gone so far as to finance special classes for children with weak hearts and to work out a diet, a curriculum, and a scheme of recreation adapted to the needs of children who cannot, at least during their tender years, engage in strenuous, competitive activities of the average school and play ground. These experiments have already demonstrated remarkable possibilities in dealing with, and in many cases overcoming a physical handicap which was once regarded as instrumountable. The movement referred to above is, however, only a small part of the great public health movement which has yielded for the public schools: (a) periodic medical and dental examinations, (b) school nurses, (c) health drills, (d) instruction in personal hygiene, etc. Questions 1. What, if any, is the attention paid to the needs of children with heart disorders in your school or community? 2. What should be the place of the school in the nutrition of the school child? Do you think, for example, school lunches are a good thing? Why or why not? GUIDE LESSONS FOR JANUARY 631 3. What is the status of health work in the schools of your community? Do you have a school physician, a school dentist, a school nurse? 4, How far should the public schools go in diagnosing or even treating sense defects and other physical handicaps in school children? Utah Autumn By Dowers Cornwall There's haze that dreams on the Utah hills, And the trees of green drip gold; Where sunflakes dance on quavering boughs, There is scent of leafy mould. Come mellowed, mauve-dusted, gypsy days, With coo] whispers stirring through, A burst of red is the canyon side, The sky is a bowl of blue. There comes a quiver of rainbow days, Come days with a rusty gleam, Days that are real, and are yet unreal, Like the pattern of a dream. Breezes are chanting a sad farewell, There's a waning plaint and sigh, Sweet prelude of the long sleeping time, Wearied summer's lullaby. An Old Wagon Cover 'By Josephine G. Moench Flora sat by the window with her sewing in her lap and her hands lying idle as she gazed with a serious face out of the window. The first little blustery snow storm had come very early; and as Flora watched the wind blowing the snow about, she wondered seriously just how she and Will were going to get the children's clothing for the winter. In the early days of Utah Flora and Will were pioneers to a little town south of Salt Lake. Everyone was finding it very difficult to get food and clothing; but Flora, being an expert seamstress, had, by a great deal of planning, kept the children comfortably clothed up until then, and by handing down and making over she would be able to make outer garments for them all. But the underwear? By any stretch of her imagination she could not expect that which they had worn through the year and which had been mended until the original garment was beyond recognition, to last through this winter. She remembered on so many occasions how she had trusted the future to providence, which had not failed her; so, with hope springing in her heart, she took up her sewing, thinking the while, that the beautiful Indian summer would come after the storm and there would be no need for worry until that was over. Hearing the sound of wagon wheels, Flora looked up to see a covered wagon stopping at the gate; the driver climbed out and walked briskly to the door. "Is this Mrs. Thomas?" asked the gentleman. "Yes," answered Flora. "I have been told," he said, "that you are an expert needle woman and have come to see if you will mend our wagon covers. This sudden storm has made us realize that we must have our wagon covers in good condition before we continue our journey to California. One of the covers is too light weight for traveling through such wilderness and if you are willing we will give you the cover to pay for your work." Willing? Was ever anyone so fertunate? The light weight wagon cover would do to make the children's underwear. With a song in her heart Flora set to work and conscientiously mended the wagon covers. The traveler was profuse i in his appreciation and thanks, and went on his way rejoicing over his storm-proof covers. Flora had sewed many fine materials but never before had AN OLD WAGON COVER 633 she been more careful in cutting not to waste, and more absorbed in her task. After bleaching the finished garments on the grass, in the good old-country way, she washed and ironed them carefully. Was it magic that had transformed the old wagon cover into the neat pile of underwear? No. Just a woman's skill combined with a mother's faith and a mother's love. A Common Prayer By May E. Lillie Oh, Father in heaven I thank Thee so— For this, our restful bungalow, For the grass in the yard where the lines swing high, Filled with clothes that are hung to dry. How clean they look, how fresh and sweet, Shirts and tablecloth, towel and sheet, And even the wholesome underwear, Fluttering high in the summer air. How glad I am for the vines that grow, Around this peaceful bungalow; Glad for the musical strains that soar Afar to Thy throne from our open door; In praise to Thee my voice is lifted For daughters dear whom Thy love has gifted, And for these others my voice I raise In lasting, joyful songs of praise.
