They say it is a sign of old age when one begins to be reminiscent and to talk about ancient history, and I admit that probably I am getting a little old, for I should like to speak a little of my experience in the Relief Society. I began my Relief Society work when I was sixteen years old, going around the block as an assistant teacher, and I feel that the experience I gained at that time has been most valuable and formed the foundation for much of the work that I have been able to do since. Later, after I was married and had seven children, I was asked to be secretary of the Seventeenth ward Relief Society. I felt that I could not do this with all my little babies. But my husband said, "My dear, you must do it; it is the very thing you need; you need to get away from the babies, and I will help you all I can, either by taking care of the children or making out your reports or RELIEF SOCIETY CONFERENCE 069 copying your minutes, or any other thing I can do." [ felt that I couldn't refuse then, so I consented. I made out my own reports and copied my own minutes, however, but my husband tended the children and helped to make it possible for me to get out. I had occupied this position of secretary between seven and eight years when I was asked if I would accept the position of president of the ward. And I did not know how I could do that either. There is a little more responsibility connected to that position than to that of a secretary, but I did, and I worked at that for about eight years, and before I was released from that I was appointed treasurer of the general Relief Society. That occurred about the year 1901. Then, during that time, the Salt Lake Stake was reorganized and four stakes made from that stake, and I was urged to accept the presidency of the Salt Lake stake, which I did. Later, in 1911, I was appointed counselor to President Emmeline B. Wells, and on April 4, 1921, which is just seven and a half years ago, I was appointed president. Now, I like to feel that I have no regrets, that I have done my work as well as I could, that I have tried to have the spirit of the Lord with me at all times, and if I should feel at any time that I should like to be 'released, I hope that you will all feel in that event that I have thought out very well the line which I should follow and that whatever happens I hope I shail still have your love and your faith and prayers. You will recollect that it has always been my policy to advocate to you that we do not retain our positions too long, that there are many capable women and that such honor and dignity as come with positions of this kind, should rotate. My earnest prayer at this time is that the Lord will bless you in your labors and help you to do your work in a manner pleasing to him. Counselor Knight suggested that the audience stand as an Amen to President Williams' remarks, and the entire congregation arose and remained standing for a few minutes. Pioneers RED RUST—CORNELIA JAMES CANNON By Lais V. Hales About fifty years ago, to a prominent family in St, Paul, Minnesota, a little girl was born. All her girlhood was spent in the West among the Swedish immigrants. In 1899 she graduated from Radcliffe College and a few years later married Dr. Walter Bradford Cannon who is a George Higginson Professor of Physiology at the Harvard University Medical School. Today Mrs. Cannon is the mother of five fine children and the author of a novel Red Rust and several articles of substance. Red Rust is Mrs. Cannon's first novel. It tells of Swedish immigrant life on a pioneer farm in Minnesota. From close observation and from her lawyer father she has gleaned her information and she thoroughly understands and loves the people she writes about. Matts Swenson, a young Swedish boy, drives his oxen over. The hills of Minnesota during the cold weather. As Matts wanders over this land of "prairie and privation'" he comes into contact with a family named Jensen who have recently arrived in the neighborhood. Olaf Jensen, the father, is a cruel man with a craving for liquor. Matts works for Olaf and gets a glimpse of the cruel treatment which Olaf gives his family. Matts, who is sensitive, delicate, decent, with a great love for beauty, goodness, uprightness, feels very sorry for Lena Jensen and her children. He realizes how hard pioneer life is on women and children at its best and he does everything in his power to make things more pleasant. In his effort to enlighten the burdens of Lena and her children Matts evokes the anger of Olaf. Olaf meets with a violent death and releases his family from the curse of his temper. Matts continues to help and befriend the Jensen family until he realizes that Lena, though an older woman, has come to deeply love him. Never before in her life had she known solicitude or sympathy from any man. Olaf Jensen, in his mad desire to build up a fortune in America, had sacrificed her without a thought. Matts and Lena are quietly married and return to the Jensen farmstead to live. Matts continues his study of wheat. Many times he has seen red rust, hot winds, long continued drought, and grasshoppers wreck the wheat crop. His dream is of finding someday, through cross breeding, the wheat which will make these disasters impossible. Lena believes in Matts and helps him. While he experiments with his small plot of ground she cares for PIONEERS 671 the rest of the farm. She endures the soul-destroying toil of pioneering in this new country with fortitude. She knows that if Matts can develop a wheat that can withstand the ravages of the dreaded red rust he can save the farmers of Minnesota. Matts struggles on meeting often with defeat and discouragement. After years of patience, self-mastery, and self-sacrifice he obtains a variety of wheat which ripens before the appearance of the red rust. Before he has time to realize that he has succeeded death overtakes him. It is left for Lena to complete Matts' dreain by having his seed planted wherever such grain could grow and give rich harvests. Today Matts Swenson is forgotten but his wheat is still growing on the fertile lands of Minnesota. There is something distinctly refreshing about [ted Rust. According to Dorothy Foster Gilman, Matts Swenson is "an idealized portrait of our new Americans." Instead of wanting to take from, his wonderful new country which he had adopted, he wanted to give to her and make her richer and finer. He is a splendid example of the kind of immigrant that this country most needs. His eyes are turned toward the future instead of back to the glory of a sunset long past. As Mrs. Cannon has portrayed him he is of heroic stature, free from all petty characteristics. And he is real too—so real that after closing the book he is still with us. The story is directly told. The language is beautiful without any attempt at effect. One can open the book at random and find such clear beautiful writing as the following: '"Matts' heart was beating fast as he lifted the paper that lay at the foot of the stocky Swedish plant. He carried it carefully to the row of native wheat, where the tall green stalk, although freed of twothirds of its spikelets, still hung its heavy head. The great moments of his life had come. As Matts stood there in his shabby clothes, his bare feet brown with the dust of the field, his unkempt hair pushed back from his forehead, his hands ready for the delicate work they must do, he was one with the poets and creators of the ages. The light that shone in the eyes must have illuminated the face of every man who ever struggled to remake his world and to build up a better one about him. The passion to set new forces free, which inspired him, may have been the driving force of the creator of being itself." The Evolution of the Ugly Duckling By Estella Webb Thomas December 25—It was purely by accident that I happened on this funny old red diary, given me by Granny five years ago this Christmas, and carefully sealed up with adhesive plaster and hidden away in an old chest of treasures when I had finished recording an episode in my fifteen-year-old life. I planned to burn it but suppose my thrifty nature must have prevented that— it has such pretty red morrocco backs. 'And then it was a gift from Granny; and now that she's gone, I'm glad I kept it. But how I came to find it, and decide to fill in the blank pages is a long story, and I'd better begin at the beginning. To begin with, then, I'm a country school teacher. Naturally! Don't Ugly Ducklings always turn into old-maid school teachers? And of course I couldn't spoil the picture—though it took some persuasion to make mother and the dear professor see my point. It was fine in the professor to want to stake me to a college education and all that; but I knew he couldn't really afford it with Lisbeth to educate, and mother needing trips in the summer vacation to keep her well; so, after the expense of Inez's wedding was over, I, Margaret, alias Daisy, decided manfully to shoulder my share of the family budget, and strike out on my own, as the original Ugly Duckling did. However, I have not developed any swan-like qualities yet, and am certainly not prepared to sing my swan song; for though, like the hod-carrier's, there are many ups and downs in a school teacher's life, it's all the more interesting for that, and I'm enjoying myself immensely. Inez, after being engaged to Dick Burton and Charlie McGee, finally married Henley Melton, whose father is the richest man in town; and she can have pretty things to her heart's content. They are spending this winter in Florida, and her letters are like communications from another world. Lisbeth is at a musical school in the East, getting voice culture. That brings me to the present, and the dilemma I'm in. It seems she has developed a case of measles right here at holidaytime; and mother and the professor decided to spend Christmas with the invalid, so long as she couldn't come home, and sent me a telegram to that effect. All this I have found out since I arrived, however, for I left Green Valley before the telegram was sent, spent a day with a friend, Marie Jackson, who teaches in the EVOLUTION OF THE UGLY DUCKLING 673 next district, and reached home after ten o'clock on Christmas Eve. It was a disappointment not to be met at the station; but after I had succeeded in finding a cab and getting myself and suitcase transported through the storm, it was a real blow to be confronted by a dark, silent house, instead of the brilliantly lighted, festively decorated one I had anticipated. The front door proved to be locked, and the rear ones as well, when I had tramped about in the snow to investigate. Shivering disconsolately on the front steps, I considered the situation. Of course there were people in town to whom I might go for the night, but my pride rebelled at thrusting myself, unexpected, into someone's house late on Christmas Eve. Our old friends the Bartons had moved from the house next door, mother had written me, and strangers now occupied the place. I must certainly do something, as I was slowly, but surely congealing in the frosty air. When I had come to the decision that there was nothing for it but to break in at a window, I suddenly remembered that I had a house key, which I finally succeeded in finding after a frantic search with stiff fingers through all my belongings. The house loked cold and cheerless when I had turned on the light, and it seemed an hour before I got a fire going in the grate and thawed out my aching fingers. When I was comfortably warm, I made an excursion into the kitchen in search of forage. There were some pies on the pantry shelf and a big fruit cake, and there mother's Christmas preparations seemed to have ceased; but I found some cold ham in the ice-box, and with this and some bread and butter on a tray on the living-room table, was trying to make myself a cup of cocoa over the fire when a sound in the hall startled me. Turning with the little sauce-pan in my hand, I confronted a very tall, rather dishevelled young man, who was evidently as astonished at the sight of me, as I was to see him. For an instant we were both silent, staring stupidly at one another, and then I collected myself and demanded indignantly what he was doing there. "Just what I was going to ask you," said the young man, politely, My answer wasn't so polite: "If it happens to be any of your business, 1'm trying to make cocoa over this smoky old fire!" I retorted, feeling that I was not looking my best, as I crouched over the fire with a sauce-pan in my hand, and one of mother's big aprons over my suit.- "Well, you're a cool one, at least,' he said admiringly, "and if you're as desperately in need of food as you seem to be, I'm sure the hospitable Sturtevants would not begrudge you a Christmas Eve supper. But why did you do it? You are so evidently not that kind of a person—Were you in such desperate straits as ali that? My mother and I would have been glad to have taken you in, and will still." 674 RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE "Indeed I was," I responded in a heart-broken voice, deciding now I knew he was not a burglar, but believed me to be one, to carry on the joke. "Starved, and very near frozen, but—no, thanks, to your kind offer, of assistance, I can't accept help from anyone!" "Oh!" the young man gave me a peculiar glance. "It isn't so hard on the pride, then, to help yourself, as it were, rather than to be helped?" "Not nearly!' I replied, giving my whole attention to the cocoa, which was threatening to boil over. There were a few moments of silence, then the young man said in a different voice, stirring uneasily, ""Well, see here, this can't go on, you know! The nightwatchman over at the bank knows that the Sturtevants left for the East this afternoon, and he'll be over to investigate when he sees the light." "T should have turned off the hall light,' I murmured, not making any move to do so, however., "Well, what are you going to do about it?" queried the visitor, somewhat sharply. "As I said, mother and I will take you in if you need help, and old Tobe Warner will think it queer, to say the least, when he investigates and finds you occupying the Sturtevant's living room." "Better put the light out, if you're afraid," I suggested, "Tobe may think it rather strange for you to be here, and while I don't wish to seem inhospitable, you needn't stay, you know, if you crave to go. But won't you have a cup of cocoa and a sandwich first?" I began making a sandwich as I spoke. "Say, this is a bit thick!" said the young man, dazedly, mechanically taking the sandwich I handed him, and looking about absently for a place to lay it down again. "Ves, I know the slices are rather thick," I said, purposely misunderstanding. "I'm not very good at slicing, I always cut my fingers." Just then there was a sharp rap on the door, and old Tobe Warner opened it and popped in his head. "What's up, here?" he shouted, and then when I appeared in the hall he said in a changed tone, "Oh! It's you, is it, Miss Daisy? Didn't know you were expected!" "Apparently I wasn't," I answered, "by the looks of things! Mr.—er—this gentleman tells me mother and the professor have gone East; do you know why?" "Why, didn't you get their telegram? I was in the office when Professor Sturtevant sent it. Miss Lisbeth's been took down with measles, and they left on the afternoon train. They thought you'd stay where you wuz. Well, I'll be getting back," he added, with a curious glance at the young man, who had stood in a dazed silence during this conversation, although I had motioned for him to stay out of sight in the living-room. "Didn't EVOLUTION OF THE UGLY DUCKLING 675 know you wuz acquainted with Miss Daisy, Mr. Douglas, you coming after she left, and all." "Oh, yes," said the young man easily and unexpectedly, "Mis —er—Sturtevant and I are old—that is, we know lots about each other. She knows that I'm a goofy and can't keep my nose out of other people's affairs, and I know that she can't cut thin slices." "Well," drawled Tobe, as a parting shot, "Course it's none of my business, but seems kinda strange that you'd call Miss Wallace 'Miss Sturtevant' if you know her so dog-gone well!" and departed reluctantly, with a glance of suspicion at Mr. Douglas. That gentleman was apparently leaving, too. In fact, he seemed in rather a hurry to be gone; but he paused in the doorway, as Tobe had, for a parting word. "Well, good evening, and a merry Christmas, Miss Wallace," he said, showing a handsome set of teeth in the first smile he had vouchsafed me; "I seem to have intruded needlessly on your homecoming, but delighted to have played the fool for a few minutes if it gave you any satisfaction!" "Glad to have you drop in any time you crave a smoky cup of cocoa and a thick sandwich!" I replied heartily, but he was gone, and my invitation echoed on the empty air. The house seemed terribly cold and dreary after my uninvited guest had gone, and without any more delay I ran up to my room and got shivering into bed. I found a small jar of cream on the step when I opened the door next morning, and had an excellent breakfast, after which I prepared to amuse myself till afternoon, when I intended to make some Christmas calls. It was after I had finished my bit of morning work, and come upstairs to rummage around a little, that I ran across this old diary in the bottom of a box of treasures and decided to finish it. It surely is the most absurd thing I've seen for many a day! What a solemn little prig I was! And what a crush I had on the professor! He'd get a good laugh out of it if he knew—but he'll never know, so he'll have to read the funny paper for his laugh. But just to pass the time on the first Christmas day I ever spent alone, I began writing in it this morning. Must go now and make myself beautiful. Ha, ha, and sally forth. (To be Continued) A Sound Investment By Miss Bernice Selley, Utah Tuberculosis Association Little children, playing in dirty, crowded city streets, in the sweltering oppression of midsummer, touched the heart strings of good people who knew that not far away were grassy meadows, cool groves and sparkling brooks. Might not the cramped lives of these city urchins, wan and ragged, many of them, be expanded a bit by transplanting them, even for a brief period, to the open country? So the fresh air camp was born. The idea grew rapidly. Summer camps of all descriptions sprang up. Health associations, appreciating the value of summer outings, were quick to join in the movement and many established camps of their own. These are called health camps and their primary purpose is to husband and increase the health capital of children below par in vigor and vitality. There are in all communities certain children who are neither definitely sick nor vigorously well. They do not need hospital treatment, but neither are they competent to keep pace with other more sturdy children. Experience has shown that such handicapped children can be helped by conserving their limited energies and by teaching them how to order their lives in accordance with their handicaps. Open air schools, preventoria and summer health camps all aim to help this type of child. Efficient health camps must meet certain standards. The children must have careful medical guidance, rest, good food, hygienic practice, including the development of sound health habits and plenty fresh air and sunshine. If there are any defects that need correction, such as adenoids and tonsils, these must be corrected. The children themselves receive training in the ways of health and their parents also are given instruction. The Utah Christmas Seal Health Camp established last summer by the Utah Tuberculosis Association in Big Cottonwood canyon provided efficient care to thirty children for a period of six weeks. The average gain per child was six pounds. It is hoped the funds next year will permit the association to increase the number of children at the health camp to fifty or sixty. The Health Camp was supported by Christmas seal funds. It was an investment with dividends measured not in dollars but in strong men and charming women. Children who might otherwise be sacrificed were made happy and healthy. Christmas seal funds used on health camps represent a sound investment, and everyone can invest their bit when Christmas seals are bought and sold. D. Comments. From the material presented the following conclusions seem certain:
1. That the yearning for purity reaches upward for help. David pleaded for a reacquaintance with purity.
2. That purity of heart assures an at-home-ness with the Lord.
3. That purity of life makes men pure without from within until their countenances are a symbol of divinity—their fathers' name is on their "foreheads."
4. That sin dust blinds our conscience.
5. Zion spells social purity as well as personal cleanliness.
6. That impurity is a bar to the privileges of the first resurrection.
7. That purity is related to our missionary system and temple ordinances, both as cause and effect. The desires and dreams of missionary experience are accompanied by a purity standard of a high order. Gospel ambassadorship demands purity of life and the expectancy of a mission is an inward call to keep clean, to keep fit for the blessings of the House of the Lord. The glorifying of the missionary work is, in all its phases, religion applied to the problem of purity.
8. That impurity carries over beyond the grave.
9. That an early-age acquaintance with the word of God is a life-belt on the sea of temptation.
10. That poetry and philosophy proclaim purity there is no worthwhile ideality without purity.
11. That we may lock the doors of our minds against the invasions of the unclean.
12. That the entertainment of the pure abashes the impure.
13. That scout work is one of the best allies to our religion. The boy on his honor is knighted a preserver of his own purity and a defender of the purity of others. The scout-life with the ambitions, expectations, and achievements give to the youth a puritanic sphere of activity full of adventure and upward thrills.
14. That the "Strength of Being Clean" contains within its covers condensed purity food.
15. That impurity "will out." Nature refuses to keep the secrets of sin.
16. That strength and beauty, survival and salvation, are the fruits of purity.

LESSON II Work and Business (Second Week in February)
TEACHERS' TOPIC FOR FEBRUARY—ACTIVITIES OF THE RELIEF SOCIETY
I. WHY THE RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE?
It is the organ of the Relief Society of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints. As such it keeps each of us in touch with the Relief Society work in general. It is a medium through which special messages may be received from the presidency of the Relief Society.
II. Material found in the Magazine:
A. It contains news of interest to women and particularly to Relief Society women, such as important world events as interpreted in their relationship to Relief Society work.
B. Literary gems in prose and verse form part of the makeup of practically every issue of the Magazine.
C. Historical events and biographies of Relief Society leaders and other women of note are preserved to us through its pages.
D. The Magazine frequently contains travel articles of interest and importance sometimes written by L. D. S. writers and sometimes by others.
E. Child guidance and parent problems are often treated.
F. Household helps such as budgeting are included.
G. The Magazine contains the guide lessons which are indispensable to good class work.
III. Talent is developed by the publication of the prose and poetry of our local writers.
IV. As editor of the Magazine we have a woman who has made a life study of woman's cause, keen and sympathetic with high ideals. She is preeminently qualified for the great task by inheritance and education in and out of the Church.
The teacher should study thoroughly one copy of the Magazine and carry it with her that people may see it and that it may become a basis of discussion.

THE LITERATURE COURSE
We promised to publish, at as early a date as possible, the price list of the books for the new literature course:
"Nowadays" is listed at $1.75; "The Devil's Disciple," at $1.00; "What Every Woman Knows," at $1.00; "Joseph and His Brethren," at 75c; "The Doll's House," at 80c. "He and She" cannot be obtained separately. It is published in a book of American Plays by Quinn. As a consequence we have decided to substitute for "He and She" Galsworthy's "Justice," which sells at 75c.
We are asking the Deseret Book Company to keep these books in stock to accommodate the organizations and individuals that care to purchase them. Whether they are purchased or not is at the option of each ward and stake. We wish to give our members all the help we can, but are anxious that no help offered shall in any sense prove a burden. That is why we emphasize the fact that it is entirely optional whether these books are purchased or not. We shall continue, as in the past, to devote as much space to the literature lesson as the size of the magazine will permit.
We would draw the attention of our members to the fact that many of the college libraries located in many of the cities have these books upon their shelves; also that practically all the public libraries carry a good many volumes of modern drama. Recently the president of the Alpine stake sent for our list in order to put the set of books in a collection in the American Fork Library, which has been placed there to the honor of their late president, Mrs. Annie Hindley. Public libraries are always eager to serve the community; and if the officers will present them with lists of books that are to be used extensively in the community, they are eager, as a rule, to receive the list and make the purchase.

LESSON III Literature (Third Week in February)
BIOGRAPHY
George Bernard Shaw is the most brilliant of living British playwrights. His public addresses are full of keen and clever statements that can come only from one whose mind scintillates continuously, as does the mind of George Bernard Shaw. He is a satirist, keen and cutting. One of his critics talks about his "razor-like" thrusts. No matter what may be said to him he always has a ready reply. We have heard a good many addresses by eminent people but have never heard one with quite the ready comeback to all questioners as an address delivered to the teachers of London by George Bernard Shaw in 1911.
He was born in Dublin on the 26th of July, 1856. His father was a retired civil servant, the younger son of Bernard Shaw, high sheriff of Kilkenny. His mother was Lucinda Elizabeth Gurly Shaw, a good musician who eventually became a teacher of singing in London. George Bernard Shaw attended school in Dublin, and at the age of fifteen began earning his own living. For five years he was a clerk in the office of an Irish land-agent going to London with his family in 1876. In 1879 he was in the offices of the Edison telephone company. At this time he had already started writing novels, but had not yet found a market for them. His first publications appear as serials in a monthly magazine Our Corner. These were The Irrational Knot, written in 1880 and Love Among the Artists, written in 1881.
Mr. Shaw joined the Fabian Society in 1884 and became active in socialistic propaganda as a street orator and also a pamphleteer. He began journalism through the influence of William Archer, on the reviewing staff of the Pall Mall Gazette in 1885. In his role of art and musical critic he was a very brilliant reviewer. It is said that he thought some of the dramas he had to review so stupid that he sought to relieve the situation by writing some plays of his own. That he has helped to raise the quality of English drama no one competent to judge will deny. His dialogue is brilliant beyond that of most gifted playwrights. He is a disciple of Ibsen.
Some of Mr. Shaw's most important plays are Arms and the Man which was produced in 1894; Candida written in 1894; The Man of Destiny, a Napoleonic drama written in 1895; You Never Can Tell, written in 1896; The Devil's Disciple, which was produced in New York in 1897 and in London in 1899; Caesar and Cleopatra, written in 1898; Captain Brassbound's Conversion, 1898; The Admirable Bashville, 1903; Man and Superman, published in 1903; The Doctor's Dilemma, in 1906; Androcles and the Lion; Back to Methuselah; and Saint Joan. Man and Superman and Saint Joan are considered his greatest plays.
In 1898 he married Charlotte Frances Payne-Townsend, a woman who appears to be able to enter with him into all his work. George Bernard Shaw has always been very much interested in extending to women those rights and privileges which were justly hers. Among the men who worked hard to obtain suffrage for the British women no one was more conspicuous in this than the gifted playwright. His wife made a trip to Boston for the sole purpose of taking part in the suffrage parade with the women of that city. When invited to ride she refused, stating that she would prefer to march with the women of that city. He lives in the city of London and his rooms are so close to those of Sir James Matthew Barrie, the famous Scotch playwright, that they can talk out of the window to each other. Practically everything he says has news value. Papers all over the world will publish any comment with which he will favor them.
THE DEVIL'S DISCIPLE By George Bernard Shaw
The play has its setting in the state of New Hampshire in the year 1777. It opens in the main room of a house where most of the occupants are interested in the fire because the morning is very cold. It is the home of Mrs. Dudgeon. She is a Puritan of the strictest type, one, as Shaw points out, of a bitter temper and fierce pride. She has an unquestioned reputation for piety and respectability, but is generally a very disagreeable woman, so disagreeable that some of her neighbors who do not hold to her strict rules of conduct think she must be exceedingly good because she is so disagreeable. She prides herself on never having missed a Sunday at the Church, but her religion has not developed in her an attitude of sympathy or kindness towards her fellowmen. She perhaps finds herself in the same category as some Christians, of whom Swift spoke when he said they had just enough religion in them to make them hate their neighbors.
With her in the room is a girl she calls Essie, who is the illegitimate child of her husband's brother, who had just been hanged at Springtown. Her husband went to see the hanging, then fell sick, and died during the night. Dick Dudgeon, her eldest son, is the first caller of the morning, consequently is the first one to bring an account of the hanging. As the matter has been planned the minister is to break the news to Mrs. Dudgeon of the death of her husband, but her son Richard really does it before the minister arrives.
Mrs. Dudgeon is not overly proud of her two sons, as the following passage will disclose. She says: "A nice comfort my children are to me! One son a fool, and the other a lost sinner that has left his home to live with smugglers, gypsies, and villains, the scum of the earth!"
Mrs. Dudgeon is very severe in her treatment of Essie as shown by the entrance of the half-wit into the room a little earlier in the scene when she says: "Why, who are you?" The girl responds shyly, "Essie." To which Mrs. Dudgeon responds: "Oh, you may well ask. Go to your room, child, and lie down since you haven't feeling enough to keep you awake. Your history is not fit for your own ears to hear." The child said: "I—"
Mrs. Dudgeon: "Do not answer me, miss, but show your obedience by doing what I tell you; and do not forget to say your prayers. She'd have gone to bed last night just as if nothing had happened if I'd have let her."
Finally Mr. Anderson, the minister, arrives. Mrs. Dudgeon is one of those women who feel that it is necessary to show a good deal of distress at the news of her husband's death. That there is much hypocrisy in her sorrow is evinced by the fact that she makes such a fuss over her husband's decision when the will is read.
Just before the reading of the will something occurs that discloses the real character of the woman who believes herself to be a very righteous person, as also the real character of her son whom she thinks of as a disciple of the devil. Richard asks: "By the way, did I hear, or did I not, that our late lamented Uncle Peter, though unmarried, was a father?"
Uncle Titus: "He had only one irregular child, sir."
Richard: "It touches me profoundly, Pastor. By the way, what has become of the irregular child?"
Anderson: (pointing to Essie) "There, sir, listening to you."
Richard: (shocked into sincerity.) "What! Why the devil didn't you tell me that before? Children suffer enough in this house without—(He hurries remorsefully to Essie.) Come, little cousin! Never mind me: it was not meant to hurt you. (She looks up gratefully at him. Her tear-stained face affects him violently, and he bursts out, in a transport of wrath): "Who has been making her cry? Who has been ill-treating her?"
Mrs. Dudgeon: "Silence your blasphemous tongue. I will bear no more of this. Leave my house."
Richard: "How do you know it is your house until the will is read?"
The reading of the will discloses the facts that: "I give and bequeath a hundred pounds to my younger son Christopher Dudgeon. I give and bequeath to my wife Annie Dudgeon an annuity of fifty-two pounds a year for life to be paid out of the interest on her own money."
Mrs. Dudgeon: "A very good way to put God's truth. It was every penny my own."
"I give and bequeath my house at Websterbridge with the land belonging to it and all the rest of my property to my eldest son and heir, Richard Dudgeon, on conditions that he shall not let my brother Peter's natural child starve or be driven by want to an evil life."
We learn later that the British soldiers in their desire to terrorize rebels have made up their mind to execute somebody at Websterbridge, just as they executed Richard's Uncle Peter at Springtown. It has been whispered about that either Richard Dudgeon or the minister, Mr. Anderson, is to be sacrificed. Dick has heard that the minister is to be made an example of and the minister has heard that it is Dick Dudgeon. The minister sends for Dick and he arrives just about tea time. Judith, his wife, thinks Dick a very ungodly sort of person, and resents through facial expression her husband's suggestion that Dick stop and have tea, but finally, out of consideration of her husband, she says that she would like to have him remain. Just as they are about to pour the tea, Christy comes with a message that his mother is very ill and wishes the minister to come at once. Mr. Anderson has scarcely left the home when British soldiers appear at the door. They arrest Dick Dudgeon for the minister. He indicates to Judith that she must not betray him and so he places the minister's cloak on his shoulders and accepts the offer of a last minute to say good-bye to Judith. Suddenly it occurs to Mrs. Anderson that Dick has been very much misjudged, that under a rough and crude exterior he really possesses the essence of a Christian character. He tells her hurriedly to have her husband get out of the way, that it will not save his life for her husband to give himself up, as they will undoubtedly hang them both. As he leaves the room, he urges her to kiss him so that the officers may be misled. This she does. As she does so, she falls into a swoon. Her husband arrives soon after the officers have departed with Dick. He cannot understand the confused condition in which he finds her and feels for a moment that Dick has in some way insulted her. Finally the truth comes to light, and then she implores her husband to go and give himself up and thus bring about the release of Richard Dudgeon. This he refuses to do, but at once arranges for a fast horse and departs with nearly all the money they have in the house. Mrs. Anderson is as much surprised at what her husband does as she was at what Dick did. She goes to the prison to see Dick and finally gets permission to attend the trial. She is incensed that it should be such a sham. Finally the officers in charge decide that Richard Dudgeon, who they think is Anderson, the minister, shall be hanged at twelve o'clock. Richard tells his prosecutors or persecutors, whichever you please to call them, that if the townspeople had listened to him they would have found the streets barricaded, the houses loopholed, and the people in arms to hold the town. But, said he, "you arrived unfortunately before we got out of the talking stage."
Major Swindon, indignant that Dudgeon should dare to talk to him in this way, replied: "Well, sir, we shall teach you and your townspeople a lesson they will not forget. Have you anything more to say?"
Richard: "I think you might have the decency to treat me as a prisoner of war, and shoot me like a man instead of hanging me like a dog."
Burgoyne: (sympathetically.) "Now there, Mr. Anderson, you talk like a civilian, if you will excuse my saying so. Have you any idea of the average marksmanship of the army of His Majesty King George the Third? If we make you up a firing party, what will happen? Half of them will miss you: the rest will make a mess of the business and leave you to the provost-marshal's pistol. Whereas we can hang you in a perfectly workmanlike and agreeable way."
The time approaches for the execution and Richard stands there with the noose about his neck and his eyes on the clock. In the meantime they have discovered that it is not the minister but Dick Dudgeon that they are about to hang. About a minute before the hanging takes place Anderson arrives at the head of the rebel troop and the town falls into the hands of the Americans. Dick is released, very much to Essie's joy, who cannot keep back the tears. Good-humoredly but wilfully Richard says to her: "Now, now. Come, come! I don't mind being hanged, but I will not be cried over."
The Problem of the Play
The problem in this play is manifestly an endeavor to discover which is the saint and which the sinner. Mrs. Dudgeon, feeling she has followed all the rules of Puritan conduct, naturally imagines that she is a very righteous person; while Dick, who rebels against the conventions of his day, is very naturally regarded by the people of the community as being decidedly unrighteous. Yet, when put to the test, Dick is willing to give his life for the minister, whose wife feels that it is an abuse for her to drink tea with him. Consequently, he that was least amongst them became the greatest of them all when measured by the true rule of righteous conduct.
Questions and Problems
1. What type of woman is Mrs. Dudgeon?
2. Do you think that the Puritan religion had a tendency to produce women of that sort?
3. What do you think of Mrs. Dudgeon's treatment of Essie?
4. What person in the play has a modern attitude towards Essie?
5. Do you call to mind any instances in your experience where convention has a tendency to make a saint out of the sinner and a sinner out of the saint?

LESSON IV Social Service (Fourth Week in February)
THE CHILD STUDY COURSE
Lesson XI. The Treatment and Prevention of Delinquency. (Based on Chapter XII, The Child: His Nature and His Needs.)
In the last four lessons we have been considering the physical and mental health of the child. We are now going to look at certain aspects of character development, and for this purpose shall consider the principles underlying the modern treatment of juvenile delinquency.
This chapter was written by Dr. William Healy, at the present time director of the Judge Baker Foundation in Boston, a child guidance clinic connected with the Boston Juvenile Court. It should be said here that Dr. Healy is a pioneer in the scientific study of delinquency and crime. It was his scientific study of one thousand repeated offenders* in the Chicago Juvenile Court some fifteen years ago which began the movement for a scientific study of delinquency and the child guidance clinic as forms of prevention.
A. Some Recent Studies.
One of the most recent bits of scientific work in the field of delinquency—stimulated by Dr. Healy—is that of Dr. Cyril Burt, psychologist to the London County Council, and reported in his book The Young Delinquent (Appleton, 1925). Dr. Burt's method of studying delinquents was fundamentally the same as Dr. Healy's in that he studied actual cases in order to discover his facts and draw his conclusions. His method differed from Dr. Healy's, however, in that he measured his delinquent group by a group of non-delinquent boys and girls of the same age and circumstances. By a rather elaborate statistical method, he discovered the following, in the order of their statement, as the causes of delinquency in his two hundred cases: "(1) defective discipline; (2) specific instincts; (3) general emotional instability; (4) morbid emotional conditions, mild rather than grave, generating or generated by so-called complexes; (5) a family history of vice or crime; (6) intellectual disabilities, such as backwardness or dullness; (7) detrimental interests, such as a passion for adventure, for the cinema, or for some particular person, together with a lack of any uplifting pursuits; (8) developmental conditions, such as adolescence or precocity in growth; (9) a family history of intellectual weakness; (10) defective family relationships—the absence of a father, the presence of a stepmother; (11) influences operating outside the home—as bad street companions and lack or excess of facilities for amusement; (12) a family history of temperamental disorder—of insanity or the like; (13) a family history of physical weakness; (14) poverty and its concomitants; and, last of all, (15) physical infirmity or weakness in the child himself."
Among his other conclusions may be noted the following: "On an average, each delinquent child is the product of nine or ten subversive circumstances, one as a rule preponderating and all conspiring to draw him into crime."
"Every cause and every influence, however, no matter what its special form may be, is found to operate and can only operate through its inner psychological effects. Conduct and misconduct are always, in the last analysis, the outcome of mental life."
B. Classification of Causes
All scientific studies of delinquency confirm each other in the conclusion that delinquency may be caused in a variety of ways. The terms "delinquency" and "crime" are generic ones and are comparable to the terms "sickness" and "disease" in the field of medicine. That is to say, the terms are very general and apply to a large group of widely different things. The significance of this fact, however, is that if progress in the treatment and prevention of delinquency is to be achieved, it must be realized in much the same way it was achieved in the treatment and prevention of disease, viz., by the isolation of specific forms, types, patterns, etc. That is to say, delinquency cannot be dealt with effectively as a whole, any more than diseases can be effectually treated or prevented en bloc. Just as there is no one universal panacea or palliative for all disease, neither is there one universal treatment or cure-all for delinquency.
This list of known causes of delinquency is so long and varied that we have attempted the following simple classification:
Classification of Causes of Delinquency
I. Factors Which Enfeeble Social Control.
A. Chronic.
1. Inherent defects in the political order, e.g., in law, in government, in politics.
2. Inherent defects in the economic order, e.g., low wages, unemployment, etc.
3. Inherent defects in the social order, e.g., in the family system, in education, in the standard of living, etc.
4. Urbanization, e.g., migration, mobility, anonymity, etc.
5. Physical environment, e.g., geographic or climatologic handicaps.
6. Changing mores and group conflict, e.g., with regard to sex; use of alcohol, tobacco, etc.
B. Acute. 7. Family disorganization, e.g., death of parent, nonsupport, incompatibility, etc. 8. Neighborhood disorganization, e.g., poor housing, unwholesome associations, etc. 9. Governmental disorganization, e.g., graft, maladministration of law and justice, etc. 10. Inadequate educational activities, e.g., amount and quality of secular, religious and vocational instruction. 11. Inadequate avocational facilities, e.g., unwholesome leisure interests and lack of facilities.
II. Factors Which Enfeeble Self-Control.
A. Chronic. 12. Inherited or acquired physical handicap, e.g., stature, deformity, constitutional weakness, etc. 13. Inherited or acquired mental handicap, e.g., feeblemindedness, psychopathic personality, epilepsy, etc.
B. Acute. 14. Physical injury or disease, e.g., accident, tuberculosis, syphilis, etc. 15. Mental disease, e.g., psychoses, psycho-neuroses, mental conflicts, etc. 16. Age and physiological epoch, e.g., adolescence, etc. 17. Personal disorganization from excesses, e.g., sex; use of alcohol, narcotics, etc. 18. Ignorance, e.g., lack of sophistication, faulty perspective, etc.
We concur in the position taken by Dr. Cyril Burt that these causes of delinquency are far from peculiar to delinquent persons and situations. "With children of the same social class," says he, "identical conditions may co-exist without plunging them into a criminal career. It must, therefore, as a rule be either the number of factors, or the particular combination of them that renders delinquency a probable result."
C. The Work of a Child Guidance Clinic
We made some reference, it will be recalled, in a previous lesson, to the mental hygiene movement and to the activities of the modern child guidance clinics. These clinics combine the services of the physician, the psychiatrist, the psychologist, and the psychiatric social worker. Their primary function is to diagnose and treat cases of conduct disorder in children. They are usually maintained in connection with public schools, juvenile courts, hospitals, universities, etc. They are strictly scientific in their procedure and are sometimes organized to promote research and the training of workers.
Cases coming before these clinics are usually referred by judges, social workers, teachers, parents, etc. Each case is exhaustively studied from the following standpoints: Family background, Home conditions, Physical history, Present physical condition, Intelligence, Special abilities or disabilities, Temperament and character, School attainment, Occupation, Recreation and leisure activities, Life history, Delinquency, The child's own history, etc.
It has been found that it is far more efficient and humane to deal with children's misconduct in this scientific way than to resort to the old, dubious process of punishment. Next in importance to the advent of the juvenile court itself in the treatment of juvenile delinquency is the development of the modern child guidance clinic, with its scientific analysis and treatment of the causes of misconduct.
Questions
1. What are the essential conclusions of Dr. Healy in regard to the causes and cures of delinquency?
2. Why is it important to accurately discover the causes of delinquency?
3. What is a juvenile court? How does it differ from any other court?
4. How much juvenile delinquency is there in your community? Is it increasing or decreasing? Can you get any reliable statistics on the subject? Why not?
5. Is there a juvenile court serving your community? Is it strictly modern and forward-looking? Does the judge employ scientific methods in determining the causes and treatment of delinquency in the children who come before him? Why is not your community more up-to-date in this respect?
6. Outline a program for the prevention and treatment of delinquency in your community.
*See his book The Individual Delinquent, Little, Brown Company, 1919. 688 RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE conditions, such as adolescence or precocity in growth; (9) a family history of intellectual weakness; (10) defective family relationships—the absence of a father, the presence of a stepmother; (11) influences operating outside the home—as bad street companions and lack or excess of facilities for amusement; (12) a family history of temperamental disorder—of insanity or the like; (13) a family history of physical weakness; (14) poverty and its concomitants; and, last of all, (15) physical infirmity or weakness in the child himself." Among his other conclusions may be noted the following: "On an average, each delinquent child is the product of nine or ten subversive circumstances, one as a rule preponderating and all conspiring to draw him into crime."
